headline: Awful workplace but go for it if you can
pros:
-Exit opportunities. Bain is Bain and if you made it in, you will have a fun, lucrative career that will be what you will make of it.
-Transfer opportunities. You can get a transfer to another office that might actually be a better experience.
-Learning. People here are very smart and will push you to be a great analyst. Additionally, Bain's international training programs are the best in the business, and the learning materials are awesome. If you have the time and curiosity, you can immerse yourself in fascinating insight.
-Perks. Not during COVID, but it's great to travel around and have expenses generously covered.
cons:
Toxic environment, period. Where do I start?
1. Feedback is never genuine. You could grind to improve on something mundane just to be beaten on it over and over. Once the hounds smell blood, you can never recover. Your cohort will dwindle and soon enough it will look like a season of survivor. This also harms the relationships you create while in Bain because it's just a long struggle and not something you reminisce.
2. The managers and the partners are mostly unpleasant. Mentorship is not genuine at all, there is no sense of collegiality, and there are no sources for support. When I first got in I couldn't get a 1:1 with my mentor for months, and everybody knew that the guy just doesn't like being there so what could I possibly learn from him or get help on?
3. Nobody has time, ever. Especially since COVID. Nobody has time to give you feedback or have a PD chat. Nobody has time to befriend you. You will be extremely lonely and just wait for it to end. Pre COVID this was different but the culture has not recovered.
4. Diversity not only doesn't exist - this place is openly discriminatory. I constantly heard misogynistic comments from managers and consultants, such as "women don't do well in these interviews so we had to change them", or "women can't drive". I really don't want to know what they have to say about non-white or non-straight people. Women are told that if they feel that their team doesn't want to hear their opinions, maybe they should stay quiet and learn.
5. HR, like in most corporate places, is a rubber stamp. Please don't go to HR if you have issues, and just try to stick around long enough until you find your next step.
6. Many people here get physically ill because of how much they have to work and how much pressure they are facing. It's not that hard to extend deadlines with clients or work more efficiently - but Bain doesn't teach you that. Instead, you will reiterate font sizes until your head drops on the keyboard. 
7. The up-or-out structure is not what it used to be. You don't get long severance anymore with decent time to look for a new place, and there is no real process to get you on track if you're not doing well enough. You just get a call one day saying you're done and good luck. Even the manager on your case might not know and you'll be the one telling them. Yeah they put you on a PIP but it's maybe 4 weeks long and there is 0 transparency about the whole thing. It has become a theme in this office that talent is not nurtured or discovered - their job is to find bros like them who will become abrasive managers and partners with the ability to squeeze any drop of productivity from the consultants and generate big buck for the firm.
8. Just to reinforce the pros - despite everything I said, go for it. stay for 1.5-2.5 years, that's enough, don't dig through reddit forever to learn that you need to leave as a manager. Get the fast learning of the first year and then start looking outside, there will be something waiting for you and I thank Bain for that.

headline: Worst HR Leadership!!!
pros: There are NO PROS (thanks to HR)!
cons:
Bain has the WORST HR Leadership in the industry. They are non-existent for employee grievances. They would only cater to their own personal interests e.g. development and promotions for HR individuals only. 

However, other business functions (e.g. TSG, Finance, KM, Marketing, IT) are lowest priority and they do not care about them. 

In the offices at GBS (India and Warsaw) and BCN (India), the situation is truly alarming. The senior most office leadership is in sync with corrupt HR practices. Employees are not offered any flexibility and their opinions are tactically suppressed. Often fake surveys are run and any genuine suggestions from these are never addressed.

headline: GBS = Unhealthy Environment to Work
pros: There were none (honestly!)... Just empty brand name.
cons:
"GBS = Unhealthy Environment to Work" - Yes, it may sound sarcastic but the people policies at this office are very much in line with this unholy expression.

They do not want you to stand up and express yourself anywhere. Every year, they run a fake WWES survey in the office and coach (or literally instruct) during the whole year and meetings to fill higher ratings for the office.

They have hired a bunch of incompetent people in a team, so that everyone keeps saying - 'Yes Boss'...Not only the team is inexperienced but they lack skill to deal with complex matters, such as salary benchmarking, experienced hiring, etc..

The leadership team keeps sending emails about new and existing policies every week, so that people are reminded that they cannot talk or escalate their genuine issues to anyone.

The local office leadership doesn't even know to draft proper emails. They only loves to discuss about a favourite topic i.e. Alcohol and that's it. The employees in general do not connect to the language and expressions. They always toes the line with a particular team to ensure their internal harmony.

headline: Company pretends to care about you
pros: Bain is a great investment in your career. You learn different skillsets, meet smart people, work in different industries and make decent money. The benefits are great. The prestige is also great. But the lifestyle is not for everyone.
cons: The leadership loves saying how much they care about people, the welfare and mental health of employees, etc... and naive people like me usually believe that... until they actually need help/assistance with something regarding their personal lives. HR will tell you that they can't do anything because of "company rules". Partners will tell you the same. Colleagues will feel bad for you but cannot really do anything. In the end, you're just a number and there are thousands of other people dying to work for the company, so your particular issue is not worth their time. You work late nights, weekends, sacrifice your personal life for the job... but when you need something, you're on your own.

headline: Extraordinary company
pros: In most of the ways that matter, Bain are one of the most remarkable companies to work for in the world. Their forensic focus on bettering the individual and empowering the collective stands them out from a crowd of world-class consultancies. The benefits are industry-leading and the compensation is usually very competitive (and consistently bench-marked both regionally and sectorially). The slogan 'a Bainie never lets another Bainie fail' made me cringe entering the company, but nearly every interaction and experience during my time here has reinforced the sway those words hold in Bain's corporate ethos.
cons: Minimal. Internal progression for non-consultants can be a little stilted and wrapped up in bureaucracy but the company are working actively to out-innovate and out-think their opposition in this respect.

headline: Best place to start a career
pros: You'll learn more here than just about anywhere else. The people are tremendous, and Bain has a rock solid culture of fun and respect that I haven't seen at other consulting firms. Your start class will give you friends for life, your managers will become your greatest cheerleaders, and if you choose to leave, the world will be your oyster.
cons: Look, it's tough work. The hours are long, sometimes the job is uninteresting, sometimes clients are a nightmare, sometimes partners are a nightmare, and sometimes your team is a nightmare. That's life. There are other places that will pay you more, work you less, or be more interesting, but if you're looking for a well-rounded job that optimizes for all of the above factors, Bain is probably your best bet.

headline: Bro Culture, Micromanaging, and Poor Pandemic Response
pros: The benefits are pretty good.
cons:
I feel like this place did a 180 on me. My experience has not matched what was pitched in the interview.  I don't think anyone here is trying to be toxic but they certainly exhibit these behaviors in my experience.  Since starting here I have personally experienced gaslighting, micromanaging (wanting to read your emails for example), being interrupted, having my expertise questioned, etc. I do not feel heard and I do not feel like I have the autonomy needed to do my job. Unfortunately, this is a common experience for those in my demographic.

There are other cultural things that make me uncomfortable as well. There is so much pressure to participate in extracurricular Bain activities e.g. Bain band, pub crawls, etc. that I don't feel like I have a choice in saying no. If that's you're passion, by all means, jump in and have fun; but that's just not for me. The idea of singing songs about my workplace (as they do in Bain Band) is 100% offputting to me. We work here, this is not a capitalist worship house. It's also not super-inclusive to encourage constant after-hours activities (which are often at a bar). Imagine what that would feel like if you had a family, cared for a parent, or didn't drink for one reason or another. I'm not saying I'm against all work events or drinking at these things, I just think they could be more mindful of how this can make others feel. I personally feel obligated to attend lest I want to limit my professional goals. 

They also do these really bizarre reply alls -- to the entire office-- that are at best a waste of people's time and at worse inappropriate. I'm sure I must sound like a killjoy at this point but dang...I just think that folks should be able to opt into how social they want to be with people. I don't need to know about everyone's business to do my job. Don't get me wrong there are a lot of awesome people here and I think it's great to make friends at work. I just think it should be more organic. I don't want to have to comb through 100 emails har-haring at something that I'm not even involved with just to get to my actual work emails.

They've also had a really bizarre approach to the pandemic in recent months. Lately, there has been a huge push to get folks back to the office. Sure there are precautions they have in place, like twice-weekly testing, but it's still an odd choice to pack folks into the open floor plan (most people maskless to boot) just for the sake of it. What's really odd is how jovial they seem to be about it. They'll email out pictures of crowded lunchrooms, meetings, etc as evidence of how great it is that folks are back and then offhandedly mention the breakthrough cases that happened. I get that there is a value in being in the same space every now and again but to what end? We can't simply will the pandemic to end and folks are working perfectly well from home. It just comes off as that old-school management thing where they want to watch over your shoulder all the time.


There are also a lot of issues with the values and historical decks/content that would 100% not fly today(but are still being used for some reason). For example, they want you to have an "insurgent mindset" which is just really gross sounding. A lot of what they do feel like 1984 doublespeak to me. For example, a few women on a recent panel talked about how great Bain was to them when they became mothers. They both mentioned stepping into lower roles so they could be with their kids more. Now on the one hand this could be a great thing...if Bain is helping people with kids find the right work-life balance then that's cool. Unfortunately, I didn't get that vibe. I might be reading into it too much but their stories made it sound like leadership roles at Bain require so much work after hours that it'd be very difficult for parents (especially mothers ) to maintain them. I'm not saying this is the case, this is simply my impression of what was shared. 

Overall I just think this place is designed for people with very different backgrounds than my own.

headline: Great learnings, good fun, hard work
pros:
- Colleagues are extremely smart + motivated + socially skilled, absolutely a pleasure to work with and a combination that is hard to find anywhere else. Bain differentiates vs. direct competitors especially on that last element and clients recognize this
- Diverse assignments in terms of client, industry, topic, role and team composition. You're not being asked to specialize until the senior manager level, which is great for diverse experiences initially. Specialization later on comes at a natural moment when you take on increasing project and client responsibility
- Family-like culture that goes beyond just being good colleagues, especially in Amsterdam. This is reinforced because of the staffing model that is more local than McK or BCG. Many friendships for life are built. There is so much social activity that you'll have to be selective to not drown in it
- High flexibility in the career path you want to take - much more so than at McK and BCG at the time I worked there
- Good compensation, roughly at par with McK and BCG
cons: The hours are the biggest drawback. The Amsterdam office aims for a 55 hour average work week and takes action when hours escalate. However, in the end it remains a personal responsibility. You have the choice between a 80, 90 or 100% solution and there is always another challenge to tackle if you want. There is quite some variation in hours between colleagues based on their personal preferences, ability to do the 80% solution and ability to say 'no'. In the end, it's in your own hands. And of course there will always be the occasional spike before a big deadline or when something unexpected happens, when you give the extra push with the entire team (which tend to be great moments actually).

headline: Room to improve vs. top tier in Spain
pros:
- Some leaders at the leadership team: excellent professionals. Willing to coach you and honestly helping you in your development.
- Efforts to foster office initiatives and company culture
- Salary in line with MBB
- Exposure to EMEA international cases - if you like
cons:
- Some leaders with doubtful professional standards
- High exposure to a couple of industries/practices, while others not existing/developed
- Diversity pushed to the limit on mid-junior level: leading to doubtful performance assessments and differentiating the performance bar for the sake of "been more diverse". Senior level full of male-het. 
- Mid-senior management hired externally mostly coming from lower profile consultancies. Few exceptions on top tier.
- Highly traditional way of thinking is not uncommon leading to a mid-junior consultant having the perception of is better to shut up than speak up. It feels comical looking at how some of these more traditional leaders try to defend a newer industry trend when having no real clue than a few general slides.

[not an inconvenient, the MBB standard in Spain]: 70-75h/week with some fluctuation on PE and FS, where is typically higher

cons: Consulting at the MBB level is never an easy job and it's not for people who want a 40-hour workweek. But I've found Bain does everything possible to mitigate the downsides (e.g. lots of flexibility on travel, people who genuinely care about how you're doing).

headline: Don't choose the Brussels office
pros:
- Excellent learning experience, feedback culture pushes employees a lot
- Nice perks outside of Covid times
cons:
- Toxic HR leadership, office head is doing his best to improve the environment, but HR leadership's childish behaviour is making a lot of people leave.
- You're a resource that should be maximized. Don't believe the polished marketing, Bain does not care about you.
- Sustainability is terrible, worse than many other European offices. Managers assume that you will work at least 65 hours per week, and they will make sure you deliver these hours even if it is not always needed.
- Massively underpaid for the sacrifices you need to make. You work in the same team as people from other offices, but some of them earn 2x as much as you.
- Workforce of insecure overachievers creates culture of fake and embellished upward feedback. If you express sincere feedback that is slightly too critical, you will be immediately seen as a threat.
- "A Bainie never lets another Bainie fail" is a joke. This is a free for all, people will throw you under the bus if they can.

headline: Great Company, but be comfortable with your offer
pros:
Bain has an incredible working community. There truly aren't weak links in this chain, I've never worked in a place where I am so appreciate and supported by my co-workers. It's generally very invested in it's employees and the benefits are very thoughtful. 

There are a lot of places to plug in, but you really have to be motivated and self-starting in order to go anywhere here. In the assistant position, potential growth is extremely limited and there is not currently a path for assistants to be promoted within the company.
cons:
There is zero wage transparency and many antiquated compensation practices that negatively impact BIPOC and women for hourly employees. 

If you're expecting salary growth, this is not the company for you. There is one promotion available to assistants with a significant raise and after that you're done. This promotion is based more on the needs of the company than the qualifications of the employees, so you could be waiting for less than a year for a promotion, or you could be there for 4 years. 

Raises are typically awarded at about the rate of inflation and are non-negotiable. If you are comfortable with your salary offer, you'll be fine.

Manager Assistants support six people and are not allowed overtime. It's a response to the pandemic that they are currently planning on making permanent. Do not factor in overtime to your compensation because they expect you to keep your hours under 40 a week (and it's not a 40-hour a week job, closer to 45-50 if you're working at a sustainable pace).

You are able to influence your development path: work in different countries, with different practice areas and you can transfer / focus on the area of your interest after getting exposure to it.
cons: For a successful career, it is essential to be able to navigate your home office politics and find powerful promoters. Some new hires are not naturally gifted at this, while some get unlucky to be staffed for prolonged periods with partners and managers they cannot find fit with.

headline: A fantastic place to work
pros:
* Company (and office) culture - this is an organization that lives its values - and where everyone believes in them. People are always willing to go out of the way to help each other, and leadership teams really are invested in helping teams be as effective as possible
* Mentorship - There is no supervisor (no matter how senior) who is not open to having a chat in a two-week window. Partners are willing to chat about career choices, share industry expertise, or offer life advice, and most of them really have an open-door policy.
* Breadth of experience - In 2 years, I have been exposed to cases in more than 6 industries - a great place to learn about a variety of industries and functions
* Benefits - Bain really tries to provide the best suite of benefits to its employees and their families (healthcare, parental leave, etc.)
cons: * Work-life balance - even with the shift to WFH, 65+ hour weeks are not uncommon. There is a lot of variability in that weekly schedule as well

It's not the right place for designers who wants to develop and grow outside the core skillset. Designers are treated as 2nd class citizens. We are of support to the case teams and are not allowed to manage client relations. We are left outside the leadership team, no mater you experience and job title, designers are no expected to have a seat at the table, where the real decisions are made. That makes it hard to grow. Actually, there is no real difference between a junior and a lead designer; they have the same responsibilities and same deliverables.
Designers are requested solely to do hands-on work fast and cut as many corners as possible to deliver on time and please the partner and client expectations, without thinking to the real users' needs.

headline: Brilliant colleagues, amazing culture, meaningful work, and flexible career paths
pros:
Bain is an amazing place to start and accelerate your career. You work on meaningful and complex challenges, while doing so in teams of smart, humble, and creative colleagues. You learn how to frame and solve problems and collaborate effectively within Bain and with clients. 

Bain also offers tremendous flexibility and flexible career paths beyond consulting e.g., expert / specialist roles, part-time positions, functional roles, etc. These roles offer a fantastic value proposition for those who want to develop more functional expertise while still doing so with Bainies and within an amazing culture.
cons: As with all professional services work, the hours can be demanding and variable. However, many roles at Bain also offer predictable hours and better work/life balance.

headline: Grateful for Bain!
pros: With the craziness of 2020, one of the things I am most grateful for is the support, understanding and compassion that Bain & Company showed towards it's employees. From the global pandemic, important social issues and stressful political issues that were affecting all of us, the company really proved that they truly cared about their people. They not only offered physical, emotional and financial support, but they also took additional steps to create fun and uplifting work environments for everyone. Simple things like encouraging virtual team events and creating ways for us all to stay connected, it really made a difference when things were difficult as we sheltered at home. I feel extremely fortunate to work with such inspiring leaders and for a company who proved that keeping their people safe and healthy was their top priority.
cons: There are no downsides, but I do miss going to the office and seeing my colleagues this past year!

headline: A solid company- you'll learn a lot, you'll give a lot
pros:
Amazing amount of learning, super smart people, strong professional development opportunities. No one signs up for consulting thinking it's going to be a walk in the park. You will work damn hard. The variety that comes with projects means some are stellar and some are rough. But you will learn an incredible amount. And Bain's culture is a mile ahead of any other consulting firms- they put a lot of effort into finding and retaining great people. Can honestly say I never disliked anyone at my time at Bain and that's incredible.

Was proud to see Bain take some big steps to confront racial inequality. I hope they've followed through with some of the promises made in June.
cons: Hours, burnout, inconsistency in HR/management. The hours can be really tough long term, which is why most people leave. The best at Bain find their niche and how to balance life and work. Management can depend based on project but overall the company puts a lot of work into developjng managers.

headline: Good pay and health benefits, strong culture if in the office
pros: Good pay and benefits, hours aren’t too bad. A lot of events if you are in the office (but you better like to drink - a lot!)
cons:
The company is very “office focused” so there is a lot of redundancy and it’s almost impossible to meet people from outside of your office, leading to group-think. This means the firm culture also had a hard time switching to virtual (granted, technology wise, they did a pretty good job), since it was so focused on in-person activities. Every office leader sends their own messaging, instead of there being national policies sent out. It also needs to refresh a lot of its policies (more vacation, allow people to work remotely [after covid]).

Separately, it is impossible to figure out the promotion process or standards if you are not a consultant.

headline: Hardworking and intelligent people with brutal and toxic culture
pros:
- Potential to learn if right staffing
- Some people are open to giving feedback (quality not great)
- High career opportunities at exit
- Power of the brand
cons:
- No open communication (Culture of retalliation)
- Ego-culture with army like hierarchy. Lower ranked employees do not have a voice. Aggressive behaviour and raised tone (i.e. shouting) not unusual
- Face time culture (~65-85h) even if case doesn't require it
- Toxic people management, managers are not trained nor incentivised to deal with people
- Potential to grow highly influenced whether you fit in (or sleep with) the right people
- Staffing is about knowing the right people
-HR has good intentions but no power (questions on confidentiality HR conversations but not proven)
- Managers have no clue how to motivate people, burnouts are regular. 
- Lowest ranked employees payed ~€8/h whereas partners take home millions
- Diversity is a joke

headline: Great work, interesting people, lots to learn, some hypocrisy in sustainability
pros:
Steep learning curve with many chances to take ownership of workstreams (at any level) 
Excellent client set 
Interesting work (most of the time) 
Fantastic training programs
cons:
At the firm level, there is a focus on sustainability - but sometimes this gets washed away by individual case teams, especially since WFH started. Raising these issues to your direct manager/sr. manager can only help in the short term (1-2 days of focus, and then return to the norm). Far too often LT gets defensive during sustainability conversations where junior/mid level team members have to justify the hours they have worked.

Overall leads to junior team members not speaking up about sustainability or motivation issues, because who wants to get into an argument with their boss' boss on how much work you do on a daily basis? 

For many cases, have seen LT promising to do work outside scope and not bring in additional resources, which then burdens the team. 

Post covid: Weekend work (used to be taboo at Bain) has become the norm, super late nights (1-2am) and early mornings (7-8am) which used to be 2-3 days / week have become modus operandi. HR is working to improve post-covid sustainability, but won't be very successful till case teams stop doing work outside the scope. 

Also, 15 days of paid leave is not sufficient or in line with India's market practice. Needs to be improved.

I feel incredibly fortunate to work with colleagues (and a supervisor) who are incredibly supportive, particularly during a challenging 2020. My colleagues are smart, driven, passionate, committed and fun. Tough to imagine I could find a more special place to make a career.

headline: People come first. Period.
pros:
- Incredible team of people. Lots of companies say they put their people first, but Bain actually does it. Let's acknowledge upfront that that makes a lot of business sense in a world where people are the product, but Bain truly delivers. Some examples: I had a team who fought for me, who pushed against the odds and the statistics, to get me the opportunities that were exciting to me. I had someone who worked for me who dropped everything when her peer's father caught COVID - this led to some crazy hours and stressful days, but this individual believed in our operating principle "A Bainie Never Lets Another Bainie Fail" - something that has permeated everyday of my career here. My path hasn't been standard but I have felt deeply supported and seen as an individual at each step of the way. 
- We do great work for our clients. Cliche, I know. But as I work with my clients, it's clear that Bain is different. We focus on delivering value that the client can actually realize - it's not about the academically perfect answer or something complex that will require 5 more years of consulting. It's about making the client successful. 
- Can't get thru 2020 without mentioning COVID. Bain went work from home before SF city ordinances (which were some of the earliest in the country) and has put employee safety first at every step. This includes people moving across the country to be with family or needing flexible work schedules to manage child care or other WFH needs.
- We aren't the most diverse company and have struggled to recruit and retain people of color and LGBTQ individuals. And I've seen Bain step up this year to fix this. Including massive financial commitments, changes to our operating principles, Diversity committee to report to MD to evaluate and track stats, an Americas-wide Juneteenth training on systemic racism and what it means at Bain. We are nowhere near the end of the road here, but as a gay woman, I believe in what the leadership is saying and setting out as a goal and direction for the company.
cons:
- it can be a bit of "you put in X years, you get Y reward" but I do think that's shifting over time
- If you aren't starting as an AC (right out of college) ... it can be alienating - the ACs who work here get such incredible opportunities and boosts that those joining out of biz school never had... I've heard many people discount how hard it is to get into schools like HBS and GSB because "it's just expected." As someone who fought for that degree, it can come off as cavalier, discounting, and perhaps "holier than thou" (oh you had to work for this thing that was just a duh for me? poor you...). Have to develop a tough skin and know that your path was worthy and real and important to survive that egotistical stuff.

headline: Best place to work!
author_position: Lead, EA/MA Program, Senior Human Resources Specialist
pros:
Bain is a company that not only talks about its culture but is a company that the culture is lived and breathed every day from all levels of the organization. From the moment you walk into the office on your first day, you feel welcome, appreciated, and respected. I have been with Bain for a year and during this year I have had the opportunity to work with a number of different people in varying roles; From my direct boss to her boss, I feel as though I have support when I need it and mentors to look up to. The caliber of the individuals at Bain is very high and you are always challenged to do your best, which is ideal when you want to thrive and grow with a company. From our office head down, I feel as though the support and care are genuine.
Bain is able to make coming to work fun! There are so many social events that you can get involved in, which also foster interconnectivity between different departments/people.
Bain has handled COVID in a way that has been supportive to the employees by allowing budgets for home ergonomics and technology to optimize the WFH set up. Although many things are unknown for the world right now, I feel as though Bain has been communicative throughout the whole process.
This is a company that I love and am very proud to work at! Bain is forward-thinking, inclusive, proactive, and ahead of the curve in many respects. This is the kind of company that you aspire to work for.
cons: No cons to report at this time as all questions and queries I have are usually always resolved.

headline: Great place to start and/or advance a career in business
pros:
- Fast learning curve: You'll always have the chance to stretch and grow
- Supportive environment: "A Bainie never let's another Bainie fail" - your colleagues want you to be successful and will help you achieve that.  That includes your case team supervisor and leadership team, sponsor, mentors, etc.
- Interesting work: You'll work on the toughest problems for the world's leading companies
- Incredibly capable colleagues: There is nothing quite like a problem solving whiteboard session with a Bain case team
- Better job sustainability than other Big 3 Consulting firms on average: I have a young family and have expressed a preference to work on local cases to avoid travel - my preference has been respected 100% of the time over the last 3.5 years!
- Global training in cities across the world: I've attended trainings in Cape Cod, Lisbon, and Dubai.
- Opportunity for temporary international assignments: I spent 6 months in Santiago, Chile working in the Bain office there with my family.
cons: - Job predictability can be low (e.g., unforeseen client request, partner feedback requiring immediate response, etc.), but that is a con associated with consulting in general, not vs. other Big 3 consultancies.

cons: Work-life balance in a top tier management consulting environment is at best a pipe dream. Some people are able to make it work, but a lot of it is a roll of the staffing die, and how happy you can be working 60+ hours per week in a high pressure environment. It's a shame because I always loved the work itself and the people, but it just wasn't what I wanted my life and stress level to be every day. They do a lot to make it more tolerable, but at the end of the day it's really the nature of the work.

Blamed me for things that went wrong and never saw my side. Cancelled a few overseas training sessions with no reason. Zero development. Quitting was the best day there. Im now in a good place and progressed in my IT career but sometimes when I remember my time in Bain all those years ago I just cringe.

headline: Best consulting firm to work for
pros: Great culture - people tend to be very supportive and willing to help if you need it. You get to work with major companies - often the biggest or top 3 in their respective industries. There is a greater emphasis on client relationships vs. other firms, and more client engagement. This translates into longer-term cases with the same client. This can be pretty rewarding since you not only get to develop a strategy or an improvement plan, but also help implement it (or at least begin to implement it). Travel is not that bad - although you travel frequently, Bain staffs on a regional level, meaning that you won't be flying across the country. Instead, you will typically be in the same state/one state away.  Great pay & benefits. Very clear career progression path (with tough cut-offs), but if you make it to the next level, pay and responsibility increases are substantial.
cons: Typical cons endemic to consulting as an industry - your work doesn't always get used by the client. Even if the work does get used, many cases are short (as consulting services are expensive), so, you don't really get to see your recommendations be implemented, but end up moving on to the next case - although at Bain that is less likely to happen than at other firms, since there tend to be longer-term client relationships. Also, the hours can be quite brutal with some weekend work. In general, it is hard to have a balanced life during the work week - you are not going to be taking community college classes and grabbing drinks with your friends on Thursday nights. If you want to have a gym routine, better try to go in the morning before work. However, that's a trait of consulting as an industry, and is not specific to Bain.

headline: This might be the best job I've had yet.
pros:
The work: 

Working on some incredibly interesting problems, with incredibly smart people is exhilarating. From driving forward AI in cars, to driving sustainability in farming and agriculture.

The people:

Imagine picking some of the nicest, most intelligent people in a workplace, and then having an entire company made out of those people. Everyone loves to have fun, and goes the extra mile to make sure work can be fun.

The perks:

Bain will take care of you. They'll make a lot of nuisances in life go away.
cons: Monday morning to Friday afternoon, Bain owns your life. Depending on the project, this can mean going home at 5-6pm everyday, but it can also mean long hours, stress, and tons of unpredictability.

headline: Do not work on this team - you will not matter
pros:
Culture-oriented
Great Location
Great interior design, lots of space to choose from to do work
Free coffee, bananas, food options
cons:
Double standards, favoritism, management is absentee or not willing to listen to employee concerns and create actionable solutions to benefit the employee and the team.  

They tout "one-team" oriented environment and being "at cause", but that's only when it's convenient for them.  When push comes to shove (when you attempt to be "at cause"), and they have to "deal with you," they will make you feel like YOU are the problem.  This is also because they lack the skill-set to effectively mediate a situation.  Do not try to voice a concern, this will only make YOU look "difficult."  

Basically, they are about themselves, not you.  If you have a problem, they will turn it against you and then have HR gang up on you to make you feel like even less of a person.  I've seen this happen with almost every person I've ever worked with in Graphics for the last 10 years, and it's getting worse by the year.  If you don't mind being a grunt without a voice, this is the place for you.  I didn't often seen happy faces walking down those newly designed halls.. most people seem miserable and unfriendly.

NOTE - I gave this an extra star for the free bananas.

headline: Great foundation for career progression surrounded by passionate colleagues
pros:
The people at Bain are truly top notch. It's incredible to feel like you're a part of a community that's in your corner and wants to propel your career, no matter where it may head. The amount that you can learn from the work, the people, the clients, etc. is incredible. The people at Bain truly believe in their culture and work can sometimes be, dare I say it, fun because of the energy everyone brings to the table!

The amount of exposure you get to see how Fortune 500 companies operate is incredible. 

Benefits are top notch, 5% 401k contribution, despite what you put in (better than matching!)

Company is very transparent about the state of the business.

Fast career trajectory.
cons:
Work life balance is challenging broadly in the management consulting field, however Bain does a relatively good job relative to its peers, with a "GAL" (get-a-life) / "virtual baby" culture where you get ~1 early night per week, typically. Work hours can range from ~55-80 hours per week depending on the client, office, and manager. 

Staffing is a bit of a challenge in that you don't necessarily know where you'll be on the next case - either in terms of work life balance, or physical location - and you only get some say in the matter.

Bain & Company is the most demanding and most rewarding place I have ever worked. I am challenged at every turn -  which is outstanding.
cons: Limited telework flexibility for support staff. Considering today's technology, it is an outdated concept that one must be physically in the office all but one day a month in order to give 100%. Also, there should be a path for administrative advancement/promotion .  Perhaps a path of MA to Senior MA to EA to Senior EA to Executive EA...something like that?  Ambition is a quality of all successful Bainies, no?

headline: Fantastic people, great career options
pros: Wonderful people who are smart, kind, talented, and care about your development. Strong culture of feedback and continuous learning. Very strong office culture. Less mandatory travel than many other consulting firms. Good benefits and phenomenal company events. Great exit opportunities.
cons: Hours can be tough, creating a difficult balancing act between work and personal time. Less control over casework/staffing situation than you would sometimes like.

headline: Awesome company, incredible teammates, great culture, super interesting projects, commitment to sustainability
pros:
- Incredible culture: many events, diverse talent pool, emphasis on connectedness, focus on personal development, learnings (worldwide trainings every ~year), mentorship, etc.
- Very interesting projects: cover all industries, help top CEOs to solve their most complex issues, we directly see the impact of our work, increasing use of digital technologies
- Smart, curious, passionate talent who become close friends
- Emphasis on improving sustainability
- A lot of opportunities to create our own experience (abroad transfers, externships, time-off)
- Awesome compensation and benefits
- Great business opportunities (business growing fast)
cons: - Potentially long hours on some of the cases

headline: Amazing and rewarding place to learn and grow; best company culture I've encountered hands down
pros:
-The best place to learn and grow professionally if you're interested in business - you're always being stretched to learn and grown and try new things
-Extremely rewarding at each stage of the career from a compensation and benefits perspective
-High touch professional development team helps you feel like you're not just a cog-in-the-wheel, I feel like I've had a very personalized journey through Bain over 6 years
-Best culture and combination of high performance people that actually treat each other well
-I feel prepared to go do so many different things, and at the same time I've continually opted into the role and the path here
cons:
The two things the firm is working to address are consistent with what I would observe:
-Sustainability - this is a hard job. A really hard job. The culture is super high performing and the problems we solve are not easy. This means that it's hard to turn your brain off of the work even if you leave for home at a reasonable hour. The upside is that relative to other consulting firms, the home office staffing model does very materially make this more of a sustainable place to build a long-term career in consulting. I've been here 6 years and could not have possibly done that if traveling 4 days/week as at many other firms. 
-Diversity and inclusion - consistent with many aspects of the corporate world, Bain is behind where it wants to / needs to be on the dimension of consulting staff diversity. I've been encouraged by how

headline: Great people, fascinating work

cons: Sometimes the hours can be long, but with a team of great people I've never felt overwhelmed.

headline: Amazing place to develop while working on impactful problems
pros: Outstanding opportunities for professional development and learning, consistent exposure to the our clients' most important (and challenging) problems, results-focused work, amazing culture with high-caliber and supportive colleagues, generous compensation with upside as you progress
cons: Hours and travel can be challenging at times

headline: Amazing colleagues, amazingly impactful work
pros: You won't find a more committed, passionate group of co-workers anywhere. Everybody here, at every level, deeply cares about the work they do. I've never been anywhere that has such  high achievers who consistently work collaboratively. There's no competitiveness, only support. I learn on the job from others every day. The reason I'm at Bain a lot longer than i ever anticipated is because i continue to learn and am surrounded by amazing people
cons: You'll work hard at Bain but the rewards, both tangible and intangible, are worth it

headline: Best place to jumpstart your career
pros:
I started with Bain out of school and have stayed longer than I ever thought I would.  What I love about the job is the combination of...
- Accelerated learning (chance to manage teams very early in your career)
- Working on hot topics (cases working on C-level issues)
- The commitment to people (weekly coaching, consistent sponsorship) 
- The flexibility to make the job work for me (externships, LOAs, part-time)
- Feeling financially rewarded (pay off student debt fast, feel very secure)
cons: My biggest challenge in working at Bain is travel and 'having it all' (the client I want, the team I want, but all of that local to me).  There are ways to minimize time away from home - like working with private equity or local clients - but I haven't historically prioritized those in my planning, which means more time on planes and less time to be with friends during the week.

headline: Clearly the best place to work!!!
pros:
Bain allows people the flexibility to tailor their careers to their own interests and passions.  By ‘building your own Bain’, our team is able to test out different industries, different management topics, and different geographies throughout their time at Bain.  This allows them the ability to learn what gives them energy on the job, and shape their future career and experiences accordingly.

In addition to this, Bain supports all of its team as we build our own Bain through its apprenticeship model.  You are constantly challenged not the job as the clients, topics, and teams you work with are constantly changing, and expectations for your role increase as well.  But you always have more than enough support from mentors, sponsors, coaches, and supervisors to help ensure you that your ramp up quickly and are able to meet those challenges.  Truly, this apprenticeship focus is the best part of Bain & Company, and one that has helped me develop rapidly throughout my career here.
cons: Honestly, I can’tthin of anything here.

headline: Fantastic culture, great people, unparalleled learning
pros: You'll love the people you work with. They'll invest in you personally and you'll learn a tremendous amount at a rapid pace
cons: All that learning and development doesn't fit within a typical work week. You'll work hard and be all consumed by the high-impact work you're doing. If you're not good at drawing (and sticking to) boundaries, it may take more of you than you're happy about giving.

headline: Phenomenal career opportunities
pros: Bain has continued to provide me with a variety of interesting client problems to work on, with some of the absolute best co-workers. Bain focuses on working with 'action-oriented' clients, making our work not just interesting but impactful.
cons: As a parent with a spouse in a travel-oriented job, consulting is a challenge at time. Bain has been flexible in helping me balance these competing demands.

headline: Best mentoring opportunities
pros: Bain is by far the best place to start almost any career. The mentors you have along the way and after they and/or you leave are second to none. The analytical action oriented thinking is a rare, but extremely valuable skill in today's ever changing world.  The employees who work here all care about doing a great job, but also about life outside their case teams.
cons: This is a job that requires you to work hard and think to get better. You get out what you put in.

headline: Flexible, supportive, hard-working and fun
pros: When I describe my work and Bain to people who aren't familiar with them as an employer, everyone is just blown away by the flexibility, support and energy that are such core parts of my job.  I feel like we as a firm are making a difference in our work and in an environment that enables us to push ourselves to be better but in a way that plays to our strengths and have fun in the process.  It's an incredible place and I'm so glad to have been a part of this journey for the past ten years or so.
cons: We work hard and some people have to travel quite a bit.  It comes with the job and is energizing to many, but can be difficult at time.

headline: Bain is a great place to work.
pros: You get to work along side some of the best talent out there.  Our people make us what we are - a great firm and culture providing results for our clients.  Bain truly cares about their employees from offering great benefits and perks to always thinking how decisions will impact the employees.
cons: A little more flexibility on working from home would be nice.

headline: Come for the brand, stay for the culture and growth

headline: A dream come true
pros:
The most challenging problems across every industry - This is the first role I've had in which logging off to think for hours is acceptable and sometimes encouraged.
Deep client relationships for Bainies of all tenure - I was working side-by-side for weeks at a time with my client counterpart in my very first case. 
A collaborative and supportive environment of the best and brightest - I am constantly floored by how intelligent and generous everyone at the firm is with their time and energy.
cons: Work-life balance is hugely variable based on case assignment. We spend more time talking about sustainability than working to improve it on those cases or groups we know to be "burners." Those Bainies who have never worked outside of consulting have accepted 14 hour days as the norm instead of thinking critically about how to plan better to drive team efficiency and WLB.

headline: 4 year Bainie in Dubai
pros:
The consulting experience is probably the single greatest business-world crash course you could hope for in life. I came to Bain straight out of university, so I feel myself having been modled into the consultant mindset early. From strategy projects, to on-the-ground implementation, to developing the ability to master a subject matter quickly ("achieving expert status"), high-value communication, and even general organizational business experience getting perspectives in accounting, finance, ops, or sales. Overall I would say there is only pros from a career perspective for 2-4 years. 

Bain is renown amongst the big 3 for its culture, and I would have to say it has the best systems and people in the business. Its not like the others are bad, I think overall everyone has a high caliber workforce and great people, its just that Bain takes pride in making people the center of their employee experience, so they just take a bit more care for it systematically, and they look for the people "it" factor in their hires. I can't say that I've met any "bad" people though at McKinsey or BCG though.

Compensation is great, benefits are great, the trainings are super valuable, and the miles/hotel points were all great perks. I made friends for life here to, so your peers tend to be really high caliber folks you will likely keep in touch with for the rest of your life. Its an intense period, and you spends loads of late nights and airport time together, so bonding with good people is key.
cons:
The one major con would be work life balance and working hard, but I honestly find that it helped me develop a much stronger work ethic in life. If you're willing to sacrifice, it will pay off in the long run. 

Culture is there at Bain worldwide, but the project quality and work culture really depends on your office. The Dubai office is governed by Dubai clients, which tend to be a lot of implementation projects. The main sectors are Gov, Oil&Gas, Banking, Telco, and some cool Retail or M&A projects sprinkled in. The internal culture in Dubai is probably not as strong as in other Bain offices, because the clients here can be extremely demanding and in need a high quality people to get work done, which often lands on the consultants/managers. I would say that in comparison to other Bain offices though, the Dubai consulting staff is generally more developed early on in their careers, so its a great "step up opportunity" for you to learn fast and gain lots of responsibilities early in your career. Don't be mistaken though, its definitely an intense, often frustrating, work life balance. 

Longer term projects are also common in Dubai, so less flexibility, and that breeds a bit more internal politics than one would like to get projects that you like. But playing the game is also valuable learning lesson for industry. Its been 4-5 years since my Bain days though, so all that may have changed at this point. I wouldn't take back my time there, I think its an excellent career launching pad.

Senior management was a bit harsh and unrelatable in my time there. The good partners tend to already be booked out in terms of mentorship, so it was difficult to find a mentor you could really get behind, but once I did, I stuck with him and learned probably the most from him.

Sustainability - the work/life balance is a struggle for a lot of Bainies, from AC through partner

headline: Best people to work with
pros:

The company -- this company does so many things right; they have a very clear rubric for what is expected of you at every different role, and you can see how your role will grow and change over time. They also do a great job of giving reviews, both formal and informal to ensure that you are growing and developing over time. They also build in a lot of time to build the culture and develop a workplace that makes people want to show up.
cons: You don't have complete control over the projects that you work on, so you may end up doing something that you don't like. The work and the hours can be very difficult and can be unsustainable in the long run.

headline: Good for 2-3 years, but gets old
pros:
It sure pushes you and you will always be reflecting on how to get better in the job regardless of your actual performance. Good thing, as it accelerates careers for top performers, but not different from any other consulting firm - even heard actually slower than BCG or McK.
Branding helps when applying for future jobs.
Nice colleagues - made some good friends at Bain.
cons:
Sustainability is an issue, but not as bad as some other offices though.
Lots of biases on evaluation and even inaccurate assessment of work quality from upper management when they don't look closely at Analyst's work - ex.: if very inexperienced CTL or Consultant is overseeing team, Principal will believe what gets to his/her ears 100% without understanding the full picture.
Very hypothesis driven culture should be a good thing, but majority of the hypotheses are not actually tested as analyses are (very) poorly done to "goal seek" wanted results - I've seen several examples of that. Biases from upper management will for sure impact the results of your work as they are more worried with long term relationship and matching expectations from senior clients - so don't expect to change the world or do cool analyses, but otherwise expect to be one more piece of the puzzle for the relationship - it is a sales organization at the end of the day.
Some managers/partners in the LA office can be arrogant or hard headed.
Boring projects in the LA office - very few strategy projects, majority will be more operational.
Bain is a lot behind other top consulting firms in terms of digital work - just recently started hiring talent specifically for digital projects. Not sure how are things now, but it was chaotic and no one knew what they were doing.

headline: Wizard of Oz
pros: The Pros of working here include the pay, the amazing holiday party,  resources, as well as the incredible brand on one's resume.
cons: I equate Bain to the Wizard of Oz - something that is advertised as super amazing, but in reality it's not.  The culture is toxic. Most of the employees are incredibly unhappy, but stay for the perks and job stability. It is considered taboo to ever speak against the company culture. Anyone who voices their discontent is labeled a "bad seed" and quickly pushed out.  In regards to the day-to-day work: The work is the same recycled solution and there is little space for innovation and creativity. In one of my cases, I observed consultants actively fabricating data in an attempt to sell an "answer" to the client. When I brought this information up the ranks, even up to the Partner - it was pushed under the rug and I was punished for not being a team player. Little known fact: The company actually encourages current employees to write nice things on GlassDoor, as a means to increase the attractiveness of our Exit Opportunities.

headline: Bain Capability Centre - The best place to ruin your career
pros:
1. Meager office perks such as free food.
2.  Can't remember anything else
cons:
This is the only section that defines how working at BCC is like.
The company has the worst kind of ethics related procedure. Nothing is followed according to the ethics provided in the charter but is dependent on the whims and fancies of the group manager and team manager. This entity lures people from the market on the behest of it's respectable parent organization - Bain and company, but it's nothing close to it. I will break it down to discuss the different paradigms.

1. Culture

The entity is run by a cartel of group managers and their flatterer(team managers) who do things according to their will without any check. People at senior level are mostly not qualified enough to answer queries on the function they are handling. If they find out that you know more than them, get ready for an egoistic clash and a round of denigration on most of the matters.
If you are a lateral, you are in for a ride. I think this is the only company that very strongly differentiates it's hire as laterals or home growns - with most of the benefits going to the homegrowns since they have grown by agreeing to all fancies of the management. They have reviews and analysis by laterals vs homegrowns which definitely all the time makes the laterals feel like an outcast.
The easy way to success in the organization boils down to being a bootlicker of the senior management, have no views of your own and never challenge them in terms of knowledge - even though if you know more. If you do the above, you are sure to go places and earn promotion otherwise you might end up in a spot where they continuously find ways to mentally harass you.
No respect for a work life balance and I was amazed to see that senior people here most of the times don't have any work and are just passing time in the company - getting complacent with their own inability.
The senior management does not have industry knowledge and cannot groom you accordingly- chances are you would know more than them, only exception being if you want to be a master politician and harasser of people.
Concerns to the HR are never heard since every news goes out to the senior management who then dictate accordingly.

2. Work

In bold letters - This is not a strategy firm. It has all that of tactical work that no one in the industry wants to do and hence is sent to this great place. Working on shards of the complete glass, you never know what the project is talking about. If you have worked in the industry, you are coming to a place that will add aryabhata's zero to your resume. It would get so difficult to define this work outside and you would as well be in a state of demotion - a confidence shattering experience. All manual activities that the bain teams don't want to do are sent for disposal at this place which is definitely not a great motivation. The senior management is even scared to add new avenues as these things don't fall under their comfort level and it's been ages since they have actually worked up on something that would value add or is more relevant in the industry in current times.

3. People 

Be a flatterer and you rise without any work as well. Be an efficient worker merely keep yourself alive under the scrutiny of the big bosses.
The young freshers are quite good and smart, can't say the same about the senior management since they run it more like a shop or their own property. These people live in their own world and deem most of the laterals as culturally unfit - coming from the people who have stayed their entire life here and saying it to people who have actually done meaningful work globally - that's how irony looks.

headline: Not for me

cons: The hours are unpredictably long and grueling. Toxic leadership creates unnecessary stress, and there is no ability to “manage up” given most leaders are untouchable. Very slow to innovate. Hires smart people but does not let them think for themselves. Prefers to have employees who are willing to put their head down and take orders versus get creative and try new things. Consulting support staff are treated as second class citizens though they are key contributors to the company’s success. Don’t expect to be shown appreciation for your work — excellence is the baseline expectation. Career path is uninspiring, and path to promotion is over engineered. Promotion takes years, and if you’re one of the lucky ones to get there, you’ll just be continuing doing much of the same work.

headline: Lags peers in caring for its international (non-US) employees
pros: You get to work together with the smartest people around. Your managers will care about your development and will support you in whatever you hope to achieve.
cons:
They hire non-US citizens out of undergrad or MBA but their sponsorship policy is the worst when compared to McKinsey/BCG or do largest banks they compete with most of the time. 
Bain only applies for H1B visa once, and if you don't get it they will not re-apply, while most other consulting firms will offer to re-apply. 
Bain's policy is to send you to an office abroad (you have no choice in selecting it, it's rather selected on demand) and then you are brought back on L1 which ties you to the company for as long as you stay in the country. This means that if you don't get promoted or want to leave, you need to leave the US. 
Although they could apply for H1B which gives you the optionality to work at other companies in the future in the US, they won't do it. This means that as an international you are not allowed to use opportunities such as externships that your other peers are able to do.

headline: Client-focused, impactful, fun, and purpose-driven
pros: Bain if a mission-driven company: it is all about creating lasting impact at clients, helping them solve their toughest challenges (in co-creation), while creating a great team experience. Along that journey, each consultant gets to give the best of him/herself, which, in combination with the support we get from the rest of the team and senior leadership, enables us to grow/learn fast. Working at Bain is also about having fun - attending great event but also on a daily basis with the team.  Finally, Bain makes sure every employee is treated as an individual (e.g., staffing based on personal preferences like geography, etc.) and leadership can go out of its way to ensure you get successful.
cons: Long working hours can make working at Bain challenging. While significant progress has been made towards improving sustainability (flexibility models, extended parental leave, etc.), this remains a hard-working environment.

headline: Best place to work for business talent
pros: I cannot think of a better place to start your career.  You will develop exceptional hard skills (strategic insight, analytic prowess) and soft skills (compelling communications, inspirational leadership, stakeholder management), see a wide range of organizations and business problems, and get the best coaching you can imagine to become a well-rounded business leader.  Culture is fantastic -- people who join say it's even better than everything they had heard about it.  Every employee is cultivated to full potential, with not only great apprenticeship and mentorship but diverse growth opportunities (externships, transfers) and flex options (leave of absence, internal roles, part-time work).
cons: It is not for the faint of heart.  Be prepared to work very hard, constantly push and be pushed to deliver exceptional impact to our clients, feel always out of your depth and pushed out of your comfort zone.  Also be prepared for adversity -- you need to be a resilient person who can deal with curveballs and complex stakeholder situations.

headline: Great consulting experiences

headline: Amazing place to thrive and grow, incredible culture
pros:
+Everyone is very sharp, fast-thinking and very smart  - you learn just by being here around the other employees, and a ton of work is able to be done in short amounts of time. Not the same frustrating redundancy as at other companies.

+Home office model means you get to know your office very well, and are invested in and mentored heavily

+"Generalist" model means everyone's brains are trained to recognize patterns and ask critical questions regardless of industry, which means inexperience is still valuable and people carry a degree of humility with them into new projects

+Staffing manager that places you onto cases removes the "hustle" and a lot of the politics from landing a good project. A neutral arbiter is looking out for you, and taking your development needs into consideration alongside project needs. 

+Great comp, benefits - makes long weeks feel doable
cons:
It's not a job for someone looking for a super easy/sustainable lifestyle, at least in the more junior ranks  - you must really want to be doing this work, or working with these people, to be fine with 9pm meetings and a lot of change 

Though it's incredibly down-to-earth compared to other consulting firms, there is a degree of entitlement among people who have been at the company for a long time. Attitudes of knowing more than others, or being better by virtue of which school/MBA program you went to, show up sometimes more than I'd like.

The reality is, in SF, most of the work is private equity deals. Even if you're sold on the healthcare or retail practice, chances are you'll be doing diligencing (which is tough, long hours) for at least 6 months. Just be prepared - some love it, and find it an amazing way to learn, and others resent that they get staffed and have no choice.

headline: Senior Associate Consultant

Bain is a truly special and unique company and I feel so lucky to work here.
cons: The consulting job has very high upside in terms of training, boosting your career, and compensation. However, the work is challenging, the hours can be long, and you'll be pushed outside of your comfort zone often. It's an incredibly high learning curve and as soon as you feel comfortable, your teams will push you into new responsibilities. headline: Best place I could imagine starting my career!
pros: My favorite thing about Bain are the people and the culture. The people there are the reason I am excited to go to work every day, my main motivating factor and my greatest resources for learning and growth. One of my good friends once described the culture as a place where everyone takes their work very seriously but not themselves, and I couldn't agree more. While we work really hard , we also have a ton of fun! Bain continually pushes to create an environment that is extremely open and accepting of all people which is also greatly appreciated. Aside from the people and culture, the thing I value most about Bain is the amount of constant learning and growth I get to experience as a result of both structured and experiential training as well as an intense focus on personal professional development. All of this, combined with providing exceptional results to clients, combines for an unbeatable work experience and the best place I could imagine starting my career (plus the exit opportunities are incredible).

The Chicago office specifically is known for having great culture, and we often celebrate individual and group successes in the office by recognizing strong contributions to our community.  The opportunities to grow and develop, especially as a relatively junior member, are huge, and I believe I have been able to learn more here than I would have starting my career anywhere else.

headline: Working at Bain
pros:
Surely, there are many great companies to work with, and there is much to discover within different industries. This is especially true in a time of disruptive change, when organizations rethink their business models and constantly have to challenge the way in which they create customer value. Being part of such an organization and accompanying it along its journey is definitely a worthwhile career path.
 
However, in a world that is getting more and more interconnected every day, an interdisciplinary and cooperative approach is key to managing the likewise increasing complexity. Therefore, even better than accompanying one organization along its journey is working with a great range of different organizations from various industries to be able to identify meta level patterns of competitive advantage.
 
I experienced that working at Bain gives one the opportunity to support top level executives of leading companies, driving their key programs and resolving their toughest problems. Therefore, one can really have an impact that, in hindsight, will be seen as industry-shaping.
 
Within Bain you can feel the ambition to create value for the customer every single day. More importantly, the pursuit of true results, i.e. sophisticated concepts AND their pragmatic translation into measurable business success, is omnipresent.
 
What is special about Bain is the great proximity that has been created within its global network. People from all around the world feel deeply connected and work closely together, a precious experience I wouldn't want to miss. Meeting extraordinary people in a rather ordinary frequency makes you sometimes even forget how quickly you learn new things about different places, people, and yourself.
 
And most astonishing, even if you sometimes work long hours, there are so many occasions and opportunities to enjoy your time, party with friends, and discover the world.
 
It is a great pleasure to work with Bain and to be part of its global team.
cons: It is challenging to keep your work life balance at the optimum

headline: Culture is the cornerstone, impact is the mission
pros: Bain is a place where you will get early exposure to responsibility and a support network to help you thrive. You work with incredibly positive, ambitious, and energetic people who are always there to support you in and out of the workplace. There is a strong culture of mentoring to ensure you have and develop the skills necessary for long-term success in your career.
cons: The work can be very fast-paced and someone won't always stop to make sure you're keeping up and clued in. You have to be very proactive about validating your thinking and work-planning for yourself.

Working with such an inspiring group makes for a motivating experience regardless of the topic. Bain's casework is broad and strategic and provides a great foundation for a career in the business world more broadly.
cons: This is a demanding job that will at times will take you away from home and ask you to work on subjects that are outside of your core areas of interest.

headline: Best place to work

- Phenomenal learning opportunities - investments by the firm are massive, from global training to mentorship
- Never gets boring and always challenging - as soon as you master a role, the next milestone is around the corner

headline: Consultant - London Office, MBA hire, former banker
pros:
Fantastic culture and genuine desire by almost everyone I meet to help each other out. Given how many intelligent and ambitious people there are, there is very little arrogance across the firm.

Most managers I have worked with will work diligently to keep sustainability a key pillar of a project. It doesn't always work out given client needs or demands but the intent is there.
cons: The London office is particularly big so it can be difficult to meaningfully know a good portion of the office.

headline: Best place to work, learn and have fun!
pros:
-The office culture is great: the office is small enough to know everyone from partner to ACs to support staf and we have a lot of fun together during the offical and unoffical Bain events
- Learning is really central in the office: whether it is in your case work, during your office leadership roles or just because you have a click with someone in the office, people always take the time for you and discuss your personal development. Also, our local staffing model is designed to allocate consultants to cases based on their development needs, which makes sure that there is no competitive atmosphere in the office. This stimulates me a lot!
- There is no pre-defined career path at Bain. Whether you would like to do an externship, MBA, transfer, LOA or none of the above - everything is possible and accepted.
cons: The size of the office and the local staffing policy can make the amount of cases you can select from limited. Therefore, if you have very specific sector/capability needs that are not very well represented in the office, then you might not always find these cases available.

headline: Great place to work

pros: Huge investment in your personal development (both for life at Bain and for life outside of Bain). Super ambitious and hard working people who also love to have a good time! Work is always changing allowing diverse skill development. Comprehensive review which enables employees to hone all aspects of their toolkit.
cons: As a consultant you lack final decision-making power (that is, you don't own a P&L line). You can therefore be quite distant from the final decision of the company/client.

headline: Bain World Cup - A standout event held by Bain & Company
pros: Bain has a very strong and inspiring culture instilled into the system which is a guiding light for all employees. Ever year, since 1987, a different city has been hosting the 'Bain World Cup' wherein employees from Bain offices from across the globe come together to  participate in sporting events such as Touch Rugby, Volleyball, 6-a-side football and 11-a-side football. The event highlights the strong bond shared by Bain teams (even beyond work) and brings together ~25% of the entire company workforce to celebrate the true spirit of Bain. For sports enthusiasts, this is a top-notch experience.
cons: It could be hard to fit into another workplace atmosphere once you've worked at Bain!

headline: Bain can do better

cons:
Working at Bain as support staff feels like you are less than the consultant. There are many instances where consultants will say hello to you when you need something but when they no longer require your help with a case they behave like they have never met you. 

On top of this, career progression is difficult. I haven't been given adequate support when trying to progress into senior positions.

Senior leadership are very approachable and transparent.

Competitive environment - not for the faint of heart. You will consistently be challenged and will frequently have doubts about yourself as you are surrounded by incredibly smart and accomplished individuals

Travel - will be a challenge for people with significant family commitments, but this is nothing unusual for consulting.

headline: Associate Consulting
pros: First -- Incredible learning environment do to the diversity of experiences you get, the management team's  to develop younger and newer team members, and the structure of formal and informal training and feedback. Bain has perfected the method for build strong and capable employees and I feel equipped to take on the challenge of high level roles at Bain or otherwise; Second -- Really, really wonderful people, Bain fosters a really supportive and fun work environment. At a local level, my colleagues are at once my mentors, confidantes, and closest friends. Bain also brings employees from around the world together on a regular basis to you can really be a part of this global community.
cons: Standard for all consultants- hours can be long, client-facing work can be more time-consuming and less predictable than types of jobs. I think the trade-off for the type of work we do makes these things well worth the hard work- especially early in your career. Bain also focuses on finding ways to make the job more sustainable in terms of work-life balance, its a weekly conversation on all teams to ensure team members feel good about they work day as well as their free time

headline: Great People, Great Culture,Amazing Learning
pros: Bain has so many flexible work options and perks that go with the job. Bain paid for me (travel and housing, fully paid) to  go to Australia for 6 month so I could explore a new culture and meet new people. Bain also has a annual event (Bain world cup where it pays for employees from all offices around the world to come together (this year in London) and play soccer and other sports and also hosts parties in the evenings. This is all to say the firm cares about the people and the experience. We definitely work hard but the Bain leadership cares about the people and especially sustainability and doesn't run people into the ground. I've been at Bain for just over 2 years and I've had the opportunity to work for several Fortune 100 companies doing major transformational work and I've learned so much along the way.
cons: Like any consulting role, its client facing so there's a bit of unpredictability in travel or schedule week to week.
