headline: Bain Capability Center - A Bane to your career!!!
pros:
"Nothing nothing nothing " 
Will utilize this space to write Cons about the biggest Con of the century. As a serious career professional you would not find any positive in this Fraud Unit that operates in the name of "Bain & Company". However, if you want coaching for anything and everything around "Un-professionalism" "Politics" and "Unethical practices" your search ends here. Say yes to them only if you want the below:
1.  Lots of Free Food - If that's your ultimate goal of going to office
2.  Lots of off-sites - If you are a holiday/travel junkie
3.  Lots of parties - If thats your mantra in life
They do throw lots of other perks at you like we throw peanuts to Monkeys in a Zoo. But, remember they still think u r a MONKEY!
cons:
"All all all everything" 
1. Sr Management (GM's): GM group is a small happy family and its a family run business. Company is very dynamic as decision making changes every hour depending on the their mood. GM's have full control on Appraisal system and policy formulations and are happy to screw careers without reason. Very mediocre leadership, most of them are adopted for life but would not qualify for a reputable position elsewhere!  To survive this breed you need to be an office pet and get their coffee on time. Spineless HR is not only a mere spectator but believes in openness and transparency as nothing with HR team stays confidential. Highly paperless organisation as performance reviews are completely verbal and without facts.  
2.  Culture: This place has a great culture of disrespect, humiliation and unethical Behavior. Anyone who questions this is a "Cultural Misfit".  Any kind of meeting/presentation is a joke as people are eating chewing & refilling the free food with no respect to the speaker who continues to present, really shocking!!! Mind blowing spy culture, the GMs have rogue agents in every nook and corner and will even report what you had in lunch hence beware every move you make is being watched - this is an essential requirement given GM's are not in office 90% of the time. Non meritorious boot-licking culture.
3.  Discrimination - This is core to the companies DNA.  Basic flexibility comes to you with designation - GM's stay at home for petty reasons, however anything below you are supposed to choose between a sick child and coming to office. Discrimination between Laterals and Home grown is also in your face.  Laterals are considered low life's as even returning their greetings is a crime, let alone following their instructions as a senior. Out of sight, out of mind meaning newbies are not marked in email communications pertaining to your own projects and have to beg to be kept in loop.  
This is a  body shop manufacturing goons of the highest order. Hence, if you are bored of being respected, professional and Ethical look no further and join them. All your nightmares will come true.

headline: High performing supportive work place
pros: One of the best places to start your career - very strong mentoring and feedback culture, which allows for constant self-reflection and improvement. This is coupled by a rigorous training program which ensures you learn the consulting tool-kit very quickly. Finally this strong emphasis of mentorship and learning is supported by a fun and supportive culture which emphasises connectivity across and between classes.
cons: Sometimes the hours can be long and work-life balance can be negatively impacted - I wouldn't say this is the norm and you can usually manage work-life balance on most cases.

headline: Working at Bain & Company, Mumbai
pros: Meritocratic working environment is the biggest plus point at Bain. The setup provides you plentiful opportunities to grow professionally and cultivate valuable mentor-mentee relationships. Your working team is supportive of your professional needs and personal needs and many a times go out of their way to help you. A typical working year is interspersed with 1-2 international training/recreational activities making your experience at Bain a truly global one
cons: The demands of consulting and the Bain standard for delivering top-notch client results might mean a couple of long days in a week.  However even this is managed in the bet possible manner by your team providing you with much needed flexibility to help sustain an ambitious career paths.

headline: great company

headline: Amazing company that takes care of the employees well!
pros: Warm and welcoming culture, having the space to learn (and make mistakes), personalized career path and true smart, fun and kind colleagues.
cons: Working late hours sometimes, doing many analysis as we are very data driven which can take some frustrations when data of clients are super difficult and incorrect / incomplete

headline: Best place to work after college
pros: This job will give you the best people to work with, and some of the coolest problems to work on. I don't think there is a better place to work after school. There's a culture and a spirit here -- created both organically and systematically -- that drive a supportive, mentorship-driven, and feedback-based culture that permeates everything we do. You'll be given opportunities to step up and act beyond your years, and you'll learn as much, as quickly, here at Bain as just about any other job out there. But you never be alone as you do it, because there will be a team and network to support you the whole way through.
cons: The long hours and travel can be frustrating and exhausting. The learning curve is real, and it's real steep. When you feel like you've half-mastered something, there is another task ahead of you, and it can be hard to keep your head up unless you're resilient and determined to keep improving.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Incredible people, challenging work, great clients
cons: Limited ability to control own agenda at junior level

headline: Emphasis on Professional Development and Learning
pros: Variety of cases, exposure to different industries and functional areas, different work, cohesive teams, mentorship, global network, fun
cons: Sometimes very stressful; long hours; multiple iterations of the same analyses or presentations are tedious; not enough support from graphics/analytics/etc. on cases

headline: Bain & Company as a place to start your career
pros: In my opinion, Bain & Company is a great place to start your career on a number of levels. The opportunities of working with top-notch clients and the ability to make an impact on their organisations is an incredible start to your professional career. On top of this, in my experience, the company genuinely cares about the development of its employees and creates a supportive environment with regular coaching and mentoring interactions. On a personal level, the people you work with are likeminded, fun people to work with which makes it a great environment to spend time in!
cons: Of course, there will be moments when it will not be your dream job. For me personally this is when the hours are sometimes long and you feel not a lot of personal progression. But again, this specific situation is when the supportive culture provides you with a network within the organization to fall back on and bounce back stronger.

headline: Interesting work, fantastic culture, brilliant people
pros:
The culture is fantastic and the company really invests in building and maintaining a great company spirit. This ranges from global events like the Bain World Cup, or opportunities to share anonymous feedback to management on a weekly basis.

The work is interesting and varied, you'll learn quickly and get exposure to several industries and capabilities.

The people are great and it is a very collaborative and friendly working environment.
cons:
Work life balance is not great, but given the industry it is really well managed, for example teams will usually try to accommodate personal plans and there is no expectation to work weekends (although inevitably people sometimes do).

Gender balance is bad at the senior levels.

headline: Energizing, collaborative, & ambitious place to work
pros:
The teams I've worked with are pro-active, supportive, and always willing to coach each other or help pick up the most minute tasks. There is a true team spirit here that extends beyond the project content-- we also help each other reach professional and personal goals and often socialize on weekends or holidays. For example, last weekend's Bain World Cup brought together 1800 Bainies from our ~40 offices for a weekend of fun and "casual" sports competition in the middle of London.  

Another big positive is that you will constantly be challenged to push yourself and learn new things. No two days on the job are alike and those who adapt best to constant change and tackling new problems with positivity will go far here.

Bain's concept of "Build your own Bain" encourages you to seek your own path at and outside the company, whether that be specializing in a certain industry, transferring to another Bain office, or taking time off for an externship, temporary leave of absence, or MBA.
cons: As with many jobs in this sector, the ~60 hour workweeks make it challenging to stay in contact with friends and family who are used to working ~40 hour weeks. Although Bain Amsterdam travels much less internationally than other offices or consultancies, those travel cases do quickly lead to 3 months' living out of a half-empty suitcase feeling. There are various options such as refusing travel cases, mitigating nights away to 2/week, and setting up videoconferencing with clients that I've seen used to mitigate these effects.

headline: Bain World Cup 2018
pros:

- Colleagues becoming real friends
cons: - Career Opportunities for CSS (transfers,...)

headline: Great place to develop

headline: The best place to work
pros: No better place to start a career. Executive level access as a new employee. Culture is unrivaled. From partners to people out of undergrad, people are Bain are interested in your success.
cons: The home-office model can make it difficult to build relationships with people in other offices

headline: Hard work & good fun go hand in hand
pros: Thoughtful, pragmatic leadership team.  Always looking to develop the next set of leaders by providing opportunities for others.  Inclusive, supportive group of peers.  Know how to have a good time.  Hard work is rewarded by lots of fun, team building activities (trainings, office off-sites, global Bain World Cup soccer tourney, etc.)
cons: Lofty goals and high expectations, but very rewarding.  Work/life balance can be challenging if you don't make it a priority for you (but are very supportive if that is what helps you thrive)

headline: Bain is a great place to work
pros: The people are amazing! No where else will you be in such a supportive encouraging environment while also being challenged and pushed so hard.
cons: Really high expectations of every employee, sometimes can be unrealistic

headline: Best place to start a career
pros:
Amazing people that make for unbeatable teams 

Consistently steep learning curve

High impact and high visibility work

Clear differentiating culture from competitors BCG and McKinsey
cons: Client services aspect of the job can make workload a bit heavy at times

headline: Great place to learn, grow and have fun
pros:
- Incredible mentorship and a network of colleagues that care about you and your personal development
- Wide-ranging exit opportunities and recruiters come to you
- Exceptional professional network that continues to pay dividends after you leave Bain
- Helpful worldwide trainings and opportunities to meet other employees from all over the world
- Strong set of operating principles which are lived by teams daily
- Challenging problems with the biggest companies in the world and creating real impact
cons:
- Limited control over lifestyle given it is client services
- Variability in staffing  means you can go from a case you love to one that you really dislike in a week.

headline: Supportive environment with amazing people
pros:
Bain has a supportive, non-competitive environment in which it's clear management is committed to your success.  The culture emphasizes learning and mentorship--starting your career you're immediately put into roles that stretch your ability, but it always feels attainable because of the support network of peers, mentors, and resources surrounding you.

Despite just having started at Bain ~9 months ago, I already have been able to tangibly see and contribute to the amazing results we bring for our clients.  It's been an amazing place to start a career.
cons: The hours can sometimes be long (which is standard for the industry), though management does a good job of ensuring work/life balance  is reasonable

headline: Amazing place to work - Be part of a true results delivering company
pros: Great people, culture, work environment and clients
cons: Workload can fluctuate and be unpredictable

headline: Zero complaints
pros:

- Incredibly kind peers

- Emphasis on work/life balance
- Amazing formal and informal mentorship and professional development
cons: The hours are longer than other "classic" corporate positions, but the opportunities for growth are endless.

headline: Associate Consultant
pros:

Perform high impact work from the beginning with interesting clients and learn a lot while doing so
cons: As with any client facing work, hours can be "spiky" although Bain does a good job of trying to manage sustainability

headline: #bestplacetowork
pros: Bain culture , teamwork, learning and mentoring

headline: Challenging, career-boosting, and a whole lot of fun!
pros:
-Surrounded by the smartest people I've every worked with, all focused on solving highly complex business challenges through an aligned an efficient approach
-Immediate and substantial benefits to long-term career prospects. I am less than a year in on the job and am already receiving great exit offers into VC, strategic positions in corporate, etc
-World-class training and professional development support
-FUN: My best friends now are the people in my class. Bain does a great job selecting like-minded co-workers who I naturally get along with. An abundance of Bain-funded events on weekends (happy hours, class budgets, bain world cup, etc) that make me feel like a well-appreciated employee
cons: Difficult to answer since I am very satisfied with where I am, but I've heard that compared to our competitors, our upward promotion structure is less flexible. We have more of a structured process that most follow with a few exceptions (2-3 years to B-school / consultant). While some of our competitors reward very high performers with significantly early promotions.

headline: I'm in good company

headline: Great place to work!

headline: Best place to learn, and excellerate, while having lots of fun
pros: At Bain you will be driven to get the best out of yourself due to the very  supportive and team driven culture. Having the opportunity to work on a very diverse set of projects, you will never be bored as you are pushed into new learning opportunities every day. And while you are learning so much yourself, you will also be very focused on working collaboratively whit the client, pushing them to be the best version of themselves and thereby ensuring that you deliver real impact by driving results for your client. Personally I couldn't have started my career at a better place.
cons: It isn't a 9 to 5 working hour job, however I feel that at the Amsterdam office there is plenty of room to balance your work/life ratio and openly discuss non-sustainable situations.

headline: Best consultancy to work for
pros:
- culture
- down to the earth
- great team work and team spirit within and outside project work, across hierarchy
- results driven and focussed on the project while maintaining a balanced ego and having fun outside project and also outside work

headline: Associate Consultant

cons: Demanding working times; limited public sector exposure

headline: Great place to start a career and grow!
pros:
Bain is full of incredibly intelligent, passionate people who are willing to work very hard to deliver great results for our clients (and the community through our social impact work). But, Bain people are also incredibly kind, supportive, and generous with their time and mentorship.

Bain has a strong culture of mentorship and professional development that allows people to grow as workers, thinkers, and people. 

Bain employees are also well compensated, and Bain offers great perks!
cons: Working at Bain often requires working very long hours, and can be challenging in that regard.

headline: Consultant
pros:
Challenging environment and missions
Exceptionnal people
Strong and positive corporate culture
Diversity of assignments
cons: Long working hours can be challenging

headline: Place for big impact on the job with supportive, collaborative culture
pros:
-What you do matters; easy to wake up and go to work every week
-Coworkers who care about making the job fulfilling and fun, and will help you defend your "non-work" time
-Global culture (via global trainings, events, case work)... I have coworkers I could stay with in >10 cities worldwide. 
-Best place to start a career; fastest access to executive decision making, cutting-edge analytics, and a general management toolkit
cons:
-Client services industry.  Sometimes clients can be demanding or rude and you have to be able to roll with the punches, including long hours and uncertainty during the work week
-Travel makes building a social network in your home city more difficult

headline: Perfect recipe for success - intellectual challenges, support and fun!
pros:
Bain’s apprenticeship model means that I have been working with the very best in the business from Day 1.  Each day, I am lucky to learn from colleagues across many different disciplines and tenure levels – from analyst right through to partner. The supportive culture and mentoring at Bain has honestly exceeded my expectations, and I know that I have a really strong support network within the business. I’ve become a great consultant because of the investment that my colleagues have made in me. 
During my time at Bain Australia, I’ve worked on clients across many different industries, and focussed on solving many different problems. The one thing that has remained constant through all cases has been Bain’s absolute commitment to achieving results. Every day, we work to help our clients achieve new levels of success – I feel like part of the client teams during our cases, and our client’s successes are our own. It’s the most collaborative atmosphere I’ve ever experienced. 
Bain Australia is a great place to start your career – a perfect mix of challenging work with the right support systems in place, great clients who are striving to achieve more with their businesses and an incredible culture. The people at Bain are exceptional – intelligent, ambitious and always up for fun. I feel extremely lucky to call myself a Bainee!
cons: We do work hard to achieve great client results, but the business acknowledges this and puts a lot of effort into creating a sustainable work/life balance. As a result, we're lucky at Bain Australia to have abolished 'face-time' culture often expected in professional services firms.

headline: Associate Consultant
pros: Supportive culture in which managers are invested in your development and learning. The culture is also such that many employees are really good friends with many of their colleagues. Bain also sets you up for great exit opportunities and is supportive of those people who are seeking their next employment.
cons: Bain values work/life balance, but the nature of the consulting industry is such that work is not always sustainable.

headline: Great first job but definitely not for everyone

cons: Minimal influence in the staffing process, often repetitive/menial client work, a culture that promotes uniformity and homogeneity of thought

headline: Amazing Culture
pros: Bain is truly amazing at investing in their people and creating a culture of support and cross engagement.  The opportunities working at Bain opens both internally and externally are endless, and the problems are incredibly challenging.   With a "One Team" mentality, most feel part of the big picture and find their home at Bain & Co.
cons: As most Management Consulting firms, there are some issues around sustainability.  That said, Bain is extremely conscious of these issues and works in various ways to create a sustainable experience.

headline: Great company - disparities across offices
pros: One of the best consulting company to grow professionnally
cons: Local culture being varying across offices

headline: A Fantastic Start to Any Career
pros: There are very few companies I know of that invest as much in employees' professional development as Bain. Upon starting as an Associate Consultant, Bain immediately provides you a network of mentors to help you accomplish your goals with both the firm and personal career aspirations. In addition to the formal development program, I've found that Bain's supportive culture assures that there will always be a peer who is willing to lend a hand and invest in your success.
cons: As with many consulting firms, a good amount of flexibility is needed to thrive at Bain. Due to the high demand for Bain teams, the staffing team is often stretched for resources and it is occasionally difficult to get placed in a particular industry or work stream of interest. That being said, if you are looking for exposure to a vast amount of businesses and topics, then Bain would be a fantastic option for you.

headline: Associate Consultant
pros: Supportive culture (formal & informal mentoring, significant training / learning opportunities), create a major impact on clients and communities, diverse learning experiences across industries & capabilities with the chance to learn from the best and brightest
cons: At times, work can be rigorous, but comes with the significant professional development opportunities

headline: Consultant
pros: Strong collaborative work environment,  supportive culture, intellectually stimulating work
cons: some week day travel away from home

headline: Awesome job!
pros: One of the best places to work in the world. Awesome perks, traveling to great places, and incredible people. Being in the team room makes you smarter. Lots of engagement with very high level executives.
cons: Hours can be tough, and managing travel is also exhausting

headline: Excellent place to work!
pros: An excellent culture, high-quality mentorship and people support, and incredibly interesting work
cons: Limited downsides, with the understanding that this is a consulting job that will have the associated hours and (albeit more limited than other firms) travel

headline: Best of Bain
pros:
As you read on this page, Bain has the best culture of any firm around.  It's hard to find a current or former employee that doesn't gush with pride talking about their mentors or mentees, the quality and intelligence of their coworkers, the high-quality trainings, the office comradery, and the incredible company events (think Bain World Cup, office offsite meetings, etc.).  Bain also does a phenomenal job of involving spouses and family in that culture.

Bain has some "work-related" pros that are often overlooked.  Bain doesn't sell small teams (1-3 people) like other firms.  You're usually on a full team (4-6 people) which builds in support and collaboration.  Travel is much more flexible as Bain staffs full teams from the same office.  There's always some social impact opportunities flowing through my inbox if I want to volunteer to do some good.  

Lastly, I feel like they care about me as a person.  They know Bain isn't my top priority in life, but they work hard to make the job as rewarding and flexible as possible so I can enjoy life outside of Bain as well.
cons: Hours and travel can be hard and at times unpredictable.   Also, sustainability and balance can shift from case to case.

headline: Wowed everyday by the best place to work
pros: Working on our clients biggest, most challenging and interesting issues; amazingly supportive colleagues with a bias towards impact; home office staffing model with very strong local office culture; beautiful office/working space
cons: Intensity of hours; every day is the easiest you will have at bain

headline: Senior Associate Consultant
pros: Absolutely fantastic experience.  The work has a very high impact, the people are brilliant & humble, and we have great success.  No other place could provide a better start to a career.
cons: Long hours.  It's fairly high-paced.

headline: One team attitude
pros: The culture and the people aspects of Bain are what really sets the firm apart from its competitors. I have never met such a great group of people willing to offer mentor ship and advice to guide your career. You also get the chance to work on excited projects and solve the largest problems facing companies.
cons: Travel can drive longer work hours

headline: Best Place to Work!
pros: Bain truly cares about our growth and development, with multiple people of higher tenure offering mentorship at every turn. Culture is so important to Bain, and the people who work here are truly amazing!
cons: The nature of consulting is that staffing for cases is dependent on what's available, so you may not always be super happy with the case you are given.

headline: Great place to work!
pros: Amazing supportive culture. High impact and very interesting assignments
cons: As with any consulting firm, hours are not ideal, but there are various ways you can make it work for you

headline: The most enjoyable and educational work environment possible
pros: Bain provides an amazing work environment.  The employees are incredibly intelligent, creating a stimulating experience for all.  However, the experience is summed up by Bain's saying, "we take our work seriously but not ourselves".  While providing a challenging environment for your mind,  Bain also has the most amazing culture.  There is a big emphasis on fun which is demonstrated through regular case team events, office-wide parties, global Bain parties and, on a smaller note, constant snacks!  The most important thing about Bain though is the amazing people that you get to know.  They are the most intelligent, fun and helpful people I have ever met.  Coming to work is always exciting and enjoyable which I don't think you'll get everywhere else!
cons: The only con with working in Bain (as will apply to all strategy consulting firms) is the hours.  They are not consistently long but you will have periods of working late so you need to be ok with that.  Having said that, the late nights can often be the most enjoyable because you are working with your team to solve a problem.

headline: Great place to start out from university
pros: supportive culture (e.g. learning and mentoring); the ability to make an impact (for our clients and in our communities); great place to start your career
cons: Unpredictable schedule; Long hours; High expectations

headline: Best starting place for a crash course in business
pros:
I started at Bain & Company straight out of uni, and found it the best place to kickstart my career in business. Some of the key pros of working at Bain:

-Impactful work: at the end of the day, I could see how our work was making a difference for our clients and wider community. Our advice was informing clients' decision making and led to multiple changes in their organisations. Some projects were truly global in scale and personally it was great to see how they are set up and managed.
-Internal culture: Bain internal culture is built around learning and mentoring. We have an extensive internal support system which addresses professional development needs throughout the time at Bain. Despite busy periods, everyone is friendly and always willing to lend a helping hand.
-Career kickstart: overall, experience and skills developed at Bain make it a great place to start a career in business. Global brand recognition also helps when looking for your next opportunity.
cons: -Hours: at times it does get busy and work/life balance suffers, however, management team is always aware of it and tries to make up for it between projects. I still think it's better than in other comparable jobs (consulting/banking), based on what I heard from my friends.

headline: Consultant
pros:
- World class clients and people
- Incomparable diversity of cultures, genders, backgrounds
- Unmatched willingness to get results while still having fun!
cons: Very intense work and sometimes people

headline: Associate Consultant
pros: Great office culture and fantastic focus on people and personal development. Next to case work all employees spend time on personal or office related  development opportunities, such as social impact, recruiting, interviewing or training/coaching. This will allow you to spend time with everyone in the office as both consultant and support staff will particitpate.
cons: Working hours can be long, but I do think our office has a culture where the  intensity of the case can be discussed as a group and where the project leadership team strives to a good work-life balance at all times

headline: Probably the best employer I ever had
pros:
Truly committed to people development
Great culture - fun and challenging at the same time!
Amazing people, all over the world
Working with top clients
cons: Hours can be challenging at times

headline: Great place to start your career

headline: Great place to work

- Teams provide the right level of support
- Management team is understanding and active conversations are held around lifestyle and sustainability
cons: - Tendency to over-deliver to clients sometimes means that there is a scope creep

headline: Brilliant place to work!
pros: You get to work on the most challenging, high-impact projects with the biggest and best companies in the world. The culture is amazing - I don't think any other high-performance company manages to balance your professional development, freedom to try new things and the supportive, 'family', environment that exists. Bain is truly unique in that regard.
cons: The hours can be long, and that is the sacrifice you need to be willing to make.

headline: Great people, challenging work
pros:
- It is a cliché because it is true: the people! Best example: when attending global training, you meet 200 new people in a week or so.  Never before have I felt so at ease joining a random lunch table. Everyone is super kind, very smart and just inspiring to work with. And most importantly: they don't take themselves too seriously. 

- Challenging work with steep learning curve. I feel like every day, every week I get to learn something new. Also lots of contact with top management layer even when you are a new consultant. 

- Linked to previous point but they truly invest in training and personal development, which is great. 

- Opportunities to do an MBA, work in another office, or even with another company
cons: - The long hours aren't always fun. It varies quite a bit per case, but when it is busy it is very busy

headline: Senior Associate Consultant
pros: Great "one-team" culture and adding lots of value for our clients
cons: Your life feels like a roller coaster

headline: Best culture and people

headline: Work hard, play harder
pros:
Great team atmosphere, extremely social office with lot's of cool events, often organized by staff spontaneously (e.g. skiing trip, ice skating, pub crawl). Very inclusive environment, with little hierarchy in inter-personal relations. Basically, you can shoot the sh*t with anyone, from partner level to support staff. 

It's rare to find a company where everyone seems to enjoy their work and is intrinsically motivated to deliver great work.
cons: Be prepared to work with short deadlines and deal with high pressure. Bain demands you to deliver high quality work on everything to do, which can get stressful.

headline: Review
pros: Amazing place to work with high-performing and enthusiastic peers, extensive support networks and lots of opportunities to promote connectivity and employee satisfaction.
cons: Tough to predict working schedules as it changes from week to week.

headline: Excellent firm!
pros: Stupendously people oriented, very organized and great culture!
cons: Not many that I can think of

headline: Fantastic Culture, best people to work with
pros: The people - there really is a ‘type’ of person that works at Bain. Every single person will go out of their way to help you out. It’s a friendly environment that has a ton of opportunities to get involved with activities.
cons: The harder you work the higher the expectations. It can also feel like some individuals are favoured.

headline: Best work place.
pros: Coolest place. Great opportunities to work on.
cons: so far nothing as in cons.

headline: Case Team Leader

Lots of responsibility given to you to run the case and you have authority to drive things forward.
cons: Not very flexible career progression, in the sense that you cannot choose to specialized and stay as an expert but rather have to go through the career ladder as more or less a generalist and make partner.

headline: CEO

headline: Great learning opportunity; sign away your life

headline: Good

headline: Great place!

headline: Great launchpad for a career
pros: Incredibly bright and capable co-workers, interesting work, great apprenticeship culture

headline: Great place to build a career
pros: You get a chance to work with some of the biggest companies in the world on some of their hardest problems. It is intense and challenging, and you will be pushed to your limits. But you learn a lot and build a good toolkit that will help you no matter what you end up doing afterwards. Great training and good coaching to learn to help make change happen in large organizations. You will work with a bunch of really smart people who have a lot of fun together. The culture is fantastic and teams are very collaborative and supportive in general. There are good opportunities to work internationally if you want to do so.
cons: The hours can be long and the bar for performance goes up every 6 months. You can end up traveling a lot. Partners can be a little too focused on commercial development rather than people development.

headline: Great company that cares for it's people
pros: Unlike at other peer consulting firms, people do matter and are taken care of
cons: long hours, regardless of what partners tell you, it is hard to maintain work life balance

headline: Great company to work for
pros:
Great company culture
Drive for change, particularly within the support teams
Great name to have on a CV
Clear remuneration package, benefits package is one of the most impressive ones i've seen
cons:
As in every big company/name, there are still some politics around/favorites, but much less than i've seen in competitors
Office could be a bit more impressive

headline: Associate Consultant
pros: Great learning experience, no strict heirarchy
cons: Tough working hours, constant travel

headline: Consultant at Bain India - 4 years experience
pros:
Good exposure to a variety of industries
Can learn to understand how a business works very quickly
Learn to deliver in crunched situations
Gain confidence presenting before senior partners/clients
Smart, motivated, friendly colleagues
Great global trainings and offsites
Largely fair review system although much more socialist than BCG/Mck (% outperformers are much less compared to these firms)
Airline miles and SPG points!
cons:
Very demanding work hours (70 hour plus weeks are not uncommon, can go up to 100 in the worst case)
At any point, ~30% of the projects running in the office are mismanaged - leadership is such that is working on the industry for the first time and hence is clueless about what direction to steer the team in and the team ends up boiling the ocean. This is esp. the case in India where Bain is relatively new and does not have too many experienced partners
Unpredictable, frequently changing priorities 
Too many layers (AC, Consultant, Manager, Principal/Partner) - 4 layers above the juniormost person, each making suggestions and giving comments, leading to a lot of rework, esp. because there is no one right or fixed way to solve the project so every one tries to do "value add" 
Limited opportunity to specialize in 1 industry or capability area in the first  5 years - so you remain a generalist for the first 5 years
No operational, hands-on experience - you only recommend, never implement
Too much focus on making slides look pretty instead of testing recommendations on practicality 
No partners to look up to who are actual industry experts (very few industry experienced people, mostly consulting lifers at the senior levels)
Poor focus on work life balance (it is only talked about not much is done about it)

headline: Truly The Best Place To Work
pros: While interviewing at Bain and researching the company I was highly skeptical about the raving reviews. I am happy to report that after working here for ~3 months, I LOVE BAIN - the company values are practiced and seen everyday; the environment is fun, supportive, and interesting; and the people are intelligent, caring, and, for the most part, all wonderful to be around. I hope to be at Bain for many years to come and can't imagine a better work place.
cons: If I had to criticize something, I would say there are a few CSS members who do not necessarily embrace the Bain motto - "A Bainie Never Let's a Bainie Fail". There are only a handful and it really does not influence the overall culture so don't let a few bad seeds steer you away from a truly amazing company!

headline: Great to start career - don't stay too long
pros:
- Becoming efficient (xls, ppt any other way)
- Gaining insight into many industries & topics
- Learning to explain complex issues in simple words
- Learning to deal with change
- Great plus on any CV
- Young, ambitious team of smart people
- People genuinely care
cons:
- work life balance (10 PM is early, 12 is normal, 2 AM is long; expect to travel a lot; the "protected" night is not always protected)
- Salary is low for the hours (large proportion of quoted salaries consist of benefits; this will not go to your bank account)
- Can't learn actual  leadership here (leading intelligent, driven, overperforming individuals doesn't train you for the outside world)
- Beware of the Kool-Aid: it's easy to buy into the idea of making an impact, staying at nice hotels, eating in fancy restaurants, being amongst "the top" and, that it's just too cool to be there. At the end of the day, you play a very small role in a large project, devoting almost all of your time and energy into this job. Yes, team culture is good, but start ups are better.
--> Come here to kick start your career, to learn and to orientate yourself professionally. Don't miss the right moment to leave.

headline: Great social culture - terrible work culture
pros: Fantastic people, very motivated, interesting and fun. Great brand name, opens doors once you leave
cons: Horrible work culture that crushes your self-esteem and grinds you down. Though their values sound great and they talk a lot about the apprenticeship model, Bain's systems (review, promotion, hierarchy etc.) are awful. I worked at another top management consulting firm before so could directly compare my experience. I saw and experienced many issues in this company but I think the main one is the lack of managerial training that employees get before they start managing coupled with the lacking incentives to manage your team well and by well I mean actually support their growth and help them succeed while also keeping them healthy (physically and mentally).

headline: Fun and challenging workplace
pros: Bain is a fun and challenging place to work:  people are very passionate about their jobs, whether on the consulting side of the business or in other roles. The focus is very much on results - not how many hours you spend at your desk, which is a refreshing change from other workplaces.  Management is very inspiring and colleagues really act in a 'one team' mentality.
cons: Very high standards and push to always do more/better. Most of the time it is highly motivating but can occasionally be stressful.

headline: Fantastic company

It truly is a great place to work and is always challenging me to learn something new.

headline: An amazing place to work
pros: For me, it's the people that make Bain such a special place to work. Every day, I come into the office and I learn from people above, below, and at the same level as me. Everyone also knows how to have fun outside of the office to ensure their is work / life balance.
cons: As with any great job, we have to work hard. That being said, Bain attempts to keep things balanced hard cases followed by more manageable ones. They also make corrections when a team is having a tough run by adding additional investment resources and pushing back on the client's scope.

headline: Amazing development oppotunities
pros: As a recent college graduate, there's not a better place to be after graduation. The exposure to senior clients, Bain partners, and the ability to influence the case "answer" from Day 1 on the job is truly unparalleled
cons: Sustainability can be challenging as in any consulting/professional services company. Bain does a good job of proactively managing this through weekly team "temp check" surveys, clearly outlining personal sustainability goals, and flexible work programs

headline: Best place to work

cons: Even though there's significantly less travel than at any other peer firm, there's still more than ideal.

headline: Case Team Leader
pros:
Bain offers you a front row seat to solving some of the most important issues faced by executives of major investment firms and corporations. Pros of working at Bain include:

* Very steep learning curve - you won't do the same thing twice as an AC, Consultant, Case Team Leader. 
* You receive a lot of coaching and support from peers and leadership. I've been "saved" by colleagues many times (e.g. figuring out something technical in a model or database, developing a key client deck, etc.)
* Ability to execute is incorporated into final recommendations and partners want to see things implemented (i.e. very results driven culture)
* We work alongside with clients to solve problems versus talking at them. Clients I have worked with who've worked with our peers say this is a differentiator
* Very attractive compensation and benefits package
* Business continues to grow offering attractive opportunities for employees
cons: Cons are in line with consulting in general. The role can require extensive travel and long hours at times.

headline: Amazing team working on cutting edge topics
pros: Bain is the best management consultancy when it comes to delivering cutting edge solutions to clients when it comes to Digital, Artificial Intelligence, Advanced Analytics and more. With our global network but relatively small size we are agile enough to quickly grasp the latest & greatest advancements in any area. On top of that, the team is amazing and always trying to push the boundaries.
cons: As with all management consultancies, the workload is high - but Bain does a good job in managing it.

headline: Very supportive and flexible employer
pros: Very supportive no matter which issue an employee has. Also very flexible if there are any personal changes. Great culture and values.
cons: Obviously management consulting is not a 9 to 5 job.

cons: The work is hard and the travel can be tough. The work gets harder every day and you'll never get to rest on your laurels--the constant challenge can get tiring.

headline: Best consulting firm

headline: Incredible growth, support, and impact
pros: A place where you get a chance to create real results with some of the most important companies thier industries. Clients respect the work and are usually great to work with. Bain's pragmatic and results-first approach means you have a tangible impact. Fantastic personal support and growth. Almost every day is a new challenge, but the team and leadership is always there to support you. If you perform well, Bain will go out of its way to help you build the career you want. Fantastic pay and benefits.
cons: Typical consulting challenges: long hours, unpredictable client demands, potential for significant travel. However, Bain probably does a better job than most of dealing with this.

headline: Great experience!

headline: Best place to work - for a reason!

headline: Innovation

headline: Fantastic place to start and continue your career!
pros: Bain excels at the fundamentals of management consulting - driving results for clients.  We work with change oriented executives to drive transformational change throughout organizations in the toughest areas.  We work collaboratively with our clients and enable the organization from top to bottom to own and drive change.   The other huge benefit is the support you have to ensure you are thriving personally and professionally.  The attention to professional development is a skills accelerator and helps you achieve your professional development goals and explore your interests.   Our home office staffing model is a key mechanism to ensure you have the opportunity to explore your interests, make sure you develop a well-rounded management skill set, and also have the strong relationships to help you navigate your career (mentors, sponsors, advocates).  You work with Texas people and then see them in the office or on future cases which helps develop strong relationships that are so important as you manage your career.  They also have great flexibility in the work schedule when trying to manage a career and family.
cons: As with any management consulting firm, the job is demanding.

headline: Best Place to work!
pros: The people are the number one reason I love working at Bain & Company. Everyday I enjoy the company I am in and continue to feel inspired and challenged! Work life balance has always been stressed here as well, and the culture still surprises me sometimes with how great it is!

headline: Support/Admin Staff are secondary
pros:
-You get to work with some great people.
-Annual offsite meetings are fun
cons:
-No career advancement possible outside of your immediate team. All Global or regional roles are based out of Boston.
-We keep hearing about the extraordinary growth of the company but continuously see cuts in budgets.
-CSS staff are secondary citizens to this company.
-Pay is sub market rate. Every year you hear about how they analyze the market rate and how we are paid what the market is showing. I strongly believe this is false because it's never adjusted. Any raise you get barely counters inflation.
-When I first started the cell phone reimbursement was $100 and now it is half of that. Meanwhile they raised consultants reimbursement amount.

headline: Great platform for future career

headline: Mentorship and Professional Development
pros: I love how Bain invests in you as a professional. When you join company you are paired up with a sponsor who focuses on your professional development, and who has been in your shoes before. You are also paired with colleagues and mentors who will guide you along the path, and help you with everything you need. Everyone I know at the company would be willing to sacrifice some of their time to answer a question, go to lunch, or help with a project.
cons: I've had colleagues who have been on clients for longer than they would have liked.

headline: Great place to work!

headline: Continuous learning in a supportive culture
pros: The learning is non-stop, once you get comfortable doing something you will be pushed to take bigger roles in more challenging environments.  This makes it to be a challenging job, but the supportive culture and apprenticeship model helps to make it a place to thrive
cons: Promotion process is pretty opaque, leading to lots of stress for anyone in a promotion window.  Despite opportunities to improve the process, leadership seems happy that the induced stress leads to better client outcomes.

headline: Powerful work experience
pros: The client impact here is just very powerful and distinctive.  My chance to learn and make a difference is simply unbeatable.  My colleagues are wicked smart, wonderfully pragmatic, and humble and fun.  It makes our work with client organizations turn into real results and I have built lifelong relationships with clients and Bain teammates alike.   This is just a great place to work and build a career.
cons: Pace is full and active but so is any successful professional career.  Here you do this with a team that supports you at each turn.

headline: Best career for top business talent

headline: Supportive Culture, Excellent Professional Development
pros: I'm not on the consulting side, which is very different, but for employees in the other functional areas (HR, Finance, Marketing, etc.), work-life balance is incredible with a lot of flexibility/autonomy.  People genuinely want to help others succeed.   Promotions seem to happen when they should, without putting the burden on people to advocate too much for themselves or fight to get ahead.
cons: There is a division between consultants and 'CSS' (non consultants), and all non-consultants can at times be treated like assistants/support staff, even at the higher levels.

headline: Bain review
pros: High impact work with a smart, supportive group of colleagues
cons: Client service can be inherently demanding

headline: Best Place to Start a Career!
pros: Bain will prepare you for whatever you want to do in your career, whether or not that includes staying at Bain long term. It opens so many doors because of the exposure you get to various industries and capabilities. Right when you start, you have an incredible impact on companies that have brought in Bain to solve their toughest problems. However, you never feel overwhelmed because of the support you have from your teams, classmates, and the rest of the Bain family. This support has allowed me to develop faster than I ever thought was possible.
cons: The travel can get demanding, but that wasn't a shock.

headline: Best thing that happened to me!
pros:
- Incredibly challenging work, working on Senior Executives' most challenging topics. 
- Passion for driving results for the clients, not just showing up to look smart.
- Incredibly supportive culture with colleagues who want you to succeed.
cons: If you're going to be in the type of career that Bain offers you too, you will be working hard.  Fortunately, at Bain, you know that every hour you worked was a highly leveraged one.

headline: Grateful I started by career here
pros:
-Almost all the work I do is obviously important to the Managers and Partners I work with at Bain, and our clients
-The teams I've been on have created positive change, and the work I've done was important to the team's overall effort, even when I was the most junior person on the team
- The senior folks authentically care about me and my peers. There are a half a dozen people in particular that I've met through my work on different case teams that I could go to for anything - a chat about big picture career stuff, trouble with a supervisor or supervisee, just to catch up.
-There's a lot of formal training, and it's not boring. Most of it has actually made me better at my job at Bain, but it's pretty obvious how it would be helpful to me if I were working somewhere else to (analytics, effective communication in different contexts, how to tackle an ambiguous problem in a structure way, planning work, managing upward, motivating and teaching people that report to you, etc.)
- Compensation and exit opportunities are great
cons: It's client services. Sometimes I work pretty late.

headline: Incredible place to grow
pros: Supportive culture and office environment; intellectually challenging work that changes all the time; highly engaged clients and partners means there is never a dull moment
cons: There's always more work to be done and everyone has their own definition of sustainability

headline: Unmatched learning, opportunity and rewards
pros: The exciting cases working with the most sophisticated executives in the world and helping them reshape their industries; bright, values-driven people working side-by-side with you to make this world a better place; flexibility to "build your own Bain"; the "Bain brand" on your CV opens all doors and is as premium as it gets - it's great (and humbling) to see heads turn when you say you're at Bain & Company.
cons: Depending where you stand, travel can be a con, but even then you have a lot of latitude to "build your own Bain"

headline: Delivering impact in good company

cons: Sometimes challenging to balance thrills of creating value for clients with private life

headline: Great company, rewarding, smart amazing people... but you'll work hard
pros:
- Career advancement: Still at Bain, but recruiters remind me of how valuable this experience is. It still feels like the best decision I could have made coming out of an MBA program was to join Bain.
- Supportive culture: Bainies are held to a high standard of performance but there is a strong culture and structure of support
- Fun culture: It's very work hard, play hard. Long hours are somewhat off-set by the emphasis on "having fun while we work," whether that means volunteer service days, internal Bain band shows, international intramural soccer tournaments ("Bain World Cup"), summer off-sites in the Hamptons or Poconos,  training in Barcelona, Lisbon, Dubai, LA, Miami, Phuket...
cons:
- Work hours: It can be a real "grind" sometimes. It's client services, so this is to be expected but there is a serious burn out factor on this job that has to be carefully managed.
- Strong culture of feedback is both a positive and a negative. It's crucial for the "up or out" environment. It's not political at all, but it can thrive on people's insecurities. Everyone always feels like they can do more, can do better etc.
- Diversity: It's very white, quite male (at management levels)- depending on the office. Diversity is clearly very important to the company, but change can look slow. New York is leading the way though, but that is to be expected given the makeup of this city

- The people are incredibly smart, diverse and fun. The culture in general is amazing! 
- A lot of Managers / Partners really care about the juniors, they will happily just chat to you about career moves etc. and are generally fairly approachable
- Great post-Bain options
- Flexibility options can be great - opportunities to live / work abroad, take externships and Leave of Absence 
- Constant emphasis on improvements in the office, weekly surveys to track satisfaction and changes generally made on the feedback where possible

- Hours are long, often with heavy travel also which can be tough on the work-life balance
- Pay in London is significantly below other Bain offices and worse than salaries in other industries that Bainies are qualified for
- Flexibility options can be difficult to take, the options for transfers etc are there, but they are more difficult to take than recruiting sells it as

headline: the secret lies in the people and their culture
pros:
What truly differentiates Bain from it's competitors are the people and the way we work together:
1. It is very important to the leadership that every team member enjoys being part of the team: In fact all team members assess the case they are working on every week and "we are having fun working together as a team" is one of the criteria! 
2. People are extremely accomplished but still down-to-earth: this is engrained in the culture of the company, valued and constantly reinforced by the leadership.
3. the saying "one bainie never lets another bainie fail" sounds extremely cheesy but it is very, very true. There is no elbow-culture and you can count on the strong support of your colleagues any time in any situation
cons: long working hours. But if you enjoy your work and like your team, this might not be as bad as you think :)

headline: Peak consulting
pros:
Intellectual challenge: 
Bain offers an opportunity to work on a wide variety of intellectually challenging problems across multiple industries. Companies only hire Bain when they can't solve the problem themselves, so you know these aren't minor issues being addressed. Plus for someone at a relatively early point in their career Bain offers unparalleled access to key decision makers and an ability to effect rapid change far beyond what you'd see in many companies (especially large ones) at the same tenure.  Finally, as you get more senior you also have the ability to build more industry/function-specific expertise, which allows you to develop a valuable knowledge base should you choose to work in that area in the future. 

Culture:
On top of the intellectual side of things, Bain offers a great working environment with people who you actually enjoy spending time with (many of my close friends have come from Bain), and who won't hesitate to support you when you need it. Lots of consulting firms offer interesting, challenging work, but Bain's culture helps make that work more enjoyable.
cons:
Sustainability/predictability:
Because this is a client services business, the workload and requirements for a given case will often revolve around the needs (and sometimes the whims) of the client and the leadership team that serves it. This can make it difficult to predict workload, travel and other requirements too far in advance, and sometimes takes control over your own schedule out of your hands. Bain does its best to try to be flexible in how, where and when you work, but in the end the needs of the client tend to come first, which can mean work/life balance can take a hit at times.  Hours are similarly variable, but longer (60+ hour) weeks are not uncommon, particularly for shorter cases or in early stages, and travel tends to compound this (although Bain requires less travel than others).

headline: The worst of Bain, globally
pros:
Global Training Programs
Bain brand name
cons:
The work, the people, and the culture at Bain Dubai are very different from Bain in the US or Europe, and that is not a good thing:

-longer cases (>6 months are no exception)
-many experienced hires in mid-management that only come for the money & have 0 commitment to Bain values. Same thing for partners. Serious issues with the quality of people. Various people are known as slave drivers. Everyone knows, no one says anything. Strong yay sayer culture where no one dares to contradict the most senior people. And don't be fooled by the impression you are given in interviews. No one will remember you when you turn up on your first day. Make sure you speak to current employees to get the real view
-culture is more like m&a banking on wallstreet than what Bain is like in the US. Very long hours, frequent weekend work is a given, no one cares about either. They say that will change, but 0 changes have happened. Employee satisfaction at consultant level and below is extremely low

headline: Great company but may need to reconsider parts of model
pros:
- Friendly, fun, supportive culture 
- Strong commitment to diversity that isn't just window dressing
- Smart, engaging colleagues 
- Great pay and benefits 
- Overall great projects that are strategic (usually) and interesting 
- Amazing training programs
cons:
- Lots of cases that continue to roll and PMO cases seem common (trying to sell "programs" not "projects" to clients) -- results in lackluster PD opportunities or fewer case experiences
- Little to no control over the cases that you get on (especially in smaller offices due to the office-based staffing model) 
- No ability to specialize at all (while many go into consulting to do many different things, at a certain point you will realize that you love certain topics and hate others and want to have some degree of focus)
- Review methods are flawed. Small, non-consequential incidents are frequently cited as examples in reviews, and the review process always feels like a lot of last minute crunching. 
- Culture that places too much emphasis on Associate Consultants to bring "energy" and "culture" to the teams. What's the point in doing so if one coordinates everyone's schedule to plan a team event that no one ends up showing up to or is late to -- on top of all of the other work? 
- Weaker in certain areas vs. BCG or McKinsey (e.g., healthcare, social sector). PEG is overhyped.
- Culture can feel overly "fratty" as expected by a young firm -- one can feel looked down upon for not attending social events are not wanting to get as "crazy" as others
- Getting promoted to the post-MBA position seems quite rare vs. BCG or McKinsey, where a large number of entry levels are direct promoted.

headline: More work than you would think just isn't that interesting or impactful at a personal level, but experiences vary wildly
pros:
- The people and culture are by far the biggest pro. Very smart and passionate, like most of those in the industry, but Bainies generally are more down to earth and supportive. I don't think the "fratty" tag applies anymore, but the people generally are fun in their nerdy ways.

- Brand name on your resume helps you get your foot in the door in many places (if you want to do strategy... if you don't, then don't wait to long to get out).

- Global trainings are fun and great way to network across the world.

- If you want to limit your travel (to the extent you can in consulting) and actually get to know people in your office, then Bain's office staffing model is a much better fit vs. a McKinsey type of model. I actually had a few cases locally.
cons:
- Yes, there is some exciting work but the proportion of heavy project management and process-oriented cases is way higher than I was led to believe during recruiting. Lots of merger integration, PMO and organization projects. I didn't join consulting to build Gantt charts and org structure boxes all day (not that there's anything wrong with it inherently but it's not a good fit for me). Management has also said they plan on competing more in battleground areas like procurement going forward. Expect mix of sexy strategy cases to go down.

- The flip side of the office staffing model is that you have less control of what you get staffed on and are more likely to get put on projects you have no interest in. You wanted a customer strategy case in tech? Too bad, there's a 6 month merger integration case in industrials staffing up and you're the only person in the office available for it. If industry matters to you, think hard about which offices you want to join and ask during recruiting what they work on most. Staffing is often a black box and you have no idea why decisions were made without any input whatsoever from you.

- MBA hires new to Bain are poorly integrated vs. returning Associate Consultants and are definitely lower on the totem pole. This is especially evident in geographies where MBAs aren't quite as prevalent as in the US (Europe and Australia for example) but it holds in the US as well. Some offices are really really bad at this so do your homework.

- A lot of tech, tools and shared services are way behind competitors. You'd be surprised at how much low-value add grunt work you'll have to do compared to other consulting firms that efficiently allocate it and optimize work based on what different roles do best. One example of this is how much time is spent doing expenses because of an antiquated system. I had been hearing for 2 years that the expense system was being improved but nothing had yet been done and people still had to spend a silly amount of time on it.

- Standard for professional services, but the quality of life just isn't good despite what you hear during recruiting. I don't know why people insist on saying during recruiting that 55 hours is a typical week - it's not, 55 hours is a great week. I can count on my two hands the number of times I worked less than 60 in three years.

headline: Great company to work for
pros: All my projects at Bain have been extremely interesting and rewarding, and I've enjoyed working with almost everyone who I've been on a team with from first-year analysts (ACs) to 20-year partners.  I find everyone has a passion for work that I rarely saw in my previous corporate career.  Everyone here is where they are because they enjoy the challenge and thrive with the stimulation of the poorly defined problems that we face in our work day in and day out.
cons: Work/life balance can be challenging, but if you own it for yourself, you are given a lot of room to decide how to manage your own life.  If you allow someone to control your schedule, then they'll happily take it without apologies, but no one has prohibited me from deciding what hours I want to work and how to manage my own life.  It's not a 40-hour week by any means, but it's also not a 60-hour week.  It's all about finding your own balance.

headline: You cannot pick a better place to start your career
pros: With responsibility right out of the gate and a learning curve that never ends, Bain is an incredible place to join the business world, no matter what you want to do with your career. The culture of support, fun, and energy cannot be beat and I love the people I work with and learn from on a daily basis.
cons: It is up to you to create your own lifestyle, so learning to be a self-advocate early on can be tricky.

headline: Phenomenal training, development and culture, but often intense and stressful
pros:
Bain's culture is its selling point and it is deserved.  People genuinely go out of their way to help others, at every level, and this is enforced from the top and through pay structures.  The informal advice I've received from those I've worked with has been crucial for my own development.
More broadly, Bain is a development-accelerator.  Helped by the supportive environment, you are expected to grow quickly and be pushed.  Having just started an MBA where I have far fewer years of experience than most others around me, I can now really see just how uniquely brilliant Bain is for developing people early on in their careers
cons: The work is very stressful, as it is in all top consulting firms. You are constantly working long hours, well out of your comfort zone.  While Bain may manage this a bit better than BCG/Mck, the experience is wearing.  As a result not a place people see themselves staying long term.

cons: Some cases required to put very long hours, making work/life balance difficult to maintain. Being part of the "right" team was an important factor to promote one's career progression.

Don't join without knowing what you're signing up for. The people who don't succeed are the ones who think that just because everyone is nice means you don't have to work hard

headline: Hard work, but worth it
pros:
I joined Bain because I wanted to learn how businesses work and because I wanted to do so in a fun, supportive environment.

Every day I feel that I am learning something new. Whether it's "hard" skills, like building robust models and crafting clear presentations, or "soft" skills, like developing interpersonal relationships, I am constantly presented with opportunities to better myself.

I also feel that my work has real impact. My analysis contributes to important client decisions, which gives me great motivation for and satisfaction from my work.

Best of all, Bainies are smart and genuinely friendly. I never feel that I am in a cutthroat environment and my colleagues and mentors are genuinely interested in helping me progress my career. This collaborative and supportive mindset is an inviolable aspect of our culture.
cons: As with any professional services work, there is great variability in working hours. Supervisors are generally cognizant of these demands and do their best to maintain sustainability.

headline: Best company to work for, but demands a lot
pros: Bain will most likely be the best company I will ever work for. From the compensation, benefits (and snacks) to the quality of my colleagues (both intellectually and interpersonally) and the supportive culture, I have not seen anything that has come close to comparing in my short career thus far.
cons: Extensive travel and long hours (55 hours/week is the median w/ peaks of up to 80+). The work can be extremely ambiguous and complex adding a level of difficulty that is not manageable by some people. Add all that up and it's a very stressful job. Even with the high number of pros listed above, these cons weigh heavily over only a couple years and most people end up leaving for more sustainable work.

Managers spend a lot of time focusing on team-building and making sure the team is happy.
I'm incredibly lucky to work with so many intelligent and ambitious, yet humble people every single day and woulnd't want to have any other job.
cons: The job in itself isn't very flexible, meaning you have to be at the office when the rest of the team is there. I would like to work from home, which works sometimes but very rarely. With all the great benefits this is just a minor thing.

headline: Awesome people, impactful work, and great benefits!
pros: I started at Bain ~3 months ago and I couldn't be more impressed. Every day I am challenged and pushed to my limits, yet there is a strong emphasis on sustainability. The people are extremely supportive and the perks can't be beat. I plan to be here for many years!

headline: Principal
pros: The people are what makes it special.  Throughout my career, I can point to people who invested in me, helping me to grow and develop.  And the relationships I formed in the trenches with my supervisors, peers, and reports helped make me into who I am today.  It's an apprenticeship business and you get to learn from some of the best.  Good learning, fantastic impact, and a lot of fun along the way.  No one hear takes themselves too seriously ... very far from it!
cons: The work is demanding, no question about that.  We invest a lot to make it as manageable as possible.  But even so, it does sometimes feel like you are in a constant struggle to juggle it all and make it work ... and are on the razor's edge of having it all fall apart.

headline: Wouldn't want to work anywhere else!
pros:
Bain is a great place to start your career. Comparing my job with friends and former classmates, I definitely have the feeling I am developing on a hard skill and personal level while enjoying my job as nobody else.

I especially appreciate the personal approach to figure out your own development plan. Multiple people from the office are involved in your development and you can tailor your path to your own needs. Besides that, I am surprised each time again what we are doing for our clients. You feel the founders mentality in a Bain team, everyone wants to achieve the best results possible for our clients. This is incredibly inspiring and also very motivating to do your job day in and day our.
cons: To be happy in this job, you need to be comfortable with a steep learning curve throughout your career. There are not many moments that you can relax and trust on your skill set. There are always thinks you can further develop. People who want to learn a lot will be very happy, but there is not much time for staying in the same place without developing yourself

Also, it's a fantastic opportunity to really make a difference, not only after two years but starting from day one. This is especially based on our strong and close collaboration with our clients, where we achieve the best results. Therefore I can strongly recommend Bain as an excellent place to start your career.

cons: - Some more challenging projects can result in longer working hours, however most of the times compensated with great results and lots of postive feedback

headline: Associate Consultant at Bain
pros: Very interesting work; Real efforts to help consultants to maintain a reasonable work life balance; Plenty of opportunities to take 'breaks' and try new things (social impact externships, office transfers, MBA)
cons: Consulting is a tough industry, particularly in the top tier - there is nothing that management could do to make the lifestyle 'great' all the time

headline: Learn from the brightest
pros: Partners from the firm are very experienced, sharp and want to invest in the development of the people in their teams. As a manager from South America I was warmly welcomed, but also pushed to deliver more insights, client results and an extraordinary team morale.
cons: Although the firm has been emphasizing work-life balance a lot, you simply cannot expect to learn and deliver the same in a 9 to 5 day. Unlike in a bank, there's no 'facetime' culture, but 60 hour weeks are common.

headline: Great company to work for
pros:
Bain has a very collaborative working style with clients, which is a cornerstone for the ability to drive lasting results.
Bain has a unique value driven culture.
Working at Bain is fun: consultants don't take themselves too seriously.
cons: Bain always pulls you out of your comfort zone: always new responsibilities and learning opportunities.

headline: Bain
pros: Great place to work with very high quality people, interesting clients and super-challenging case work.  Good career progression comes as standard, with very good promotion opportunities and broader career transition effectiveness
cons: Like all consulting, you will work hard.  We're client facing, so we do focus on delivering to a very high standard, which can feel quite relentless if not managed properly.

headline: Best place to work!
pros:
Bain is the best company to start my career. The number one thing that attracted me to Bain was the people I met through the interview process and the reality has absolutely lived up to my expectations. Over the last 3 years I have been seduced by Bain's strong and supportive culture and in the process have made some really strong friends. I have also been able to take advantage of the flexibility options and live and work in the US for 6 months. 

The work itself is really challenging and rewarding, everything an ambitious young graduate is looking for in a new job. I had the opportunity to work in a variety of industries, ranging from Oil & Gas to Finance and made some tangible impact while building strong relationships with my clients.
cons: Sometimes the clients are based outside London which means I had to travel during the week. This is a reality of any consulting job and is fun at first while exploring new places, but can sometimes be tiring when combined with the intensity of the job

headline: Executive Assistant
pros: Flexibility, culture, environment, location, people
cons: large company - so hard to get to know a lot people

headline: Bain as a consultant
pros: Excellent training and diverse range of projects. Involvement close to the action on projects with real impact. Great bunch of people. Genuine culture of results-focus, which to my mind makes it (a) ethically sound and (b) better training for future line or entrepreneur role. Great flexibility as you become more senior.
cons: Pressured environment where mistakes are forgiven but not forgotten. Constant review process makes for rapid and satisfying development, but also "always on" atmosphere. Often long hours.

headline: World class clients, great results, fantastic people
pros: Clients ranging from the largest blue chip global leaders to the next generation of upcoming or local companies. Tremendous focus on true and lasting results, hand in hand with the clients. Fantastic and extremely bright people and culture.
cons: Work life balance is in line with what you could expect from a top consulting firm, so there will be long days. There are however multiple initiatives (protected night, possibility to work from home, daily reprioritization of tasks,..) to make this all manageable.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Excellent place to start your career. Many opportunities to have an impact, also as a starter. Collaborative culture and highly engaged people.
cons: Long hours cannot be avoided on certain projects

headline: Recruiting Manager
pros: Work on a daily basis with very smart, inspirational, fun, dedicated and passionate people in a supportive environment where team is more important than the individual
cons: None that I know of.

headline: Great place to build your career
pros: Best people i've ever worked with; hands down the most intelligent, down to earth, humble and fun mix of people you will ever find. Most interesting variety of work and a real opportunity to build your own Bain. Incredibly flexible for high performers, with great opportunities to shape what you want.
cons: Hours can be tough, though you learn alot about yourself and how to prioritise what's important to you

headline: Bain Brussels great place to work
pros: Bain Brussels is a strong growing office that is leading the consultant world in Belgium, with a span across Europe. It's a fast pace environment with projects for all the leading companies in the Benelux in a variety of industries. The work is typically for senior management of the clients and hence very exciting and impact full.  There is also a big focus on learning and development. with worldwide trainings and daily coaching. On top, the office has a super down to earth culture with lots of opportunities to contribute to other things (going from pro-bono work to organizing office events of all sort).
cons: As in every high pace and demanding environment, the working hours are on the high side.

headline: The right balance of challenge, excitement and support
pros: A place where you can have a highly exciting personalised career focused on having an impact at some of the biggest global companies and brands
cons: Careers in Professional services can always be accompanied with a short bursts of stress at times

headline: Best place to Work bei Glassdoor
pros:
I work in the best company I can remember because the BAIN company is a big family.
Everybody have the same spirit, passion, joy to work and together a lot of fun.
One of the best is that everybody fits into the team. There is nobody who isn't a really a BAINIE.
Every day is a major challenge. You can make your experience, you can learn a lot and you can ask everybody for help.
A good working atmosphere with amazing colleagues.
You'll never stop to learn so much and you get the feeling you belong to the big BAIN family all over the world.
Everyone is an enrichment and I’m very proud to be a member of this big BAIN team and of the company.
And in additional is, that BAIN makes so many events for all BAINIES in the local communities and worldwide were you can participate.
cons: Sorry I have no idea.

headline: Great place to work!
pros: one-team spirit, challenging tasks, open-door culture.
cons: there are no "Cons" to mention :-)

headline: Summer Internship
pros:
- Warm & kind-hearted colleagues, who make time for you/ look out for you. This is one of the biggest advantages of Bain's 'home staffing' model - you become part of the community in your office, and the leadership team really invests in you.
- Diverse and challenging work, as advertised
- Excellent benefits, on top of attractive salary
-
cons:
