headline: Great people, great work, great benefits
pros: Amazing, brilliant & interesting people, most cases are very interesting. Great work from "staffing" to match your professional development and the needs of the firm. Got the opportunity to travel.
cons: Long hours on some cases.

headline: Great place to work with extremely bright people
pros: The people here are genuinely passionate about their work, and there is a collective effort to ensure that everyone gets the best out of themselves. It's an environment where you can learn a lot in a short space of time, and within the company there is a feel good factor
cons: Work hours can be unpredictable, sometimes you work to tight deadlines

headline: Awesome Company to work in
pros:
- Great experience
- Meet great people
- Work with high performance teams
- Great Culture
- High growth

headline: Great culture
pros: Fantastic, supportive, collaborative culture. Management really cares about each individual. Lots of opportunities to pursue other interests (e.g. charity work).
cons: As per whole industry, consulting work becoming more specialised and less opportunities to work on pure strategy cases. Data has become a lot more integral to the process.

headline: Senior Consultant
pros: Great fun, culture, spirit, learning opportunities, nice colleagues
cons: Long working hours in consulting, limited flexibility in part time models and selection of cases

headline: AMAZING AND INSPIRATIONAL PLACE TO WORK !
pros:
Working at Bain means working with inspirational and smart people and always upgrading your skills to the top. 
Great people, great social events, great atmoshpere.
cons: Less career opportunities for administration staff than for the consultants. Would need more opportunities to transfer in other offices for admin staff.

headline: Manager
pros: Super interesting, really challenging, constant self improvement
cons: Lifestyle can be from times to times hard to manage

headline: Amazing and fun people + incredible exposure and experience
pros:
Bright and friendly people. Come and find your new family
Lots of traveling opportunities and once in a lifetime experiences (work-related or personal)
Amazing client exposure with huge visible impact even from most junior positions
cons: Predictability of lifestyle is low

headline: The BEST Place to Work
pros:
- Opportunity to tackle interesting business problems each day
- Incredible people to work alongside
- Top-notch training programs and focus on personal development
cons: - Hours can sometimes be high, but management works proactively to address these cases

headline: Great first job
pros:
At Bain the positive you get:
- A well-rounded skillset with rigorous in-office and global training
- Management skills from 1-2 years into the job
- Good compensation
- Amazing culture with fun, ambitious people
cons:
At Bain the negatives you get:

- Long hours

headline: Excellent workplace, but small size has benefits and drawbacks
pros: Good comp, great people, and experience is as promised: fast-paced, high level problem solving, and fairly interesting challenges.
cons: Standard-issue work-life balance difficulties. Smaller offices mean that staffing cannot be as tailored to your preferences - this can be a source of major frustration.

headline: Tremendous impact for clients, supportive culture
pros:

- Great variety of industries, projects, locations and teams
- Steep learning curve at all levels of your career
cons:
- Relatively long working hours

headline: Best place to start your career
pros:
Great support on both professional and personal development from not only official advisers but also from anyone else within the office. 
Great opportunities to directly interact with clients and have a positive impact within their company.
Great work within the non-profit sector.
Best colleagues that will become your friends from day 1.
cons: Everybody is really smart and eager to learn/develop/work so you need to make sure not to get 'sucked in' too much

headline: Working on the best projects, for the best clients, with the best colleagues
pros:
- Working on the most exciting projects for world-class clients across industries
- Working alongside the brightest, most talented and exceptional individuals out there
- Awesome culture - fun, supportive
- Strong focus on professional development - managers are investing significant time and effort in helping you advance
- Fast career progression compared to industry roles
- Truely global firm, offering plenty of possibilities to work abroad
- Great compensation & benefits
cons: - Working on projects that represent pivotal moments for clients can result in situation where maintaining a good work/life balance can be challenging

headline: Best Culture. Best Consultants. Best Firm.
pros:
- Culture, culture, culture!
- Learning opportunities (e.g., Big Data, industries, capabilities, etc.)
- Client Exposure
- Name Recognition
- Mentorship and Coaching
- Ability to expand interests outside of Bain
- Post-Bain career opportunities
- (Mostly) protected weekends 

Personal Anecdote: I was choosing between Bain and BCG and I found that the culture, and client work done at Bain SF the selling point for me. Hands down, this office and this company are unparalleled in their ability to build a cultivating and thriving culture that is fun and inspiring. 

Random note: You can expense things on your personal card versus the corporate card which allows you to keep all the points. This isn't the same across all firms.
cons:

- Too fratty at times

headline: Information specialist
pros: Great coworkers and exciting work!
cons: This company is full of people who work very hard so you often end up working long hours and sometimes on weekends as well.

headline: Work hard, play hard
pros: Good culture, good people.  Flexible work options if you go internal but it also comes with a salary cut.
cons: Client travel required - typically 3-4 days away.

headline: Great people, inspiring atmosphere!
pros: Flexibility, people, training, learning, environment, helpfulness, atmosphere, passion, results-oriented, opportunities, employee satisfaction

headline: Bain Brussels - Best place to start your career
pros: Very strong result delivery, focusing on a cooperative approach with clients; Enormous investments in mentoring and coaching on every level; Possibility to shape our own learning path while being supported by leadership; International case experiences across Europe/world; Very open and friendly culture
cons: Sometimes work life balance is not optimal, long hours can happen depending on client although management focuses on making work as sustainable as possible

headline: Learning & Development
pros: learning, mentoring, career opportunities, coaching
cons: If possible, I'd like to travel a bit more

headline: The biggest clients and the most talented people
pros:
They have huge, very well known/respected multinational clients.
The people are extremely talented, but very modest and grounded with a good sense of humour.
The atmosphere is very collaborative, a truly supportive team spirit.
Every project is a steep learning curve with the reward of great satisfaction at the end from knowing how much your knowledge developed in an area in a short space of time.
cons:
The work is challenging and with each new case you have to put your pride to one side and be open to learning about the subject matter
There is plenty of travel. Some find this a negative, others a benefit.

headline: Associate Consultant

headline: great place to work

headline: Great company to work for and to start one's career!
pros:
- Dynamic working environment: you work with very intelligent people who will always push you to your best
- supportive culture --> in case you want to redirect your career, Bain will always support you and find ways to make you happy with your job (possible to take up responsibilities and to be provided with additional help if needed)
- You are well-rewarded for the hard work that you do (celebrations with colleagues, compensation & benefits, recognition of your work, etc.)
- Very flexible company: as long as you are doing a good job, you can manage your working hours like you want
cons:
- Sometimes a lot of pressure is put on you to manage difficult situations - you need to stay calm and not to be overwhelmed by the stress
- Work hard also means that you need to work late if necessary, as the top quality is always required

headline: Bain & Company - Company Review
pros: Bain & Company offers exactly what I am looking for as a young professional: a unique work environment, a company culture that can be characterized by outmost support both from a learning and from a mentoring point of view and a high ability, also for junior colleagues, to make an impact. Bain's value proposition is not just unique but it also differs from that of its competitors in that Bain places a "one team" attitude above everything making it a great place to work. This even results in friendships beyond just co-working and spending the work-week together. Therefore, Bain is the exact right place for me to start my career and to prepare me for future steps/ developments. The support that you enjoy as a member of Bain & Company both on junior but also on more senior levels is outstanding and makes you feel part of something "bigger", even part of a "family" with great co-workers. Even in times of great stress or when facing (private/ personal) issues, the company supports you in taking necessary steps to overcome the issues, which is very important in today's business world. And at Bain & Company you enjoy such great flexibility. Furthermore, and this is amongst the most important aspects of an attractive employer, young professionals are granted the possibility to create impact: they can derive solutions with guidance from the leadership team independently, have exposure to (senior) clients from which they can learn a lot and can implement the developed solutions to actually implement the change in the organization(s) thereby further developing an amplified skillset. As part of the learning curve, these are opportunities that not all employers can offer and which sets Bain apart from other companies/ consultancies. Together with flexible career opportunities and development plans offered, Bain has an outstanding value proposition.
cons: Further improvements could be made regarding work-life-balance

headline: Bain Chicago
pros: High impact, industry shaping work with some of the biggest companies in the world; Wide range of industries and projects to be staffed on; Incredibly talented colleagues who are easy and enjoyable to work with; excellent support staff (HR, IT etc.); well compensated; rapid career progression; very supportive culture
cons: Some travel needed to client sites depending on case; Longer weeks (e.g. ~65 hrs) during busy / crunch period on projects but typically balances out with downtime between projects

headline: Great place to work
pros: Great culture and challenging work opportunities
cons: Supportive staff and ability to consistently grow

headline: Great place to work, amazing culture and learning opportunities
pros:
- Great, family-like culture with many fun and inspiring colleagues
- Amazing development opportunities right from your first day 
- High impact work (C-level impact at great clients)
- Great variety in type of work and sectors
- Ample opportunities to travel, yet no pressure to do so if not compatible with personal circumstances
cons: Lifestyle can be tough at occasions, but generally acceptable when comparing to the average in the consulting industry

headline: Business Analyst
pros: Good Salary, benefits and career

headline: Incredible place to work
pros:
- Working with high profile clients at CEO and C-suite level, helping them solve their most critical issues.
- Wide variety of projects, both from a sector and capabilities standpoint
- Incredible learning opportunities on the job, one is always pushed out of one's comfort zone

headline: Fantastic company to work for
pros:
- highly motivated, ambitious people who like to help each other succeed
- work atmosphere that is supporting, helps you thrive, while also making sure that everybody has  a lot of fun
- international opportunities (MBA, short-term/long-term transfer, leave of absence to go volunteer/travel etc) to accommodate personal wishes
cons: none that I can think of

headline: Best company to work for
pros: Unparalleled learning opportunities - from creating real value for the stakeholders, to managing a team of high-performance contributors, to creating a network of sponsors among clients
cons: Work/life balance - there is large attention from top and middle management to create a sustainable working experience... but the work is what it is, and requires dedication (unless we sacrifice output quality, which is obviously not up for discussion)

headline: Bain & Company review - great place to work!
pros: excellent culture, fun and talented work colleagues, great grounding in business skills
cons: not always a choice of projects due to limited client set

headline: Great place to start your career
pros: Challenging work, smart & fun people
cons: Working hours can be long

headline: Great place to work!
pros: Amazing people, best in class development opportunities.
cons: Work can be challenging at times.

headline: A great company to work for
pros: I've worked at several companies so far in my life, and I have really been amazed by my experience at Bain. We deliver incredible results for our clients bringing our experience and analytical rigor and working with clients hand in hand to determine and address their issues. We have an incredibly supportive and fun culture that helps us grow and become amazing partners to our clients and leaders when we decide to leave.
cons: The cons that I see at Bain & Company are more so industry related than company related. Professional services is tougher than industry, from an hours and travel perspective.

headline: Fantastic place to work and grow
pros:
The people, the projects, the attention to detail by management, the compensation.

The regional staffing model and people are what make it head and shoulders better than its peer group of consulting firms. If you value anything outside of work, the staffing model equates to a much more sustainable and controllable lifestyle, without negatively affecting the experience in any way.
cons: Longer hours, but beach time in between projects (essentially free vacation days) help balance.

headline: Bain is the best!!!!
pros:
- Best place to learn: structured thinking, get to know most important trends in any industry, learn how to drive change at orgs and how execs think, learn how to manage teams with great professional development tools, build sweet decks and learn how to model
- Build network: particularly if you're staying in same geography, broader Bain network can enable you to do almost anything
- Growth trajectory: Bain continues to do really well financially, means great career growth trajectory
cons:
- We constantly push really hard - hours aren't as long as some other consulting firms, but that's made possible through ruthless prioritization. It's not the kind of job where you can just write off a day
- Hourglass team structure - more than competitors, we put so much on the manager position

headline: Best place to work!
pros:
- Learn from some of the smartest people you'll meet
- Interesting, impactful work for senior leaders at the largest companies
- Amazing culture
cons:
- Higher hours (though typical or low for the industry)
- Lack of flexibility due to client needs (again, typical for the industry)

headline: Amazing place to work!!
pros: Phenomenal opportunities to work on the most challenging problems faced by companies in different industries around the world, opportunities to work on cutting edge business-related IP, exceptional local and global training programs, uniquely collaborative and fun culture
cons: Can be tough to maintain a work life balance due to travel

headline: Highly recommend Bain!
pros:
Very supportive working environment ("A Bainie never lets another Bainie fail!") - Bain culture is truly lived by
Ability to easily change between industries
cons: Time-consuming case work - however, this should be expected and is no surprise

headline: A great place to work
pros:
- pragmatic, down-to-earth culture: real people, not show-offs
- strong sense of community: we are still small enough to know your colleagues
- real focus on results: we to the things that matter to our clients, and our clients value our work
- strong focus on professional and personal development: we take care of our own and invest in their development, looking at the individual, not at quotas
- we are serious about our values: people who do not honor them will not succeed at Bain
cons:
- workload: our work is in high demand, and our growth is strong - the downside of which is that we work a lot
- variety of projects: while we are present in all industries and serve the full spectrum of projects, we are not a behemoth that has 20 projects of one type in any given industry at the same time, sometimes you will have to wait a bit for your "dream project" - but this is the natural downside of being a smaller firm, focused on the toughest problems
- international staffing: absolutely possible and happens a lot, but we are still trying to staff our teams "close to home", if possible - if you do not want this, you have to articulate it very clearly

headline: A great place to start your career
pros:
- A supportive culture (e.g. learning and mentoring)
- The ability to make an impact (for our clients and in our communities)
- Best in class maternity leave
cons: - It's client service; sometimes the hours can be long

headline: Great place to work
pros:
Supportive managers
Great professional development
Wide opportunities apart from case work
Pamper you with social events
cons:
Now in expansion phase so hiring some industry hires who are not Bain-fit
May be losing its cool culture due to the high expansion of FTEs

headline: A great place to get challenged, learn, grow and have fun
pros: The atmosphere in our office is amazing - people know each other (and by much more than their name!), care about each other, work on exciting cases for leading global clients that want to change, and we create impact. There is room to grow with a tailored career path - and if you like sports, social impact, organizing events etc., you can combine this with work and add an extra layer to it.
cons: A small con is that working hours sometimes are unpredictable - but when you communicate and plan, often those appointments can be met and that's important for me.

headline: Challenging, supportive opportunity to work with best-in-class (colleagues + clients)
pros:
For me Bain is one of the best opportunities I have had in my professional life (always a bit hesitant to say this out loud) - but there are plenty of moments when I realize how great the work is we do and how proud I feel on our work and culture. I remember having to chose between consultancy firms, finding very hard to know what the differences are. In hindsight, there are things to know, that would have made this choice a lot easier. To name a few (up to you if you believe they fit whatever you are looking for):
- Bain has a clear true north approach; be honest and open about your approach and answer, especially in the internal and external communication
- Bain serves the largest, most impressive clients worldwide 
- Bain has a distinctive focus on Private Equity (vs McKinsey, BCG), which allows you to see a different side of consulting
- Bain has super supportive and collaborative culture and vibe in the office; colleagues become friends (of course not all of them) and a Bainee never lets another Bainee fall 
- Bain implies humor and a 'don't take yourself too serious' attitude - but at the same time our work is taken at the single most important thing
- Bain's Amsterdam office is still small enough to know everybody in person, which makes it even more collaborative and fun
- Bain has great opportunities outside of Amsterdam, the Netherlands and Europe!
cons:
- Working at Bain requires to have some balance - it is always hard to find the balance in work, social activities with work and your social life pre-Bain
- You will be challenged every single day, and although there is always guidance and help available, you need to be up for a challenge and enjoy the ride
- Our feedback culture is very open and straightforward - something which feels natural to the Dutch culture, but requires a certain mind-set as well

headline: Results & People
pros:
High impact at high profile clients. Steep learning curve.
Amazing culture: coaching, supportive, driving individuals to reach their full potential
cons: This high learning curve, great impact etc. comes at a cost. We should continue to improve on sustainability... but this is consulting

headline: The place to start a career
pros:
The best job you can get out of university to set yourself up
-Learning is phenomenal
-Culture is spot on
-People are unbelievably smart
cons: - Long hours; certain Partners are not 'current' Bain and don't have a focus on worklife balance

headline: Joining & staying at Bain: a no-brainer
pros:
4 years ago, I joined Bain Brussels as an Associate Consultant Intern.
At the time, I was excited by the opportunity to crack some of the toughest business problems encountered by CEOs with a group of smart, driven people, and my expectations have not been disappointed.

The work I’ve had the chance to do at Bain has been incredible.
From driving a full-scale strategy and organization transformation at a global industrials company of 16,000 employees to working on some of the world’s largest mergers in consumer goods, I feel I’ve personally been a part of meaningful results for notorious clients.

What I didn’t know 4 years ago, however, is that I would end up getting to do this great work with mentors and teammates who would become some of my closest friends and advisors, and who would be so personally committed to my success.
For me, Bain has offered an incredible mix of problem solving with real, enduring results and a supportive, fun culture that I couldn’t have found anywhere else.
cons: At Bain, you never stop learning. In practice, it also means that you're never really in your comfort zone... but that's the very reason that makes up all wake up in the morning.

headline: Bain & Co review
pros:
- No other company that is so true to its values, the people and the leadership team really live the company values
- Bain & Co always puts the client's interest in the first place. There is no room for politics and selfishness
- Quality of the people at Bain & Co is something I have never seen before
cons: The job is amazing but asks a significant personal investment (often travelling and therefore spending less nights at home, working long hours at times, etc.)

headline: Growing at Bain
pros:
Bain&Company has for me been the most terrific start of my career. Over the past four years, I've been able to do projects in telecoms, CPG en private equity and across all sorts of capabitlies: Pure strategy, Cost Savings, Merger Integration and both DD and VDD work.

Apart from the many opportunities I got within Bain, I also got to experience New York City and Columbia University in particular for my MBA. Bain fully supported me to take an educational leave for 18 months in order to complete the MBA program at Columbia - an amazing experience, I would otherwise have never had a chance to do. 

Thirdly, Bain is a place that really helps you get the best out of yourself: there's a whole network of supporters behind you that help you truly become the best that you can be. On your case team there are weekly professional development chats with your manager, which help you develop in your day to day job. Additionally, you select your own personal advisor, that helps you make the bigger career choices and helps you succeed at Bain in the long run. Laslty, there are many 'informal' advisors: people that I have worked with, people that I've gotten to know socially, or anyone else in the office, that is always there to chat about whatever career question you might have. 

Last, but certainly not least, is the enormous impact I've seen our teams have at our clients. Probably my favorite case was a merger case, in which we first carved out a specific part of a large food conglomerate, to later merge this carve-out with a specialized player in the market. Te merger created the #2 player in that market and was completely up and running in two years time - something I didn't think our client and us could make happen at the start.
cons: Though Bain is a great place to work and I would always recommend anyone to go and work here, the hours can be long. We have demanding clients and demand a lot from ourselves - a combination that can result in longer than average working days.

headline: Awesome place to work
pros:
- Focus on/track record of creating lasting results for our clients
- Supportive culture that values learning and relationships 
- Flexibility to build a sustainable long term career
cons: Being in client services means that sometimes your schedule is unpredictable week to week however as you become more senior, your control over your schedule increases

headline: Deserving of "best place to work"
pros: The people are fantastic, you will learn great skills, the work is challenging, interesting and impactful. Lives up to its name as a career accelerator.
cons: Longer hours for some cases - but management is aware and will usually try and adapt approach to improve sustainability. Generalist model isn't for everyone.

headline: Great fun place to work
pros:
- Brilliant individuals
- Great working conditions & premium office locations
- International & open-minded corporate culture
cons: - Work / Life balance

headline: Partner
pros: Bain has the best learning opportunities, throughout your career.  You have significant impact not only on client's business, but your own personal development.  Hands down, the best place to learn how to run a business.
cons: Not much come to mind

headline: Great place to work with tremendous learning opportunities and a strong focus on Corporate Culture
pros: Bain works with high-profile clients on the most relevant management decisions. As part of the Bain team, one can thereby quickly advance his/her skill set along various dimensions. Further, Bain puts a high focus on the collaboration of teams (also beyond the project work) and heavily invests in the positive Corporate Culture.
cons: The high intensity of traveling can be exhausting.

headline: Long term learning & stimulation
pros: High amount of impact at exciting clients, Incredible rate of learning at any moment in my career, Personal care and coaching, Feeling like a family with a fun culture
cons: Opportunity to go even further in gender diversity and working on sustainability, despite constant efforts and improvements

headline: Real impact - no ivory tower
pros: Great minds that care for each other (a Bainie never lets another Bainie fail) and embrace a Founder's Mentality
cons: Travel-intensive consulting business in Germany

headline: Great place to work and start a career!
pros: Fast paced, dynamic work environment with fun and very supportive people. The company embraces driving results for their clients based on data driven insights. Personal and professional development is prioritized for every team member. Even at the entry level there are opportunities to work with senior executives at influential companies across every industry.
cons: Experience can vary based on case/team placement, but there are many opportunities to give feedback and work on many different teams if you'd like.

headline: Great experience but exhausting
pros: Culture - camaraderie with colleagues is fantastic - made some lifelong friends! Interesting projects, with lots of room to grow in a structured strategy consulting environment. If you can find the right senior folks to work for, your experience can be awesome.
cons: Projects vary dramatically from one office to another. Work-life balance is difficult to achieve in a sustainable fashion. Travel 4 days per week may work for some, but too much for me. Ability to succeed is dependent on politics, as is the case with most companies. Its just more subtle here.

headline: A lifelong career
pros:
- Over and above investment from senior leadership in individual professional development 
- Supportive team environment, we are all in this together to deliver results and add value
- Work life balance is important to management
- Options for career mobility
- Ability to work on a diverse set of tasks/issues
- Flexible work hours
- Vacation time, health insurance and paternity/maternity leave policies are the best I've ever seen!
cons: Not many cons about working at Bain. You won't always be able to see the value add in all situations but Bain does a great job instilling the belief that in everything we do, if we do it right, we are building promoters. I can find motivation in that.

pros: Great place, great people, great vibe
cons: Hard work, demanding but rewarding

headline: Great place to work
pros: Great people, impactful work, rigorous training, personal and professional development support, mentor culture, apprenticeship model, incredibly supportive work environment
cons: Long hours, lot's of travel, work can be stressful at times depending on team and manager dynamics

headline: Consultant
pros: Great colleagues to work with
cons: Demanding Environment to work in

headline: Great company to start your career
pros:
- Very supportive and great learning experience. You will constantly work with extremely smart and humble people. 
- Collaborative working environment with clients. New starters get send to the client early on and have the opportunity to lead client meetings early on
cons: - On some cases long hours and intensive working environment

headline: Highly recommend!
pros: The people are extremely supportive. Contrary to popular belief, there isn't this feeling of competing amongst peers. Everyone was willing to help me instantly when I needed it. Also people were fun to be around - I enjoyed spending my evenings with members of my team once we were off work.
cons: Transferring after ACI summer to a different location for full-time may be harder than expected.

headline: Amazing place to work and grow!
pros:
The first thing which comes to mind is the quality of the people, both the raw talent coming in and the senior talent which has been in the company for a while - smart and enjoyable.
The culture is truly unique and that is what keeps Bain such a great place to live. 
When I came to Bain, I expected to learn the toolkit of the general manager and the strategic thinker (which I have been learning) - but to my surprise, I have been learning about leadership and personal growth in equal measure.
cons: The typical top Tier consulting challenges apply to Bain: it's a fast paced environment, and in client services, so projects can be quite busy and it can be tricky to balance personal life with the requirements of the job. The office centered approach and supportive culture do a lot to alleviate those challenges,

headline: Best career choice I made
pros:
Coming from an advanced degree background (Ph.D.) I was looking for a place that would have excellent mentorship, great network, excellent culture, and limitless opportunities to work on exciting projects and develop the skills I need to success in the business world.  Bain has exceeded my expectations.  

-Very interesting and high impact projects (my experience has been mostly in healthcare in the SF office) and excellent private equity group
-Awesome training and mentorship (very useful as an advanced degree, clear goals and stepwise increase in responsibilities)
-Very sustainable (big emphasis of teams; lots of families; I can do it and I have a 2 year old)
-Local staffing with opportunities to travel if you choose to
-Close knit office culture (partners are easily accessible and supportive; local staffing really helps you develop relationships with people in your office)
-Long-standing relationships with clients (again because of local emphasis; allows one to have access to higher level projects and executives)
-Great network outside of Bain that has strong ties to Bain and is willing to help
-Growing business (very high growth globally and in the SF office)
-Opportunities for social impact, externships, office transfers, etc.
-Excellent paternity leave (8 weeks of paid leave and supportive culture where everyone takes the full amount)
cons: I can't think of any.  Cons would be general to the consulting industry (i.e. you have to like working on teams, diverse projects, and put in hard work)

headline: Great place to work
pros: Solving the biggest client problems, collaborative team, really smart people
cons: Sometimes lifestyle can be unsustainable

headline: Invested in people, high impact work
pros: Very few places offer the level of exposure and impact to people so early in their career. There is a significant investment in personal development and a culture of frequent constructive feedback and support. It's not uncommon to have a meeting every two weeks to exchange feedback and ensure that you are on track. The office-centric staffing makes it easy to connect with others in the office and develop and maintain mentorship relationships, which really supports growth over a number of years. This isn't somewhere where you're expected to churn through people every two years -- while people do leave, it's to pursue their own interests with lots of support from Bain rather than because the job/office isn't supporting them/burned them out.
cons: Like most professional services, this is a demanding job. Although Bain practices travel as needed, you may still be on the road for 2-4 days a week, depending on the case. The nature of the personal development structure means you will always be pushed to be a little bit better than you were yesterday, which is great but can be uncomfortable if you are looking to just rest on past success.

headline: AC review
pros: Good culture, good learning, good comp/benefits, sets you up well to do anything. Fun to work on a variety of projects on the highest priority issues for clients
cons: Long hours, varying lifestyle by project

headline: Great place to launch your business career
pros:
Collegial atmosphere 
Impact/Results focus 
Firm wide focus on mentorship and development 
Fantastic client relationships and partnerships 
Global trainings are incredible - awesome location and content 
Opportunities out of both undergrad and MBA are unparalleled in the level of exposure to senior clients, and an individuals role in cracking the case.
cons: The firm has been running so hot the past few years, that everyone is very busy.   Very little "beach time" between assignments, which can make it hard to catch your breath.

headline: High-impact work with fantastic people
pros: The perfect balance of challenging, high-impact work solving clients' most important problems and a fun, supportive atmosphere of friendly, smart people makes Bain a best-in-class place to work. I am constantly learning and growing by taking on new responsibilities for clients with the support of my supervisors and mentors. Professional development is unparalleled - high-quality, actionable feedback is given every couple of weeks from both direct supervisors and managers, and 6-month reviews are delivered effectively to help me reach my professional goals. The people here are fun, humble, and selfless. Team members help each other solve business problems and support each other outside the office. Finally, the global training program is unmatched by any other firms. I've made friendships with people from around the world and learned by practicing case work, not listening to lectures, during our training programs.
cons: The job is unpredictable. You may not know whether you'll be traveling, home, or working late until a day or a week in advance. If you can accept this lack of predictability, you will find there are few cons to working here!

headline: Fantastic work, fantastic people
pros: I've been consistently blown away by the quality of work and quality of people I've encountered during my time at Bain.  Training is a clear priority as well!
cons: No cons specific to Bain - I think client services comes with its own problems, but that is nothing that Bain can address in a vacuum.

headline: Great place to start or sustain a career
pros: Strong support structure for consultants, exposure to a wider variety of company sizes, problems, industries than most competitors, easy to transfer from office to office if needed
cons: Client services is inherently stressful at times, travel can get old, hours are less predictable than a typical 9-5

headline: Incredible place to work
pros: Unparalleled company culture, exceptional professional development,  intellectually stimulating work, and a vast array of exit opportunities available (if desired). Bain teams adopt a genuine "one team" attitude and support each other to deliver top-notch results for clients - while having fun, as well! Bain places extraordinary emphasis on professional development - I feel as though I have mentors who are invested in me as a person, and I consistently receive the coaching and actionable feedback that helps me grow. And because Bain is an industry leader, we get to work with exceptional clients to solve their most challenging, interesting questions - I know our work makes a true, lasting impact for our clients. I consider working at Bain a privilege and honor.
cons: When working for an industry leader like Bain, which is known for delivering exceptional client results, you have to expect that long working hours will sometimes be part of that. Sustainability can become a concern for some - however, Bain does a tremendous amount to support a sustainable lifestyle. Case teams respect weekly commitments or "early nights," vacations are considered sacred, weekend work is avoided when at all possible, and teams check in regularly to ensure everyone is doing alright.

headline: Best Place To Work
pros:
- Amazing mentorship and investment from management in your professional development
- Opportunity to work on interesting problems for clients across industries
- Option to travel - it's there if you want it but if not you can often be local
- Outstanding financial rewards that reflect Bain's meritocratic culture
cons: - It is client services - ultimately you are at whim of client which can lead to long work hours

headline: Love my job
pros: Mentors who want you to succeed, caring co-workers, fun atmosphere
cons: wish the CSS staff had more flex on hours

headline: Bain & Company review
pros: I have been at Bain & Company for over 4 years - with no plans to leave anytime soon. Bain says they really care about their employees at it's true! I have never experienced even close to the level of support, benefits, etc. elsewhere (and I have worked at 3 other companies). I feel so fortunate to be on an amazing team, and feel supported by my peers as well as mentors and managers.
cons: The career paths for those outside the consulting staff is less clear/defined.

headline: Bain review
pros: Great place to build a business career. It provides opportunities and experiences well beyond what you can get in corporate positions.
cons: There is very little to say in terms of cons at Bain. Only caveat would be if you know exactly what you want to do in a specialized role, Bain's learnings are more general.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Your colleagues are legitimately smart, and always interested in helping you progress your career. Pay is generous and grows quickly if you do well. Company culture is unparalleled. Work is interesting and focused on most important company problems
cons: Work can be taxing, and the nature of client services often leads to fire drills and stress. As with any consulting firm, sometimes you'll work on specific tasks that are annoying, but it's definitely the minimum

headline: Bain advocates for my professional development
pros: Someone once asked me, "What would have to happen for you to leave Bain?" and my answer was that I would have to lose my mentors--the people who are invested in my professional growth. The coaching, feedback, and opportunities I am given to challenge myself are major contributors to what makes this job exciting and satisfying. Other factors include smart, fun, and respectful coworkers and of course clients with whom we collaborate to meaningfully improve their companies.
cons: The only major downside of working at Bain is that cases can be very demanding. This is a double edged sword--it means I'm very engaged in the work that I do, but it can also be exhausting.

headline: Great value proposition
pros:
-Unbelievable learning opportunities
-Diversity of work and importance to clients is top notch
-Great culture, very collegial atmoshphere
-Company continues to grow quickly
cons:
-It's no surprise, but some projects can be quite demanding
-Structure training and mentorship seems to decrease once you get to the manager level

headline: Best In Class
pros:
Best in class client results - I hear over and over again from my clients that "it just feels different to team with Bainies." They love our work, and they also love working with us. That makes a client services job incredibly rewarding as you often find yourself developing strong friendships, as well as advisory relationships, with senior clients. Our rate of enduring clients who actively call Bain for their toughest problems speaks for itself. 

Strong supportive culture - It's in the DNA of Bainies to support one another, coach, and mentor. I feel like I have an amazing set of mentors supporting my career, all the way from Senior Directors to my peers to our ACs. 

No better place to start your career - I am in awe at the opportunities Bain creates for our ACs and Cs to develop the general manager mindset. We constantly push our teams to deliver the best work we can, and as part of this we stretch our people to learn new skills and build towards their personal career goals. It is awesome to watch Bainies succeed, both at Bain and outside of Bain.
cons: Client services is inherently demanding and at times unpredictable. However, Bain really does support you in finding a balance that works for you. Increasingly you have control over your schedule and I've found that helps provide mental wellness all in, carving out enough time for my own life outside of work, and flexing work hours as needed to do that.

headline: Great place to be
pros: Great, nice and intelligent people
cons: Can be more welcoming for parttimes

headline: Former Employee
pros: Great company to work for.  Great people
cons: Take care of your loyall employee

headline: Senior Associate Consultant
pros: Amazing culture and amazing staff. Pretty much the perfect job coming out of college -- a concentrated professional development experience, access to a variety of industries.
cons: Bain's generalist model has both pros and cons. Provides you the opportunity to develop skills in a variety of fields, but tough to develop specific expertise in one industry (depending on the office).

headline: Fantastic career launching pad with unparalleled learnings and supportive culture
pros: Results-oriented - results for our clients, results for our people. Supportive and connected culture. Ability to work on high impact projects with high profile clients. Unparalleled learnings for those starting off their careers
cons: Like most client-services, workload can have significant variability and tight turnarounds, but typically the learnings outweigh any lifestyle challenges

headline: Love going to work every day
pros:
The work is incredible. At Bain, we tackle challenging problems with clients who are often in crisis and need dynamic solutions tailored to their unique culture. I think that's what makes Bain different - we are highly responsive to clients, and instead of pulling a generic solution off the shelf, we build our answer from the ground up. The Partners I work with would never in good faith hand off a recommendation to a client then walk away. We embed the idea of "results delivery" in all of our work, so that the solution we identify can be successfully implemented by the client once we leave.

As a former AC, I truly believe Bain is the best possible place you can start your career. The company cares deeply about your professional development and it comes through in global training, in bi-weekly professional development chats with your Manager, and in coaching sessions with your mentor, your colleague and your Professional Development Advisor (3 different people!)

The people are also amazing :)
cons:
It's a professional services job so at the end of the day, it's the client that makes the final go/no-go decision. You can have the perfect solution but if the CEO has different ideas, then there's nothing you can do about that. 

As an AC or a Consultant, you own your workstream and get to develop an idea from inception to client handoff, but often times you don't see the FULL lifecycle of a particular idea or solution, like you would at a startup or as a product manager.

headline: Best Place to Work, hands down
pros: Supportive work environment, everyone has passion about delivering results to our clients.  Smart, driven employees who care about our clients and each other.
cons: You'll work hard at Bain but it's worth it!

headline: Incredible Place to Grow
pros: Bain invests in each individual's growth and development. Bain provides a unique combination of high impact career opportunities within a fun and supportive work environment.
cons: Bain has been working hard to create more flexible options for paths within the company. I think this continues to be an opportunity area so that we can attract and retain the best business talent.

headline: Manager
pros: The pros about Bain & Company are the following: it has an amazing culture. The work is challenging work. There are great people. And, there is a strong focus on professional development.
cons: The pros about Bain & Company are the following: The work life balance can be very challenging given the pace of work and the realities of professional services. Not for everyone.

headline: Still loving it
pros: It's hard not love the ability to have a material impact on our clients' businesses, the long-term development of the people with whom we work (both clients and teams), and the way that Bain operates through constant innovation. It's what still keeps me hear after so many years
cons: Sustainability is less about hours and more about uncertainty, driven by the client services nature of our business. This gets easier the more senior you are (and have more control over the calendar), but CEOs still call at 5pm on a Friday...

headline: Greatest Place to Work in the World!
pros: There is no better place to work than Bain & Company. They are the most supportive and fun work place I have ever seen. Everyone is so kind and invested in your personal and professional growth.
cons: There is an amazing work/life balance at Bain, but I wish we had more work from home days!

headline: overall good
pros: Meritrocratic, fun, good people, fast growth
cons: Work life balance is unsustainable

headline: Principal
pros: Very strong culture, collegial work environment, interesting work, great compensation, local staffing, great career development opportunities and professional development, diversity
cons: Long hours, travel cases, steep learning curve, predictability low at lower levels, case variety

headline: Great Place to Accelerate One's Career
pros:
Great Mentoring Programs
Equality for all; including minorities and LGTB 
Flexible hours and career
Flat hierarchy
Perfect Meritocratic system
cons:
Huge Work Load
May involve a lot of travel

headline: Great career starter
pros: Awesome people, interesting work (for the most part), great network to have
cons: Long hours, travel, stress; but all of that is expected in consulting

headline: Very meticulously data architecting
pros: Good benefits, can meet diversed group of people, bosses are good and friendly, data architecting is my strength with SQL.
cons: Dealing and negotiating with clients are a big headache to upper management. Plus deadlines is crucial has to be met in order results are being delivered.

headline: Best place to work for recent college grads
pros:
- Great place to start a career
- Lots of learning opportunities and mentorship/support
- Interesting work, cool problems to solve
- Fun teams, amazing office culture
- Enjoy going to work every day
cons: - Hours can sometimes be long, but it is worth it for the learning opportunities and relationships you develop

headline: Unparalleled Learning Environment
pros: Mentorship, openness to feedback, rapid exposure to new industries, supportive culture, fun co-workers, little emphasis on hierarchy
cons: Work-life balance is not enforced.

headline: Great Company
pros: Amazing place to work at. Supportive environment which helps grow as a person. Focus on full round development. Right place to start a career.
cons: The challenges are typical to a consulting firm - travel, long working hours.

headline: Fantastic company to build strong networks of mentors while having lasting impact with variety of clients
pros:
Create deep long lasting relationships with co-workers (up and down) - over the past couple of years I have developed lasting mentorship (and friendship) relationships with both supervisors (Managers, Partners) and supervisees (Analysts). This has been enabled by (1) local staffing model allowing to develop relationships over time (2) supportive and learning culture (weekly or bi-weekly professional development chats with supervisees) (3) group of exceptional individuals, working with other Bainies is very humbling

Bain's teams commitment to have lasting impact for our clients is inspiring. It is supported by a (1) commitment to providing 'the right answer' combined to (2) a culture of collaboration with the client to ensure design of practical solutions the clients truly believe in
cons: Though leadership really focuses on combining lasting client results with a sustainable experience for the teams, variance across cases still exist.

headline: supportive culture
pros: Whether you are a seasoned professional, or a recent graduate, Bain is supportive of your personal and professional growth.  I have had nothing but positive experiences learning and teaming with others at Bain.
cons: No negative comments at this time.

headline: Continue to love where I work
pros:
I came to Bain thinking that I would stay for two years, learn a lot and then head on my way to try something new.  Instead, I find myself here five years later and continue to love every day at my job.  The amount that I have learned during my time here is just phenomenal.  I have worked on really interesting and hard problems across endless different industries.  Each case is a new challenge and you won't find another place that so relentlessly wants to find the best (and most actionable) answers for our clients.  

What has also kept me here for the last five years is the amazing people.  My Bain colleagues are some of my best friends.  I love the teams that I manage and am consistently learning from them and laughing with them every day.  We work hard but we are humble and down to earth and have fun while we do it.
cons: The life style can be tough at times, but at least we spend time with really great people.

headline: Manager
pros: Great opportunities to work abroad, unparalleled coaching across all levels that encourages you to be challenged always.
cons: It's important to find more ways to make job more sustainable for women. This applies to all consulting.

headline: Best post-MBA career choice
pros:
There is no better career choice to make right out of business school: the environment is fast paced, you are surrounded by brilliant, supportive, and fun people, and you are constantly learning something new. It's an MBA's dream career.
The apprenticeship model at Bain means that you are not only always learning, but you have someone managing you who is there to show you the ropes - because he or she was in your shoes just a few years earlier. A heavy emphasis on mentorship and a strong company culture help reinforce this model.
cons: Like many consulting roles, the hours can be very unpredictable. Luckily with Bain's local staffing model there are frequently opportunities to be staffed in the city you live, making the work/life balance more manageable.

headline: Amazing learning environment
pros: Great apprenticeship culture - lots of opportunities for feedback and steady progression of opportunities. As someone who wants to gain broad exposure, particularly earlier in my career, I can't imagine a better place to start. Amazing colleagues to learn from, who foster incredible team culture into a sense of community
cons: Less predictable / controllable hours in client services

headline: Consultant
pros: Supportive environment with a constant set of challenges that help you progress through your career.
cons: Working hours can be a bit longer.

headline: Bain Review
pros: Really feel like a valued employee!
cons: I see on the consulting side that the work life balance isn't all that great

headline: Associate Consultant
pros: There is a large emphasis on professional development, where those more senior than you are very personally invested in the development of the people below them. At the same time, the culture is one that also prioritizes a sustainable work-life balance, so that we can grow on the job but also grow in life as a whole.
cons: I don't have any Cons about the job, this is the best job you can get right out of undergrad

headline: The learning never stops
pros:
Bain is an unparalleled place to start a career. As a young person you are tasked with solving problems of the highest impact. Each time you begin to feel comfortable with your job you are asked to fill a new role - creating an environment of ongoing learning that is invaluable.

Beyond that - Bain invests in its people. Human capital is the scarcest resource Bain trades in and they do all they can to find and develop it.
cons: Bain is a great company and does its best to create a supportive and engaging workplace. However, like any client services firm, there are times, albeit rare,  where client needs win out over those of employees.

headline: Incredible place to work!
pros:
1. Formal and informal mentorship
2. Working on some of the most interesting and difficult problems faced by the worlds' most influencial companies
3. Fun, supportive culture
4. Incredibly smart co-workers
5. Local staffing model means less travel and actually knowing the people you work with
6. Attractive exit options at every level
cons: Like any Consulting firm, involves some travel and late nights

headline: Very good pace to learn
pros: - will learn a lot
cons: - more weightage on what the client wants than what the client neeeds

headline: Knowledge Specialist
pros: Analysis, Strategy, Leadership, Team Work, Global Exposure
cons: Fragmented, Open culture, Silos, Not structured, Movability to other teams

headline: Bain Chicago Consultant
pros:
The generalist model. In my first year at Bain, I've worked in functional areas including: Growth Strategy, M&A diligence, PE diligence, Performance Improvement, and Organizational Strategy. I've worked across industries including: Agriculture, CPG, Industrials, Restaurants, Sports, and Healthcare. I came to consulting to gain breadth in problem solving across industries and have experienced exactly that. 

The impact on our clients. I've had 2 of my cases show up on the front page of the WSJ this year and have been involved in helping to save a company running up against debt covenants with their banks and financial sponsors. The work I've been involved with has been innovative and transformative and having a seat at the table to work through these solutions has been very rewarding. 

The support and people at Bain. There have been numerous times when my team has worked late evenings and weekends to help me out when needed (and vice versa). No one is left behind to struggle on their own. I feel like people are really invested in my success and I've been able to maintain these relationships long after a case ends. 

The brand. I started receiving calls, LinkedIn messages, and emails about potential exits less than 6 months into my job at Bain. The skills and executive presence you get as a Consultant are very sought after in industry.
cons: It's a demanding job which sometimes requires travel and personal sacrifices. Working in client services can oftentimes be unpredictable and sporadic. If you know that going into the industry, it shouldn't come as a surprise. However, this can be an adjustment from industry.

headline: Great place to start your career
pros:
- Accelerated learning
- Incredible mentorship and coaching opportunities
- Exposure to C-Suite level business problems at a young age
- Great exit opportunities
cons:
- Work/life balance (not just the hours, but also the unpredictability)
- Up or out culture can be stressful and overly "doom and gloom"

headline: Engaging work, great career path
pros: I've been working at Bain for just over five years now (excluding breaks for school)  - consistently challenging and interesting, high quality work, high investment in the people
cons: This job is only rarely a 9 to 5 kind of thing. There's a decent amount of travel (though much less than many competitors) and some unpredictable spikes, as in any client services business

headline: Drinking knowledge from a water hose
pros:
I started working at Bain after college. I can't imagine a better place to develop myself the first few years after college. The quality of talent pushes me to a level of excellence I rarely find my friends in other companies being held to, the level of investment others have given me has been unexpected from a personal and professional level, and the work I am given is challenging but helps me grow further. 

I don't know many places where my supervisor and managers make it priority to give me feedback weekly and if an unplanned event (client meeting) occurs, still honor that commitment to personal growth if it means staying at the office at 9 pm with dinner.
cons: You are constantly on that once you're "off" you feel the burn from all the work. Long hours are not uncommon. This is the trade off you make when you work at Bain. You grow and learn, but it comes at the price of being "on" longer than at other places.

headline: Great Place to Work
pros: Bain has an incredibly supportive, fun, and collaborative culture that permeates every office and region.  You're given a lot of responsibility early and are set up for successful client impact at an early stage in your career.  There is a strong mentorship culture, a lot of learning, and the opportunity to interact with a diverse and high-profile group of clients on meaningful work.
cons: Must be able to adapt to a fast-paced work environment.

headline: Excellent culture and business education
pros:
-Fantastic culture, people are ridiculously capable but we also hire for coachability, humility, team skills so I have had almost universally positive team experiences in my 3 years here
-Interesting and important problems - we are a significant investment for our clients so they typically only bring us in for issues that are critical to their success
-Opportunity - you will get unrelenting inbound interest from recruiters simply by having a Bain email address,
cons: Bainies are committed to excellence and we work on hard problems, so it can be hard to shut it off sometimes. Balance is the primary issue you will wrestle with if you come here.

headline: Great Place to Work
pros: Great pay, lots of benefits, fun culture, overall a great experience
cons: Very clear distinction between homegrown and laterally hired employees.

headline: Manager Assistant
pros: High performing culture with lots of training
cons: High demand for management and unsustainable at times

headline: Consultant
pros:
Supportive culture, focused on people's development
Meritocratic
Lots of learning
Fun job (have fun while working)
Great benefits
Great salary
cons: Lots of travelling, hard to control schedule

headline: Awesome place to start a career
pros: The culture at Bain is truly unrivaled - I've been working here for over four years now, and am constantly impressed by the intelligence, support, and character of every new teammate I work. with.
cons: As with all management consulting, hours and travel can at times be a challenge for balancing life outside of work.

headline: Supportive of multiple career paths
pros:
Partner track isn't for everyone and Bain recognizes that.  They have great career support teams to help consultants across all levels navigate their careers outside of Bain to make sure that Bain alumni land well post-Bain.  For those that want to stay with Bain long term, there are also lots of options to consider whether it's internally facing leadership roles, externships, temporary office transfers, etc.  There is no one size fits all employee at Bain. 

Low on politics.  Great people.
cons: Some find the hors to be long and the travel schedule depending on where your clients are can be challenging.

headline: Best people, best place to work
pros: Awesome work with best friends - smart, down-to-earth, fun, humble teams
cons: Some projects less interesting than others

headline: Best place to start your career
pros:
- Culture: Bain has an extremely supportive culture. Formal training opportunities and mentor assignments complement the natural mentoring and training that occur on the job.
- Impact: From day one, I was helping clients solve some of their toughest problems. I was given a work stream that directly contributed to the answer our team provided to the client.
- Way of working: Bain is extremely collaborative. We work together and with our clients. 
- Career development: Bain has amazing systems for giving feedback and offering opportunities to improve in development areas.
cons:
- Long hours in client services
- Travel depending on the client

headline: The best place to start a business career
pros: Incredibly supportive and collaborative culture. Ridiculously motivated people, yet somehow, no sharp elbows. Truly care about their people and their clients.
cons: Top tier consulting jobs will always be demanding careers

headline: A firm that genuinely cares about my career path - at Bain and beyond
pros: Bainies are an incredibly supportive group of people (right up to the most senior leaders at the firm) who genuinely care about me professionally and personally, and who demonstrate a real investment in my career at Bain and beyond
cons: Bainies don't always stay for life - so when they leave, I'm sad to see friends go... but they go on to pretty great roles (so it's nice to have friends in high places!)

headline: Start your career at Bain & Company!
pros: People here care about your development, as a professional and as a person
cons: There's a lot of work to be done; managing your time can be challenging

headline: Best company I've ever worked for
pros:
-Amazing company culture - people are down to earth and the company is incredibly supportive of employees
-Smartest people - the people who work here are incredible; you never have to worry about being the smartest person in the room...
-High impact work - you are truly transforming global companies, and people from age 22 on up have exposure to and are influencing the C-suite
cons: -The job, not the company, is hard; hours can be long - but the work is incredibly rewarding; it's less a con of Bain and more just something you sign up for in a high impact job

headline: Supportive culture and results for our clients
pros: Working at a place where we collaborate with our clients to get them the best results; working with teams that are second to none - the smartest and most supportive people in the industry. Bain is committed to getting the right results for our clients while making sure our people receive the best opportunities and mentoring from those around them.
cons: Hard to identify a con for the company - while we work hard, we are still focused on making it a long term sustainable career for everyone.

headline: best business job out there
pros: this is just the best business job out there - you get to engage with really high level business problems, with very senior and impressive executives, in an environment that is incredibly supportive of your learning as an individual.  I can't say enough positive about it - it's really just the right combination of type of work and quality of peers and supporters...
cons: we do work a lot!

headline: Amazing company
pros: Incredible learning opportunities in a true apprenticeship model. Building a track record of tangible results. Get inspired by clients and teams that want to make a difference.
cons: The job can include some travel. There is always more to do, so need to set strict boundaries.

headline: Great place to build a well-rounded business career
pros:
-Excellent mentorship and multiple layers of professional development (trainings, learning from peers, learning on the job, frequent and consistent feedback)
-Good combination of hard skills (modeling, data analytics) and soft skills (communication, upward management, team leadership, change management)
-Exposure to broad set of business challenges and industries
-Great benefits including generous parental leave
cons:
-Variable experiences based on the project (working hours, travel required, client expectations have meaningful variance project to project)
-Significant time requirements for activities outside of "core" work (training, recruiting, culture-building)

headline: Great way to have an impact on global business
pros: "Global team of people all passionate about making  a difference in the businessworld" is how i'd summarize Bain.  Doing great work as part of a team of people that are all trying ot help each other thrive is really special.
cons: It can be intimidating being around people that are all so smart and driven, especially if you're used to being a big fish in your previous pond

headline: Amazing career, high impact work with top investors and management teams
pros: High impact work, great breadth of opportunity as well as depth in key verticals (e.g. private equity, healthcare, retail). Coaching./mentoring and career progress has exceeded all expectations
cons: Up or out culture (but supports high performance)

headline: Amazing long-term career
pros:
- Interesting, challenging, meaningful work
- Significant opportunities for global experience, including 6+ month transfers to other offices
- Supportive colleagues and mentors who are actually invested in your professional and personal development
cons: - Cannot specialize very early in career

headline: Work on the Toughest Problems and Never Stop Learning
pros:
Bain is an incredible place to build a career. You get to work on the most interesting problems in the world of business, the challenge never stops ramping up. I've been there 12 years, and I'm still learning new skills every day. The project-based nature of the work is great because it gives a lot of variety both in whom you work with and what types of problems you get to solve.

Work/life balance is quite good. I have tons of flexibility about when and where I work.
cons:
Travel can be tough although in my personal experience I've only had one case that involved 4-day a week travel.

The hours can be hard at times although there is a lot of flexibility once you become a team leader.

headline: Great learning, great people, great impact
pros:
Bain has all the qualities of a top tier consulting firm - crazy smart people, big important clients, great exit opportunities, good compensation. These things are a given, so I will focus on what makes Bain different from the pack:

- Professional development: Laser focused on junior employees' learning from Day 1. Culture of coaching and mentoring is reinforced through longstanding processes and traditions - it is a part of everything Bain does. As a junior employee you feel invested in.

 - Nice people: As simple as it sounds - the people here are genuinely kind, positive and helpful people. Bain hires for smarts and fit... and fit is important. This makes for a very collegial, non-competitive work environment and culture

- Results focus: Bain tries not to be the firm where a bunch of smart people gather data, develop a recommendation, deliver a killer presentation, collect fees and walk away. In most cases we partner with our clients not only to devise a strategy but also to implement a strategy.
cons:
The consulting cons: hours, travel, etc.

Relative to other firms, the promotion schedule is rigid. Top performers are not promoted much faster than average performers

headline: Great place to start a career

headline: Executive Assistant

cons: EA's are an after-thought, even though they keep this place running. Environment can also sometimes be annoying since there are so many young, intelligent people trying to be the next to get ahead. EAs are extremely busy with no thought to balancing desks and the work an EA is being given.

headline: This place has serious work culture issues!
pros:
- Projects are very impactful. And interesting.

- People are smart with a high IQ (but not EQ).

Thats about it.
cons:
- Culture in Dubai is miles short of what is advertised in US offices. Many people are neither helpful, nor supportive nor down-to-earth. Although there are always exceptions.

- Several people here have inflated egos. Comes packaged with the smartness I guess.

- Crazy work hours for consultants. Its not just bad, its crazy.

- Build relationships with colleagues? Barely - since they are as crunched for time as you are.

- “Work hard, play hard” is basically “Just work hard”.

Serious advice - consulting experience varies a lot from office to office. Avoid the Dubai office.

headline: Wins Best Place to Work for Good Reasons
pros: I'm not sure if I can add anything to what's been written by others except to say it is all true.  You're constantly surrounded by super smart people who are also super friendly.  There's just no comparison to the experience at Bain.  The work challenges you to develop faster than you've ever thought possible.  The people you work with become lifelong friends.  You have a never ending stream of amazing story-worthy experiences.  The compensation is generous and fair (granted it isn't stratospheric like some finance/PE comp, but let's be real here--this is still one of the fastest most reliable paths in the world to the "1%").  And if and when you decide to leave, the door to opportunities swings wide open to everything from traditional corporate and operating positions to entrepreneurship (one of our former associates got the highest ever investment subscription on Shark Tank for his new venture!).  Finally as an alum, you have an open invitation to come back which is a huge safety net particularly if you're thinking about starting a company or doing something that could be risky.  This is absolutely positively the best place in the world to start your business career.
cons: Travel is probably the biggest downside--true with any consulting job.  But!  Invest early in establishing your network of internal promoters, and there are lots of ways to manage your travel demands.  The geographical model of staffing at Bain really makes it much easier to do this than other industry-based staffing models.  There are also some offices where the industry cluster naturally creates lots of local case opportunities.  And if you stay at Bain for a while and progress in career (and life) and things like new babies, medical issues, etc., come up that require a period of greater accommodation, Bain is amazing for coming up with ways to help match the rhythm of life (e.g., local IP development case for a few months, temporary or permanent rotation to a practice area role, staffing on a local client, etc.).

headline: The best of management consulting with the nicest people in the industry
pros: Bain is a great place to get all of the benefits of a career in management consulting - including lots of learning and doors opened to amazing future career opportunities - while working with some of the nicest people in the industry. Pretty much all of my colleagues had cross-offers with other firms, with more or less identical pay/benefits packages and doing more or less the same work for the same clients, and the people who chose Bain were generally the ones who cared more about working with people they liked than prestige or resume-building. pros: Professional development is great- most managers will dedicate time to ensure you're successful- always work on interesting, and important projects for top businesses

headline: Best place to start your career
pros:
I can't think of a better place to start your career--amazing learning opportunities, extreme focus on professional development, interesting/important problems to solve, and great people.  
Staffing model is designed to ensure that you get a range of experiences to develop a well-rounded skillset, preparing you to advance to the next level (a general manager skillset is very transferable to many jobs outside of consulting).
cons:
You will work hard in exchange for those professional development opportunities and interesting problems--that's the deal you make.  As a more junior consultant you have less control over your schedule, but that increases significantly as you gain tenure.
If you know that you only want to work in a very specific area from the beginning of your career, the model is not designed to accommodate that (and it wouldn't be in your best interest to do so, from a skill development perspective). You are allowed (and expected) to specialize, however, as a manager.
From a long-term perspective, the job changes significantly several times over the course of your career--the best consultants are not necessarily the best managers are not necessarily the best partners, but you must play every role along the way.

pros: Bain is a terrific place to grow fast and get significant business experience at the beginning of your career. Company culture is great, people really have fun and there's a fantastic office environment. Y

headline: Great place to work due to supportive environment
pros:
Being a consulting firm, Bain knows that their only assets are their people, so they invest incredible amounts to grow and support their employees.  This is done in numerous ways:
-Training: Every year or two, you attend a global training for 5-10 days with everyone from around the globe of your tenure.  These are both fun and hugely informative/helpful to development.  They also create a global network, so that you quickly know people from several other offices
-Mentorship: Bain will assign you mentors of differing levels, but the most important (and impressive) aspect of mentorship are the un-official mentors.  Within 6-12 months you have a strong network of people you have done cases, worked on recruiting, or generally interacted with who all are willing to take time out of a busy schedule to grab coffee and chat about anything that may be concerning you regarding the job.
Overall culture: Bain is a shockingly fun place to work.  Some work events (such as the holiday party and offsite) are some of my favorite social events that I look forward to each year.  Several of my co-workers have also become some of my best friends over the past few years.  The company understands that happy customers stick around longer, and they invest a lot of time (and money) to keep people happy
cons:
Most of my complaints/concerns are related to the consulting industry overall.  I think Bain does a better job of promoting work-life balance and limiting travel than other major firms (and I know many people at all of them), but the hours can still be long and tiring, and more importantly are very unpredictable as we are often responding to client requests.
The one thing I think is more of an issue at Bain than other consulting firms has to do with the types of cases.  I've been at Bain for several years and have seen a marked shift towards longer engagements.  The norm now seems to be for people to be on the same case for 6-9 months.  One of the appeals of consulting is to work in lots of industries on lots of problems, and this is greatly diminished if you only do 3 cases every 2 years.

headline: The Best Place to Work
pros: Do you like a challenge? Do you like making an impact? Do you like being surrounded by the best and brightest every day? I do -- and that's why I chose to work at Bain & Company. We're a dedicated group of problem solvers who strive to make a difference to our clients. We help C-suite executives solve their toughest problems, problems that are so challenging they realize they can't handle them alone. Sounds tough? It is -- but at Bain, you're never alone. There's an intensive support system in place to set you up for success and ensure that we deliver a great result for our clients. These people are hand selected from the top schools across the world to be not only smart and ambitious, but also collegial and fun. They're not just your colleagues, they're your friends. They're the people who will both stay up late with you trying to crack the case and also stand beside you at the alter on your wedding day. Bainies are a truly unique bunch, and there is no company in the world quite like Bain. Between the work we do and the people we do it with, we've truly developed the BEST place to work.
cons: There is no such thing as a routine at Bain. There's no repeating the process and over and over so that you become quick at doing a single task. At Bain, your challenged to stretch yourself. To be a better version of you than you thought possible. The bar is continuously raised, and it's certainly tough to continue to meet the expectations. That said, a Bainie never lets another Bainie fail -- so if you want to get there, if you want to continue to the next level at Bain, you can through the support of your peers.
