headline: Welcome to Bain
pros: Welcome to Bain.  I'm going to give you a problem that neither the CEO nor his entire management team could solve.  And I'm probably going to give you lots of different opinions and imperfect data sources.  And then I'll ask you to focus in on where the most value is and convince all those people with different opinions that you're right.  But don't worry, I'm also going to give you a Bain team.  Those associates and consultants are going to be tenacious in coming up with creative approaches.  Those managers and partners are going to knock down barriers for you, connect you where you need to be connected, guide, support, direct and re-direct you.  The office support staff is going to fix your computer after you spilled coffee on it for the third time, find you the unfindable data source, and smile and hand you a baked good after you ask for help re-doing dozens of slides.  You are empowered and accountable but you are not alone.  And the best part is you can't fail.  Because after all, what all those people are reinforcing is that a Bainie never lets another Bainie fail.
cons: Here's how you know you've made it at Bain.  The reward for doing a good job is getting a bigger, tougher problem next time.  Meaning, you are always solving the easiest problem you will ever solve again.  This takes a lot of resilience and active managing of self-expectations to remember that you are not actually getting worse, the problems are just getting harder.  So my advice is to remember that.  And then take a second to realize that it would be a lot less fun if the reverse were true.  And isn't that precisely why you wanted this job in the first place anyway? It sure was for me.

headline: Bain is a great place to work with fantastic people and learn how to approach many business challenges
pros: Bain is a fantastic place to work. You learn a ton and work on great challenges with clients. It is a team oriented environment, full of intelligent but humble people. It is a pleasure working here.
cons: The work requires you to work hard. This is not unique to Bain, which is thoughtful about work/life balance, but a broader challenge with this professional service industry.

headline: Bain & Company - the greatest place to work!
pros:
Bain is an incredible place to work for many reasons.  A few of the highlights as follows:

+ The best training for any career aspirations, both through formal global trainings, as well as our unique apprenticeship culture
+ Incredible rewards, both financial and otherwise (including recognition, Bain World Cup, benefits, etc.)
+ Great people - the most talented, interesting, and yet grounded individuals I could ever hope to work with
cons: We work hard to make sure that our clients achieve the best results possible.

headline: Great place to start. Only the fittest survive
pros: Great exposure to multiple industries. Constant focus on your professional growth and development. Working in extraordinary teams on projects with high impact helps justify the long hours
cons: The hours are long, especially when you are working for Private Equity clients. The attrition rate, though lower than BCG or McKinsey, is still high- and goes to show the nature of the consulting industry

headline: Excellent environment for top-tier consulting
pros:
-Top-tier consulting, working with CEOs and their direct reports on the biggest issues facing their companies
-High impact worki that will move the needle with clients
-Excellent people: Smart, hard working, real and humble... they like the work they do, are passionnate about their clients but also care about things outside of work
-Lots of infrastructure in place to maintain work/life balance and make this work in the long run
cons:
-Some travel requirements
-Consulting has it's moments...

headline: Assosiate Consultant
pros:
There is no better place to start your career than with Bain. Beyond the traditional multi-industry, multi-functional exposure management consulting offers, Bain has a strong mentorship culture in which everyone from the top down takes an active role in professional development. Coaching is more of an ongoing weekly conversation than a quarterly review. At any given point you have a team of people heavily invested in seeing you develop through your Bain experience and not only accessible to you, but eager to assist in any way they can. 

The mentorship culture and emphasis on constant learning and development is undoubtedly one of the reasons Bain is able to deliver strong results for clients. Teams are invested in each other and thus are able to produce extraordinary work that helps clients solve their most daunting problems. If you are walking through the halls of a client and pass a Bain team you will see a group of people who genuinely enjoy working together. At Bain you can learn a lot, be a part of developing innovative solutions for clients and have a lot of fun doing it.
cons: At times, the lifestyle assosiated with consulting can be challenging. Bain encourages people to figure out how to make the job sustainable for them- it takes a little time to figure out what makes sense for you but there are a lot of great people who set an example of how to make it for the long run and manage work life balance.

headline: Not recommend
pros: You learn a lot and the pay is above local average. Colleagues are usually smart and nice.
cons: You work alot and your supervisor are not always friendly nor interested in your progression

headline: Good place to work
pros: Lots of opportunities, large variety of projects, senior exposure, interesting people, great culture
cons: Long hours, as new consultant highly directive but get more ownership over time

headline: Bain review
pros:
Clients trust Bain with their most difficult problems and everyone is committed to finding the best possible solutions to those problems. We work in close collaboration with our clients to ensure that we develop realistic, actionable ideas to drive results. 

It's also an extremely supportive and collaborative place to work. Everyone is willing to provide help, advice, coaching, etc. and I've always felt like I had people in my corner that want to help me succeed.
cons: To make Bain an even better place to work, I would like to see the opportunities for internal roles to continue to grow. There are periods in my life where a client facing role has been less than ideal and there are some opporunties to remain more internally focused but increasing this would provide more opportunities to me within Bain.

headline: BEST place to work
pros: I've been at Bain since 2008 and the things that attracted me to the firm in the first place are just as relevant and exciting today as they were when I was fresh out of college: the learning, career acceleration, my amazing friends, teammates and mentors, and the privilege it is to work with our clients on their most important issues and achieve great results together.  I have a seat at the table with leaders on key decisions I couldn't hope to be a part of until much later in my career if I worked in industry.
cons: Lifestyle is not great.  Supervisors and teams are incredibly supportive of one another to try to achieve balance, but the fact is we are in client services and our clients are owed amazing service for the fees they pay.  While I have found the travel to be quite manageable with our local staffing model, the hours can be tough.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Incredible people, high impact work, supportive culture, focus on both professional and personal development, commitment to making a difference in the community
cons: Travel, long hours, lack of flexibility

headline: Great first job
pros: Incredibly supportive culture; engaged and inspiring mentors; impressive opportunities for ownership and supervisory roles very early in your career
cons: Work life balance is okay, but not could be improved

headline: Unrivaled
pros: Top notch challenges working with some of the world's most impressive companies and leaders.  Amazing place to learn.  Wonderful culture.
cons: Lifestyle can be challenging at times, both travel and high stress, though I get the impression both are less than at our two primary competitors.

headline: Bain Chicago - Amazing place to work
pros:
-Collaborative and supportive culture
-Focus on client outcomes and results
-Opportunity to work on clients most critical issues
-Opportunity to work with an energetic, fun group of people
-Great exit options
-Global training
cons:
-Hours can be unpredictable and highly variable
-Travel can be taxing
-The work is not always as "sexy" as it's made out to be

headline: An incredible, challenging and fun experience
pros: Wide variety of types of work - whenever I get comfortable with one type of analysis, client or industry, I find that things change to challenge me again, and rapid career progression as well. I've worked here about 4 years now full-time (started post-undergrad) and have been constantly challenged and had my responsibilities broadened while making an impact and having a fantastic time with great people.
cons: This job is challenging - it requires a significant portion of your brain power and your time every week. It provides a huge amount of satidfaction, but does have significant work/life balance tradeoffs

headline: Great platform
pros: Amazing learning experience, very supportive culture, great training and focus on developing their teams
cons: You have to work hard, but that's just the nature of the job..

headline: High-impact work, most supportive culture
pros:
Ability to make an impact across a broad range of clients, industries and capabilities
Home-office model that fosters connectivity with peers and mentors
Staffing designed to develop and grow each individual consultant
cons:
Work/life balance can be difficult 
Average case length

headline: High-impact work and a flexible career
pros:
Work on key issues for top excutives, Bain's strength in Private Equity gets you behind one of the bbigest deals that you see in the newspaper.  Awesome people to work with and fast career development.  

Biggest plus for me lately has been the ability to shape my work-life balance as a new father.  I've been able to craft full-time, exciting roles that minimize travel and get me home more often with my wife and child.
cons: Work can be unpredicatable and you need to be able to be flexible to be successful.  This does mean some late nights, but typically just means that you can't be rigid in your work and personal schedules.

headline: Can't imagine a better company to work for!!!
pros: Bain provides an unmatched opportunity to work with the world's top business leaders, while solving the most complex business problems and making true and significant impact.  At the same time, you get to work beside some of the smartest and down-to-earth people you'll find.  I really can't imagine a better place to start a career (or spend an entire career, for that matter)
cons: Consulting in general is a demanding career choice.  While I think Bain does an excellent job of helping employees maintain a good work/life balance, consulting can require long hours at times.  For me, this has been more than offset by the development I've achieved, but it's still a reality of the job.

headline: Fantastic place to work
pros: Joining Bain was an inflection point in my career. The on the job training I've recieved at Bain will stick with me for a lifetime. The mentors I've had at Bain have been invaluable. My teams have helped our clients solve extremely challanging problems... which has been very rewarding. I've loved working at Bain and I am very appreciative of all I have learned here.
cons: It is a demanding place to work - you'll be pushed!

headline: 2 thumbs up
pros:
Results driven focus
Great, highly engaging people
Market leader in Private Equity strategic due diligences
High leadership focus on coaching and developing talent (incl. employees about to leave the firm)
cons: The usual consulting-related pain-points: travel (albeit alleviated by an office-centric staffing culture), and hours that are often outside of one's own control

headline: It is as great as they say.
pros:
- Amazing corhort of colleagues you'll be excited to be around every day.
- Solving extremely interesting problems.
- Really positive, supportive culture focused on your development.
- Devotion throughout the organization to making Bain a fun place to work.
cons: - Being responsive to client needs can occasionally create taxing or inflexible work requirements. Bain generally does a good job mitigating, but that's the nature of client services.

headline: The place for the most impactful work
pros:
- Tremendous client impact and focus on value
- Challenging and diverse cases 
- Amazing exit opportunities
- Brand and prestige
- Extremely smart and humble peers
- Unique culture
cons:
- Need a better time and expense management software
- Travel can be tough depending on the case

headline: Great place to start your career
pros: I couldn't imagine a better place to start a career than at Bain.  The supportive culture, the mentorship (both formal and informal) and the learning opportunities are unmatched.  I started my career in a very different place (investment banking) and I'm always amazed and so proud when I see the investment we make in developing our people.  Bain feels like a family that wants the best for you and once you're a Bainie, you're a Bainie for life.  I love the people I work with, the clients I serve and the problems I've gotten to tackle.
cons: This is a challenging job and that does come with some stress; it's not the right fit for everyone.

headline: Review from a manager at Bain
pros: Challenging work, supportive culture, focus on development, fun!
cons: It can be a tough job, but can't cite any specific cons about Bain - amazing firm and grateful for the career I've started there

headline: Best launch pad out there
pros:
Excellent people
Home office staffing model far superior to competitors: able to quickly build a very strong professional network 
Solving clients most important problems 
Incredibly steep learning curve 
Excellent exit opportunities and very strong alumni network
cons:
Can be fast paced and high pressure - no 40 hour work weeks here
Despite model, travel can be onerous at times
Feedback oriented culture might not be best for everyone

headline: Amazing place to launch a career
pros:
I can't think of a better place to launch a career whether it is out of undergrad or business school. The sheer number and range of opportunities you receive through Bain to see various industries and verticals is hard to match elsewhere. This results in you learning so much from work that you do with major corporate clients that ultimately has a really meaningful impact for them.

Beyond the work opportunities, it's really the community of people at Bain that sets it apart from other workplaces. The people are not only smart but truly care about those around them. This manifests in great mentoring at every level of the organization and support from everyone around you so that you are set up for success.
cons: Some travel required based on case - but plenty of local opportunities as well during my experience in the Bay Area.

headline: Manager
pros: Bain is a truly unique company, starting with a positive and supportive culture. This results in high-gain and enjoyable teamwork, with differentiating results. The projects are focused on high-impact work at the clients, and the collaborative approach results in
cons: The work can be intense, which shouldn't be a surprise given the high stakes of the projects. Bain does however truly emphasize sustainability compared to other consulting firms.

headline: Senior Consultant
pros: Big, Industry Changing Projects and Impact; Supportive Culture; Local Staffing; Top Tier Clients; Leading Compensation
cons: Long hours, limited travel opportunities, and limited ability to specialize and choose an industry/capability focus

headline: Bain & Company
pros: Some of the smartest people I'll ever work with. Constantly challenged at the job and I learn every day.
cons: Need to protect work life balance

headline: Best place to start a career in business
pros: I enjoy working with highly intelligent people on interesting & important business problems. I've learned a TON - came out of undergrad with an engineering degree, and working at Bain has set me up for success in the business world.
cons: Consistent travel has the potential to create a poor work-life balance. I've found opportunities to travel less and work from my home city, which helps sustainability.

headline: Best place to develop
pros: Bain is absolutely top-notch when it comes to developing people.  The culture is incredibly supportive and people truly want to see you succeed.  They do that by giving you honest feedback and supporting you throughout your career.  When I started at Bain five years ago, I thought I would stay in consulting for about two years.  But the supportive environment and the fact that I continue to learn and challenge myself every day has made me stay.
cons: We definitely work hard at Bain to meet the needs of our clients.  That being said, I love my teams and they make the longer days fun and energizing.  The management team also goes out of their way to try to find ways to make the job as sustainable as possible.

headline: Bain is the best job for aspiring general managers
pros: Bain is a fantastic place to start your career.  I joined many years ago as an Associate Consultant.  The steep learning curve, opportunity to have impact at my clients and supportive culture have all contributed to me staying at the firm for nearly 30 years.  I spent 15 years in client facing roles and almost as long in internal roles focused on talent management.  Bain has really delivered on its value proposition in my case.
cons: Consulting is a hard job - the problems we are trying to solve are very complex, clients have high expectations and colleagues are really smart.  To not only succeed but to thrive in this environment it is critical to have sufficient support and engagement from leaders.  Bain's culture does an awesome job in providing that supportive culture to help individuals thrive.

headline: Bain: The best place to start a career
pros:
I've worked here for over 10 years, and I still learn something new every day about how to be a better analyst, leader, adviser, mentor, presenter, etc. 

I get excited about going to work every day - the work we do has a real impact on our clients' business - we are definitely solving their most important problems
cons: Travel can be a challenge although it can also be fun to spend time going out with the team in a new city and to work closely with clients.

headline: Proud to be a Bainee
pros: Great company that encourages learning, growth, and career development. Absolute pleasure to be a part of this organization and it's amazing culture.
cons: Can't think of any at the moment!

headline: Great place to work!
pros:
The culture and people at Bain are top notch. You're surrounded by top talent, which makes you want to rise to the occasion each day. Supervisors, mentors, peers - everyone takes a vested interest in your career and you as a person. 

The benefits are phenomenal. Both the medical/dental/401(k), as well as the general every day perks (cereal/fruit, company outings, growth opportunities, etc.)

Bain truly cares about their community and gives back in a varity of ways - pro-bono work, charity auctions, food drives, volunteering, etc. 

I work on the Adminstrative side and I have no issue finding work/life balance. I know my personal time is valued.
cons: In my 5+ years here I have yet to find a con worth noting.

headline: Incredible Company & Unparalleled Support
pros: Since Day 1, Bain has offered me continuous support in learning my first role with them and still provides mentoring for my professional and personal goals via Bain's leadership team and colleagues. By investing in each individual employee - we are able to succeed in providing our clients the best results and contribute to their goals as well. The unique culture this company offers allows us to make a positive impact in the community on a local and global scale through outreach programs. This has been a fantastic place to start my career and I don't plan on going anywhere else.
cons: None! Bain really takes care of its people.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Bain & Company is a great place at which to work. Interesting projects where we work closely with clients to solve their toughest issues. Very supportive culture and fantastic teams. All around great post-business school experience.
cons: Must be ok working within the generalist model initially out of business school (I think it's a great experience)

headline: Incredible place to make a career
pros:
When I joined Bain, I thought I'd stay for 18 months or 2 years... but it's been 13 years now!  There are so many things that have kept me excited to be a part of this firm: 
1) Learning opportunities - Whenever I feel like I've plateaued or been bored, the next challenge has come along - in the form of new skills to develop, new stakeholders to work with, new responsibilities to manage.  
2) Flexibility and career progression - There are so many opportunities to progress.  And so many flex options, including the ability to work part time, which was important to me after my youngest child was born.  
3) Really smart, fun, accomplished and humble people - The environment in the office is definitely collegial.  What's really special, though, is getting to know individuals and their interests and experiences and accomplishments outside of Bain, too.  Often those opportunities to get to know people are serendipitous (e.g., a delayed flight together; working on a committee of some sort, singing in the Bain band, etc.).  I'm continually amazed by the talent that I have the good fortune to work with.
cons: People do work hard, and there's often a fair amount of unpredictability in schedule.  Depending on your role, travel can be a challenge.  Both of these are really the nature of professional services

headline: Great place to start a career and drive it forward
pros: Fast-paced, challenging enviornment with collobrative support
cons: Intensive hours and travel

headline: Associate Consultant
pros: Very strong brand for business and strategic training
cons: Work-life balance can be difficult to maintain

headline: MBB consulting
pros: resume booster and good pay
cons: work will sometimes not be glamorous (tedious, non-thought-provoking work)

headline: Fantastic place to work!
pros: I believe there isn't a Firm that has a better culture than Bain.  The people here truly make it fun to come to work every day.  Our leadership is talented and inspiring and are commited to the  professional development, growth, and career advancement for all employees. The benefits and perks are top notch as well!
cons: The hours can be long sometimes not nearly as other firms in the industry.

headline: Good place to start a career
pros: You gain exposure to different aspects of business and different industries.  It's a great place for people early in their careers to learn how to solve problems .  You're surrounded by top notch colleagues, who also tend to be very pleasant to work with as well as being intelligent and motivated.
cons: You've got limited control over the types of projects you work on, so you can end up doing work you aren't interested in.  Not sure consulting (in general, not just Bain) is the 'career accelerator' it used to be.  Certainly not for tech and start ups, who seem to look for people with experience 'doing', which you don't get much of in consulting.  There's a period in the middle of your time in consulting that doesn't add much to your attractiveness to other firms; so do it for either up to 2 years, or stay for 5-6+.

headline: Supportive leadership; many paths within the firm
pros: At every major promotion point, there has been a senior leader who has invested heavily in my success. It made all the difference to have a senior coach on my side who know when to push and when to support and listen. I've also found that as you stay beyond 2-3 years, the firm's leadership bends over backwards to make the job work. They created a new program for me to trial a new capability area, gave me a 3 month leave of absence to travel, and transferred me across offices as my personal and professional goals have evolved.
cons: The arc of a Bain career is not smooth and straight. There are considerable ups and downs, and learning at the pace required can be stressful. To be successful long term at Bain, it's important to manage through difficult case stretches as I've found there's always an immensely rewarding experience around the next corner.

headline: Best place to work
pros: Always challenged, important problems, great people
cons: Need to figure out how to make work-life balance work on an individual basis. Once you figure it out, it can be sustainable.

headline: Executive Assistant
pros:
Inspiring
Great Benefits
Culture
Work and life balance
Management 
Continuing Education
cons: In my opinion, no cons at this time

headline: Best business career
pros: Turbocharges your career.  Lots of mentorship... the value of office-centric professional development while still getting a global career!  Amazing global case opportunities.
cons: Consulting is a fast paced career, so make sure that's what you want.

headline: Best consultancy to work for
pros: work life balance, work hard party harder, team outings, good pay, actually very good pay, nice mates, office infrastructure is really nice
cons: no cafetaria inside office, very mechanical work, no exiting projects, off shore group has capability to bore anyone within months, cannot learn anything else ppts

headline: Fantastic work
pros: Hands down the best reason to work at Bain is the impact of the work that you get to do. While at Bain I've had the opportunity to work on transformational projects that have changed how clients - most of whom are names you would recognize - approach their own business, their customers, their employees, etc.
cons: The biggest con of working at Bain & Company is that I'm still trying to figure out how to explain to those "not in the know" what, exactly, it is that I do.

headline: Build & laucnh your career at Bain
pros: Results-oriented culture, incredible mentoring and support, flexible career options. And fun!
cons: Client services is always fundamentally challenging and comes with some lack of control, but Bain does a great job helping to make tradeoffs with our clients in order to balance work-life tradeoffs. Doesn't work 100% of the time, but it's awesome that the conversation happens regularly.

headline: Manager
pros: Great place to learn analytical, negotiation, communication skills. Will have lots of job opportunity if you are successful in the company.  Very nice colleagues and team work culture.
cons: Always very busy. Sometimes receive lots of pressure from boss and clients. Frequent travels. You may not be able to support clients until they realize results.

headline: Great short term career move
pros:
-Global training programes
-Smart, fun outgoing colleagues
-Really interesting work (most of the time)
cons:
- High level of "intenseness" can feel like you are drinking from a waterhose in the first months
- Need to learn the right way of doing things very early on
- Extremely long hours at times (say goodbye to weekday socialising)

headline: Amazing culture and people, but work leaves something to be desired
pros: The culture and people at Bain are second to none. All the firms will say this during recruiting, but after observing how junior employees interact at the top firms through various friend groups, it's evident the people at Bain enjoy each other's company more so than elsewhere. Even more impressive is how consistent the culture is globally, as seen at global training and Bain World Cup. People tend to be incredibly fun, approachable, and humble. Strongly recommend as a first job out of college.
cons:
Unfortunately, while the people are amazing, the work is far from that. The hours can be long, but not horrible like banking. That said, it is generally unpredictable and there can be extreme periods leading up to key deadlines. It is also hard to make plans with confidence during the work week. 

The greater issue is that for a junior employee, the work is menial. There is a strong mismatch in terms of the qualifications of the ACs and the work they're asked to do, in that ACs are certainly capable of more. The work might be challenging initially, but once the approach is figured out, it becomes a matter of repetition and grinding. The learning curve begins to plateau around the 1 year mark. Many late nights will be spent on grunt work, administrative burdens, and tasks which will be asked to be re-done multiple times. There is generally a lack of ownership in that ACs do not get to define their own work, it's more so coming down from the top. You do not spend much time "problem solving", which is probably what draws people to the job. Clients are big companies, often oligopolistic, usually trying to defend their turf, so there is not much innovative thinking behind the "answer", and more so identifying best practices and optimizations.

headline: A Thriving Culture is the Key to Success!
pros: Wonderful people! Multiple resources to become successful. Excellent mentor program and high promotors!
cons: I haven't  found any yet..... But who's looking?

headline: Great place to work
pros: Company culture is great. They truly care about their employees.
cons: Hours can occasionally be long.

headline: Great company to work for
pros:
This is a great company to work for--the leadership team really understands that employees are a critical asset.   So they put a lot of emphasis on making sure people are learning, enjoying their jobs and are well compensated.
I also appreciate the external focus--the "heroes" are people who create success with clients.   So you just don't see internal politics.   We are all too busy helping our clients succeed.
cons: As with any top consulting company,  the lifestyle can be challenging.      Figure out what is most important to you (ie,  getting to the gym,  not working on the weekend) and be willing to make tradeoffs.    Most supervisors are very open to that discussion.

headline: Great culture and career progression; poor lifestyle
pros:
- Excellent culture relative to other ther consulting firms with very smart people
- High degree of learning
- Clear career progression with incentives for high performers
cons:
- Long hours
- Unpredictable schedule and workload
- Client services can be painful in general

headline: The best!
pros: Strong company with lots of flexibility, particularly for internal staff.  Benefits are amazing, everyone at the company is wicked smart.
cons: There are not very many negatives to working here.  Strong company with a great reputation.  The best and brightest in every way.

headline: Great Place to Work
pros: Bain is a wonderful place to work and it is mostly because of the people. Everyone is smart, driven, and caring with a focus on mentored learning. I am challenged by the work and I enjoy spending time with my case teams. I returned to Bain after business school and I would strongly encourage anyone interested in consulting to apply to the firm.
cons: As is the case with any management consulting firm, we work hard. That being said, my weekends are always protected and travel is limited to Monday-Thursday.

headline: Bain & Co
pros: Great culture, exciting work, challenging problems and great people. Impact on clients is real and you can really make a difference.
cons: A lot of travel can be taxing at times - clients are scattered around the country. Hours not too long but longer than industry.

headline: The ultimate place to start a career
pros: Incredibly intelligent people. Incredible benefits. World class industry leading clients.  Amazing training and learning opportunities.
cons: Sometimes hours can be long, however the learning is worth it.

headline: Energizing, exciting and supportive workplace
pros:
From day one, I got to do real, impactful work and my team trusted me and guided me along the way. The overall environment is fun and supporting and the office is very inclusive- of significant others as well. 
Senior management is very approachable and I can reach out and meet with anyone I want for coffee and have an open conversation about anything. 
In addition, the home-office staffing and the travel-as-needed model, were huge factors when I choose Bain over the other big three. It makes the work more sustainable and allows me to develop a true network within the office and balance my work/live better.
cons: Wish they had more international employees in the office.

headline: Bain & Company consultant
pros:
Steep learning curve
Opportunity to focus in specific industries
cons: Excessively high "training on the job" approach

headline: Great people, interesting work
pros: Smart bunch of people, great energy and fun atmosphere
cons: Work-life balance is a constant challenge

headline: Best company!
pros: Working at Bain provides you with challenging and interesting cases at the same time as offering the best culture for it.
cons: Consulting industry is a hard working one so achieving a good lifestyle is sometime tough.

headline: Deserves award for "Top Ten Best Place to work"
pros: Bain values it's people at all levels and uses it's team culture to add value for all of it's clients as well as all of it's employees.
cons: None come to mind - I would recommend Bain to  anyone looking for a great company to join

headline: One of the best consulting firm
pros: One of the most competitive members are working as a team together.
cons: As an Ac you cannot really choose the area of projects you wish for

Work/Life balance is non existent - work every night until late and weekends

No influence on staffing cycles and project choice

headline: Bain
pros: The best firm to work and learn, with a high speed career growth and opportunity to work in several industries
cons: The work is a little bit heavy sometimes, but it totally worth!

headline: Good Experience and Exposure, but Offer is Below Competitors

- Projects on interesting clients for Italian Business Environment
- Good exposure to clients also for ACs
- Strong culture and smart colleagues
cons:
- MBA sponsorship not guaranteed

- Poor Salary

headline: CSS is a great place to work
pros: I love working here! Terrific people doing smart and amazing work.
cons: I don't think there are any cons.

headline: Amazing place to start a career.
pros: Cool people, great compensation, solid learning experiences. Bain management is great at meeting your career advancement goals.
cons: Working at Bain as an associate means you'll probably be working pretty long hours. That said, those hours are spent collaborating with very smart and also fun/cool people. It's worth it.

headline: Typical consulting firm
pros:
Good brand name which can help the career and in finding good opportunities
Great people - most smart and highly motivated
cons:
Rigid structure - need to follow the development plan and career path laid out by the firm.
Also the skills required at all levels are different, so someone who is a great analyst will not make a  good manager!

headline: Good place to begin a career
pros: Interesting challenges and cases; smart colleagues; exposure to senior management (especially in smaller offices); goof office culture and an appreciation for people
cons: In the smaller offices, professional development is not the best as the structure is not well developed yet; Hours getting much longer compared to a year ago; career progression a bit slow in this office compared to bigger offices, leading to increased attrition rates

headline: Differences between offices
pros: Opens doors, overall you gain a great skill set (some experiences less valuable than others), typically great people
cons: As with any consulting job, limited control, difficult work situations, etc.  On average the people at Bain are great people.  This, however, varies by office.  Not all offices are at the same level.  Southern offices, for example, have less exciting work and less competent managers.

headline: Great
pros: Awesome work environment, great focus on quality and employee development as a whole...very clear focus on quality
cons: Focus on quality and agility can at times leads to heavy lifting in terms of work, leading to a potential compromise on a healthy work life balance

headline: Great place to start your professional career
pros: People are great. Cases are extremely interesting, with high impact for the clients.
cons: Management is too aggressive with junior consultants.

headline: Great career start
pros: Smart people, good brand, exposure to multiple industries and capabilities, good culture, great exit options
cons: Pay can be benchmarked to banking which indeed has less workhours. Long work hours and becomes unsustainable over time. Also lot of focus on formatting. Low engagement from partners on solutioning.

headline: Great but demanding
pros: Professional development is paramount at Bain & Company. From consultants to partners, everyone takes time to get to know the associate and their aspirations.
cons: Very demanding work and social requirements.

headline: Computer Hardware Engineer
pros: I obviously like working for this company because of the care they give employees
cons: there is a possibility to sleep out of home one day for fear that the elevator might fail one day

headline: Manager
pros: Overall very good flexibility, with opportunity to have your own time to improve client relationship. Teams are always very well motivated and with great commitment
cons: Sometimes you still need to work hard on weekends or on nights. Partners might tends to take the lead on some core project leaving you squeezed between team and top management.

headline: Great Place To Work
pros: Free coffee, espressos, and unsweetened almond milk.  Everyone loves the cereal bar and you can fill your water bottles at the fountains like in the gym.
cons: It's on the 42nd floor so the elevator can take awhile; especially if you forgot something.  There's a Chipotle on the same block so temptation is always a few doors down.  Plus, there's another one just a block away!

headline: Senior Associate Consultant
pros:
Great people and general culture.
Clear progression path
Highly valued by other potential employers
Travel and other opportunities
cons:
Day to day work can be tedious, lots of powerpoint
Most "strategy" projects are not strategy.

headline: Great!
pros: Intelligent colleagues, great culture, challenging work
cons: You spend too much time manicuring slides

headline: Best Place to Work
pros: Excellent Employee Appreciation, Wonderful office environment, team atmosphere. Great Life/Work balance, offsite perks & activities.
cons: Sometimes can be very stressful & thank-less, but they are so employee-centric and care about their employees that the cons don't really matter.

headline: Senior Associate Consultant
pros: Experience across many industries, great branding, MBA sponsorship
cons: Hours and lifestyle, travel can get very intense.

headline: Hard time retaining CSS people. High turn over
pros: Nice clients and business is doing well.
cons: Extreme turn over in my time at Bain. I was considered the role model on my team yet never compensated or appreciated, just given more work. Limited growth in CSS, you will hit a glass ceiling. Constant big brother feeling, Hr will make you feel like you are incompentent of being independent and responsible for your work. No flexibility to work from home, every step in and out of the office is logged and critiqued.  Difficult for working CSS moms. The company's core values seem stuffy and old school. HR team is immature and hard to communicate with.  Bonus/Benefits for CSS staff are horrendous and barely compettive. Review process is tedious and ridiculous.

headline: Consultant
pros: Intellectually stimulating, young colleagues, network, trainings
cons: Long hours, facetime culture, useless work, lot of codes in relationship

headline: RA
pros:
It had nice salary 
Also there were all good people whom I can learn a lot from
their training programme was exceptional compared to others
cons:
Nothing really.
Sometimes over working but generally manageable and considering the salary 
it's expected

headline: Inspiring and challenging, every day
pros: We solve our client's toughest problems, and we become trusted advisors along the way. We develop unique rapports with these clients, from senior executives down to front-line operators, based on the caliber of our work and accessibility of our people. Our teams are fun to work with, we place a significant emphasis on the in-office culture, and foster an environment where you're always being pushed to the next level.
cons: Work-life balance can be a tough feat to achieve when on the consulting side given travel involved in the job. That said, this varies considerably by office and practice area, and there is always flexibility to accommodate different preferences.

headline: Top Tier Consulting with Great Mindset
pros:
- Top tier: you get to consult industry-leaders, listed companies and hidden champions from all over the globe
- Private Equity Group: the chance to do only PE topics for at least six months. Bain with #1 position in market for PE consulting and therefore many "hot topics" for leading PE funds
- People: the people make the biggest difference. Despite all the hard work there is always a great team spirit and there were lots of occasions already where we as a firm/ project team ended up partying together
- No one here likes weekend work
- International staffing
cons: - It is top tier management consulting - working hours can become demanding sometimes despite everyone trying to avoid it...

headline: Admin manager
pros: Bain has a work hard play hard atmosphere. There are lots of company wide events during the year that are meant to bring employees closer together. The culture is second to none because of all of the events that are provided to the employees.
cons: Turnover on the Administration side is few and far between because it is such a good company to work for. Employees can run out of opportunities because of the low turnover rate.

headline: Consultant
pros: Learning from great professionals, having an impact in society, quick learning curve
cons: Long working hours, need to travel very frequently, little flexibility for personal issues

headline: Great company in US, so so elsewhere
pros:
- name value
- salary (for consultants)
- perks
- surrounded by smart people
cons:
- no work-life balance
- selfish environment

headline: Incredible place to learn and start your career in business
pros: Smart, supportive, ambitious people who are great to work with. Very collegial, team-oriented culture.  Steep learning curve; always learning and being challenged. Incredible training and professional development- the company really invests in its people. Ability to work in a wide range of industries and business issues. Important, meaningful work from the getgo.
cons: Sometimes inefficient work culture b/c of hierarchy and expectation of long hours.  Unpredictability of client work in general can lead to unpredictable schedules, long hours at times, travel even when unnecessary. That said, at Bain, management tends to be better about restricting travel to when its really necessary and tries hard to work on work-life balance as much as possible.

headline: Really solid
pros: Really great team. Invest heavily in culture and training. Very transferable skill set.
cons: Hours are long. Professional services can be tiring at times.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Bain provides a welcoming environment where you are coached and trained in how to proactively solve problems and think like a CEO. There is a great office culture that values hard work but also fun.
cons: The work at times can be demanding, and sometimes clients are difficult to work with, but this is more a feature of all consulting.

headline: Senior Associate Consultant
pros: Good career plan, fast learning curve
cons: requires travel depending on the case

headline: Excellent
pros: There is an extremly bright group of very hardworking and helpful employees who will always help assist you when necessary.
cons: Asside from the hours, which are standard at any consulting job I have yet to find any actual cons to working at Bain

headline: Great employer
pros: Great culture and development. People really take an interest in your career and help you achieve your goals.
cons: Lifestyle can be poor if put on the wrong case. Travel can make that even worse, though Bain's local staffing model is much better than either BCG or McK. Unpredictability of the job can wear on you as well.

headline: Incredible company!
pros: When I started at Bain a year ago, I had no idea how much I would learn in such a short amount of time, and how much fun I would have while doing so. Bain has pushed me to continue growing every day, and has surrounded me with impressive and supportive people along the way. I have found mentors that have invested incredible amounts of time into my development, and couldn't have chosen a better place to start my career.
cons: Hours can be long, but the company makes an effort to support sustainability.

headline: Great spirit and great opportunities

cons:
The usual consulting cons:
Working hours can be tough
Little control over own time as a junior team member

headline: Great company fresh out of college
pros:
It's an amazing platform to be exposed firsthand to high-level issues at big companies, with a lot of travel (I'm based out of Southeast Asia). As a fresh college graduate, I am hard pressed to think of another industry that will offer the same types of opportunities. 

Bain specifically, has an amazing collegiate culture that it's hard to tell friend from colleague at times (can be both a good and bad problem). The SEA office is also very diverse (our second most prevalent nationality is Italian), which makes for an interesting set of colleagues nonetheless.

Being in the SEA office specifically can also be really helpful to professional development immensely - I've had a lot of exposure to senior clients very early on, even in my first year that I find my colleagues in the US don't experience as much. Also, since we are a less developed market, the projects I work on are very  much growth oriented with many "2020 Ambitions" strategic projects thrown into the fray. There is a huge opportunity to work on really high-level, less process-oriented projects that one is more likely to work on if he/she were in the US.
cons: As much as the projects here are great, there is also limitations to what we do - there is less data in less developed markets for example and clients are not as sophisticated as they are in the developed world. This means various things from tougher work life balance to data analysis limitations when the biggest hurdle is actually getting the data.

headline: Top talent, lifestyle with ups and downs
pros:
- Top talent
- Projects with industry winners
- Hands-on approach
- Strong private equity practice
cons:
- Some general aggressiveness in (some) people's attitudes/work style
- Lifestyle sometimes miserable

headline: Exciting and challenging consulting job at a top tier global firm
pros:
- Bainies have a great team spirit, are down to earth fun to work with
- The case work is challenging and very diverse, both in terms of industries and functional areas covered
- If you are willing to work hard, you are rewarded with lots of responsibility early on as well as a steep learning curve and exciting development opportunities
cons:
- Working at Bain can be challenging because consulting firms do business in a very competitive market, which can cause projects to have ambitious timelines involving long working hours
- Be prepared to travel a lot - this can be strenuous for some people

headline: Great place to work
pros: People are great, work is interesting and great culture in general
cons: Hours are long and compensation is lower than other high performance industries

headline: Great place if you're looking for a management consulting career
pros:
Fantastic global culture based on (in my mind) collaboration, high ambition and pragmatism (a rare thing among consulting firms)

Many events such as a global football tournament and global training sessions

Really well paid job

Meritocratic promotion system
cons:
Hard work, but not harder than other firms in the same industry

Travel, but less so than other firms in the same industry

Being #3 in terms of size means Bain often need something extra to win in tenders where McK and BCG is involved. That can result in tough cases

headline: Bain Brussels Assessment
pros:
- Bain supportive culture. On the first hand, efficient professional development programmes are in place, ensuring all employees can optimize their learnings, both from clients and colleagues. We get to work on several types of cases, developing communication skills, analytical skills, etc. On the other hand, a Bainie never lets another Bainie down. We can always count on the support of our colleagues and a eal one team spirit exists.

- Impact: As from the day you join Bain, you get involved in decisions and interact with senior clients. You feel you have an impact as of day 1 and this is great!

- Fun: Several team and office events are organized to keep the fun dimension high, including a Bain World cup, team events, etc. I also helps enhance the overall atmosphere on a daily basis. Your colleagues become friends and this is unique.
cons: - Working hours tend to be quite heavy in comparison of other "industry" jobs. However, Pros clearly counterbalance them!

headline: Great place to start a career
pros: Wonderful company culture, smart and hardworking peers, interesting projects that address pressing client problems
cons: As with all consulting, hours can at times be unpredictable and travel is often a significant part of the job

headline: Perfect place to start your career after college
pros: Great culture and atmosphere, great people to work with - even after a long day we are still having a great time; Time flys by as I am learning so much every day; Bain offers many possibilities to learn and grow both professionally (international trainings, AC class meetings etc) and personally (colleagues, mentors); I like how we work together with the client and have a friendly attitude towards them - arrogance is not tolerated here; Overall, I could not have imagined a better place to start my career after college than Bain. Looking forward to may more fun years!
cons: Long working-hours are standard and expected (in line with all other strategy consultancies); "smaller size" of Bain (compared to BCG, McK) limits office choice

headline: Review by junior Nordic employee
pros:
+ Steep learning curve
+ Best and "funniest" people with highly unique culture
+ Prestige
+ Potential exit opportunities after Bain
cons:
- Unpredictable working hours
- Sometimes tedious (unavoidable) tasks

headline: Excellent place to launch a business career
pros: I chose Bain for the people. I have used this criteria for most of the major decisions in my life and I have yet to be disappointed. Bainies are absolutely excellent individuals. They are driven, smart, funny and kind. I absolutely adore coming to work because the people are fantastic. Additionally Bain provides a lot of training and support.
cons: The work life balance is challenging. Either you'll be working long hours 10+ on some days, or you'll be traveling to another city most days of the work week. That being said, I have never had to work on the weekends and that is fantastic.

headline: SAC Bain Review Germany
pros: Bain is by far the strongest in "people" as the key asset in the consulting business. It's not only about the focus on results or the market leadership in sectors such as Private Equity consulting, it's more about being surrounded by inspiring people, whether colleagues or clients, who always challenge you to give your best. I've been through the entire recruiting process of all so-called MBB firms or the top tier, and in Bain I've noticed how unique it is to have a firm made up by authentic individuals who yet have an unbelievably strong culture in common. Finally, Bain offers more flexible and variable career options and programs to juniors compared to the main competitors in the field.
cons: It is really hard to find or point out cons at the best consulting company to work for, as stated by several ranking. Nonetheless, there is always room for improvement. Bain is not the biggest consulting firm, but has always been within the top three, and it's not only about size anyway. Notwithstanding, there is clear room for Bain to expand. So I would say one of the things missing would be even more offices in some of the hot zones at the moment.

headline: Great Launching Pad, Fantastic Culture
pros: Bain is a phenominal place to advance your career and get experiences and exposure that will set you up for success no matter what path you take next. One area in which Bain excels is culture and community. It is amazing how they are able to bring together such a diverse but compatible group of people, and how heavily they invest in your ability to build bonds within your classes, teams, and office across all levels of the organization.
cons: Overall Bain is definitely less travel heavy that it's key competitors. While I understand how some find this appealing, I personally wish I had the ability to travel more regularly.

headline: Research assistant
pros: Communicative coworkers and an open atmosphere overall. Interesting and useful work. Nice bright office that is conducive to natural interaction.
cons: Abrupt inception into work and office. Superiors open to communication but too busy to listen to suggestions. No extra pay for overtime.

headline: Consultant
pros: People are extremely nice and supportive. I have offers from other top consulting firms and  have friends that work at those places. Bain is the only one with a unique culture that focus on people. I spent a lot of time at works, but I genuinely consider bunnies are my friends. We hanged out outside of work quite often. There is no sense of competitiveness amongst Bainies unlike other firms.
cons: Like any consulting jobs, the hours can be long. It is hard for employees to maintain a sustainable lifestyle. Partners travel a lot also

headline: Great firm to work for
pros: Working on challenging und interesting projects, great learning opportunities, amazing company/ office culture and a lot of great colleagues to work with.
cons: Work life balance is an issue (as it is typical in the consulting industry) and if you don't like traveling, this job won't work for you.

headline: Best consulting firm? Bain & Company.
pros:
There are lots of great examples underlining why working at Bain is an exceptional opportunity. After many discussions with friends employed at McK and BCG, I'd like to write about two that stand out for me:

-"Generalist approach to staffing": compared to other firms in which you have to commit early to an industry or "competence center", Bain pursues a "generalist approach" to staffing giving you the opportunity to cover as many industries/ functions as you like. This is a great deal who wants to get the most out of consulting possible. It basically never gets boring and you never feel like limiting yourselve to one area unless you want to.

-"Diverse development opportunities": Bain's commitment to staff development goes far beyond the industry standard. Besides supporting an MBA or offering international office transfers, Bain has diverse development opportunities like for example a) "externships" (work in your favorite startup for up to 6 months while receiving your full salary) or the b) "experience track" (pursue your interests through a language course or summer school while receiving your full salary and support for tuition fees).
cons: Working long hours is usually considered a "con" but honestly, EVERY AMBITIOUS PERSON will work long hours no matter in what industries he/she is in.

headline: Highly demanding! But would I do it again? Hell yea, it's worth it!
pros:
Bain has given me tremendous opportunities to develop over the past years - I've been staffed in multiple countries, on multiple projects and I can already confidently say I've seen a lot and gained massive experience!

Every project is a new challenge and brings new learning. I get the chance to work with extremely smart and ambitiious people who at the same time are down to earth and nice, buffoons are just not accepted here!

Finally, the office and company wide social events are a blast! :)
cons: Before opting in for Bain, one has to be honest with himself - working here is not a piece of cake. Our Clients are top-notch but also very demanding. The quality of our work is outstanding. But to deliver all this, hard work needs to be put it, sometimes a lot of it. This may come in conflict with your personal life, particularly when you travel a lot and don't get to see your family and friends as often as you would have wished for. Nevertheless, the firm is truly committed to make things work and very flexible in terms of personal needs - I highly appreciate it!

headline: Great Training but Bain Koolaid overrated
pros:
- Great training and hands-on experience for a young employee
- Respectful managers, good guidance, good culture
- Teamwork focused environment, great alumni network, proud to be a "Bainee"
- Great launch point for a career, skillset valued by many employers / business schools
cons:
- The consulting industry itself is not that fulfilling (just look at the attrition rate of employees)
- Pay and benefits are lagging jobs of comparable skill/role.  Limited upside opportunity
- Very structured job function. Limited creative opportunity

headline: Excellent place to work

Interesting work with plenty of opportunities to learn

headline: Start your career at Bain
pros: I can't think of a better place to launch a career: incredible mentorship from management; extremely supportive culture; high level of accountability that leads to amazing learning opportunities

headline: Associate Consultant in Dallas, Texas
pros:
The people who work at Bain are some of the most caring, bright, fun and passionate individuals I have ever had the opportunity to surround myself with. I feel fully supported by the company in all of my work endeavors, and they have even been incredibly supportive through personal injuries that have occured off the job. 

The mentorship programs at Bain are unparalleled. The leadership team has a vested interest in all of the associate consultants, and the focus groups (Women at Bain, Global Development, and others) all ensure extra support for different communities and interests. 

I couldn't be happier with my employer and the people that I get to work with. Throughout my first year with the company I believe I have grown immensely in my work and inter-personal skills.
cons: As in all consulting firms, you don't always get to choose the content of your case or the type of work you will be doing. I often enjoy the people I am around more so than the work that I am doing. However, one of the benefits of this type of work is that everything changes, and one bad case will end and likely transform into a new good one.

headline: More than just a Springboard
pros:
Great people to work with and share experience with, ample learning opportunities across all industries and functional fields, from finance to marketing and organization, there are some of the smartest people working for Bain to learn from.

Fantastic team spirit, worthy of the old "A Bainie never let's another Bainie fail" expression which is supported through local and global trainings where employees come together from around the world to share experiences and take on new challenges. All rounded off with global spirit events such as the Bain World Cup with more than 1,200 attendees this year competing in soccer and volleyball and celebrating together the Bain culture
cons: Like in any other top tier management consultancy, nights can get long. The difference is in whether the Team takes on the challenge together or breaks apart and at Bain, my teams have held every time.

headline: Incredible support and development
pros: An highly supportive culture creates an environment with an incredibly steep experience curve. Looking back over my 3 years at the firm I am amazed at how much I have developed across all aspects of the professional skillset spectrum, but at no point did I feel "over-my-head" due to the strong mentors - both on cases and in general - who have been there for me at every step of the way.
cons: While this is an issue present in the majority of firms, and Bain overall seems to be ahead-of-the-curve, I would love to see a strong female presence in senior management levels.

headline: Know what you're getting in to and how you'll get out
pros:
The Bain Manufacturing Process is a solid approach for structured thinking and project management...
The people are hard working, intelligent and generally sincere...
The name on your resume is valuable and does open broader opportunities...

Overall the company is a good company and the experience a net positive experience. I enjoyed the majority of the people I worked with, felt they challenged me and gave accelerated my development. I am an industry hire, which is rare at Bain: I joined the firm as a consultant with 12+ years of experience and my reasons for coming to the firm were very specific: it was the last chance I saw to have an intense investment in myself and it brought optionality to a career that was previously focused on two industries.

The case work was high profile (though not groundbreaking or innovative) and the work we do - by and large - has a big impact on Fortune 20-50-100-500 companies. The work I have been on has received national attention. This can be a reward unto itself, if this is something that is important to your career or self-worth.
cons:
...but the application of the Bain Manufacturing process varies from office to office, case type to case type and manager to manager.
...but there are some people the idealize how they want to be without reconciling it with how they come across or treat their case teams.
...but it comes with a cost around your health and wellness outside the firm.

The firm has developed its own language and uses it liberally. The issue is that it leads to a form of laziness: the consulting staff - particularly managers and case leadership - rely on the language for direction and it becomes a form of leadership shorthand. It's the equivalent of an MD's scrawl: fast and expedient, but highly susceptible to misinterpretation. This can lead to a high degree of frustration with case staff. It's compounded by the fact that manager to manager, partner to partner, etc., use terms like "answer" and "80/20" differently. They use it similar enough that you know the general idea of what a manager wants, but the portion that is different can lead to high yield loss, or worse, feeling like you're not being leveraged to best affect the team. The company relies on terms like "process driven" or "answer driven" to communicate messages, but those terms mean different things for different managers. The result is a highly frustrated team.

There is also something that occurs between Consultant level and Manager level. A slow evolution begins where managers and above start to lose touch with the volume of work required to deliver against requests. Partners will make a request and managers will promise delivery by the EOD when it actually requires four times as much work. The issue is that the work WILL get done. Even if it means working until 3:00, 4:00 or 5:00 in the morning. Because additional requests don't bump out the timelines for the work you already have on your plate, they just add to it. This is a function of being in a client services business. This is the function of having partners that are unwilling to have backbone and push back against clients when they change the scope of work. This is a function of an industry that is willing to churn through high volume of bright, intelligent people, because they know they can replace the cog. That's not an indictment on the industry or Bain; it's just the way it is. What is an indictment on Bain is the fact that they market themselves as not bowing to this kind of systemic pressure, that they're different. They're not. It's a competitive environment for clients and Bain is continually trading consulting staff well-being for winning a bake-off: as long as that continues to persist, the sustainability will suffer.

There is also a bit of arrogance within the firm, and while understandable, it has turned me off to some of the brighter aspects. I've seen people reach a certain point around the five year mark, where they fall in love with the Bain way and lose track of the always learning mentality most had early in their careers. They assume an attitude of "I've arrived" and "I know all there is to know." Having gone into my Bain career with the idea that I was going to be a sponge and soak up as much knowledge, expertise and skill-building as possible, this has started to be the biggest detractor to my experience. It's more pronounced in some that others; however, it's generally systemic.
