headline: Great place to work
pros: Management consulting is definitely a great way to start your business career and Bain has the best culture in my opinion. Everyone is nice and friendly, pretty much across the board
cons: Just the typical cons of the industry, I don't see any specifics with Bain.

headline: Case Team Leader
pros:
Great culture
Amazing salaries and benefits (vs. peers)
Interesting people throughout
Great mobility across the globe (for personal or professional reasons)
cons:
Slower track to partner than Mckinsey (esp for high performers)
Emerging markets not performing at the same standard as US and Europe

headline: Limited growth opportunity and morale for assistants
pros:
- You get to work with smart, driven people (on the consulting staff).
- The benefits are great overall.
- The culture is often fun and inclusive to all "Bainies," not just consultants.
cons:
- Salary is low for EA / MA's compared to that of other high-profile consulting firms.
- HR will often look outside of the firm before promoting one of their own, in part so they can low-ball a new hire.
- HR tends to micromanage the assistant team.

headline: Excellent place to work
pros: Employees are highly valued, well-trained, fairly compensated, and become members of a culture of excellence
cons: Job opportunities/path to growth not as clear for non-consultants

headline: Glad I did it, and glad I'm no longer doing it
pros: Great people, strong culture, excellent resume builder.  The environment is competitive but not cutthroat.
cons: Not a sustainable work/life balance in any way.  For most people, it's a sprint for two or three years followed by a burnout.  Clients have become more an more savvy about how to best utilize consultants, and they work them to the bone.

headline: Senior Associate Consultant
pros: great learning experience and colleagues become friends for life
cons: can be long hours on cases

headline: Consultant
pros: Great people!  Great Culture!
cons: Unpredictable work hours and travel (depending on case)

headline: Great culture, smart people
pros:
Working with smart & nice people
Great culture
Good compensation
cons:
Challenging work environment
Work-life balance
Frequent business travel

headline: Great place to work
pros: Bain is a firm truly dedicated to professional development and mentoring. A place where you can learn and grow a lot - professionally and personally. A great culture with people that are smart but also down to earth and can laugh about themselves.
cons: Long hours depending on the project - but that's typical in the consulting industry. So not really Bain specific.

headline: good
pros: freebies and smart colleagues and good location
cons: work life balance is hard understaffed in knowledge

headline: Case Team Leader
pros: Great people for the most part, interesting client challenges with senior leadership, decent pay but could be better
cons: Really long hours otter. Not necessary, lack of diversity especially in EM markets, poor office culture that is more hierarchical than advertised

headline: Great learning but intense
pros:
- Steep learning curve
- Diversity of projects and clients
- Some of the smartest people on the planet, all under one roof
cons:
- The hours & pressure to deliver
- The travel & nomadic lifestyle

headline: Great culture, decent work-life balance, smart people
pros: Great culture, decent work-life balance, smart people. Interesting work that only gets more interesting as you move up.
cons: Sometimes long hours. At lower-level consulting roles, the work is not always as interesting as it is for more senior members of the team.

headline: Good place to work
pros: Good learning opportunity and wide industry exposure
cons: Work style could be tough to manage given all the travel.

headline: Consulting staff
pros:
- Some very interesting and very impactful projects to work on 
- Opportunities to work in some interesting geographies (including Central Asia, West Africa)
- Surrounded by very smart people and a very diverse, international crowd in Dubai
- You do learn a ton in a very short period of time and the Bain brand has serious value when you go on the job market afterwards - strong alumni network in my experience so far
cons:
- Culture of office very much depends on your geography; Dubai office had very little of what is raved about in reviews of US offices
- Depending on region your office is in (i.e. Middle East in this case), you will have excessive travel and an increasing number of boring, long-term processy cases
- There are some people in senior positions (esp. manager/principal level) where no one knows how/why they got there (either due to obvious lack of ability or terribleness as a person)

headline: Senior Software Engineer
pros:
1) Good Work life balance
2) Various Fun activities.
3) Team offsite
4) Parties
5) Global Exposure
cons: Small Software team. Not enough opportunity for people manangement

headline: Great place to learn and get a network for a lifetime!
pros: Mostly interesting well rounded people eager to develop and who are not only intelligent but have great people skills as well.
cons: Can be tough working hours - but if you are young worth doing to get a stellar resume.

headline: Great place to learn, but not the right fit for everyone long-term
pros: Local staffing model, great culture and people, great learning
cons: Staffing uncertainty, can end up on bad cases or with bad teams

headline: Great people, great training
pros: Fantastic place to work with smart, fun people. Being able to test out different industries and types of cases helped me figure out my passion and senior leadership supported me when I went after it.
cons: Hard to get ownership, difficult to predict your life 6 or even 3 months in advance. A generalist firm, so can be difficult to specialize.

headline: Learned so much
pros: There is so much to learn from Bain even on the non-consulting side.  Lots of opportunity for professional growth and finding your own path.  Also allows great flexibility for part-time without sacrificing opportunities
cons: Long hours, availability sometimes required needed across time zones

headline: Sr. Recruiter
pros: Smart People, hard working, fun environment
cons: No room for upward movement

headline: Great Great company to work for
pros: Steep learning curve; absolutely a highlight in your profile
cons: workload is too much, can't see a good life-work balance, but it's common in consulting firms.

headline: Great place to start a career.
pros:
Awesome training
Strong, social culture
Talented and friendly people
Great network and brand
cons:
Culture may not be for everyone (e.g. it is very social)
Consulting hours and travel can be long, tiring

headline: Experience as ACI (Associate Consultant Intern, summer internship)
pros: You will work with very clever people, high motivated and very interesting. The ambient is very stimulating, with constant challenges.
cons:
Stress.

You will deliver results (analysis, slides, docs, etc.) to your boss (senior associate consultant, consultant, case team leader or manager) daily. You will be expected to be very efficient (80/20 rule) and productive. 

Also, the working hours and the availability on weekends results in burning out from employees.

headline: Highly satisfied
pros: Unbeatable access to business learning and growth opportunities.  People care about your professional development.  Meritocratic.  You get what you deserve.
cons: Long hours and travel, but nothing out of the ordinary for this industry

headline: Work hard play hard
pros: There is a very good atmosphere and a formidable spirit of collaboration.
cons: It can be a bit challenging to manage work and your personal life

headline: Smart team and great culture.
pros: Results-driven, great people, great impact
cons: Work / life balance, travel requirements

headline: Great environment
pros: The people I work with are amazing
cons: I have no complaints about NY office

headline: Temporary Project Assistant
pros: The tasks were quite mundane but it was an enjoyable experience to work at the Singapore office and see the consultants at work. The people were all very friendly and it was a great learning experience
cons: I was working on a temporary basis and was only called in for  specific projects so dont have any cons in particlar

headline: Great launching point into other jobs
pros:
Incredibly strong professional development focus (without being overly critical!!)
Congenial, intelligent peers
Once you work here, getting a job somewhere else is relatively easy (combination of the network and the brand name)
The job responsibilities change considerably each year you stay
cons:
Long hours
Can feel like a boy's club (sometimes it feels like there's a popular kid table full of the loud, boisterous ones)

headline: Amazing people, good money, incredible culture
pros:
You will learn a ton and get any exit opportunity you like
Awesome reputation
Incredible culture
Awesome compensation amongst MBB
cons:
Unpredictable hours
A bit too fraternal

headline: Great place to work -- if you're a consultant
pros: If you're a consuktant, Bain & Company will teach you a lot, give you amazing opportunities (such as, you can basically pick any one of their 51 offices world-wide for a six-month case) and introduce you to a lot of important people. If you're not a consultant, the company will still promise you many of these great opportunities, but that's all just a lot of talk.
cons: A very demanding schedule and pace, with employees pressure tested all the time. If you're part of "Consulting Support Services" (like me) you're just a cog in a machine. For example, consultants get "professional development" talks with their bosse every six months or so, I have my first such talk after six years on the job. Consultanst are made part of Baion's alumni network right away -- CSS staff like me will never be part of that network, even if we work here 20 years..

headline: Great experience working with company. Amazing people that consider work/life balance. Good leadership throughout.
pros: Great company to work for. Great people. Good benefits. Care about work life balance.
cons: Long hours and lots of travel.

headline: great learning experience
pros: - culture /  people /  passion
cons: - salary and  career opportunties for staff

headline: Not that results oriented
pros: Most of their collaborators are super smart. They have nice training sessions where you can meet people from all their offices
cons:
There is a strong focus on producing slides rather than adding value to the client. The results oriented vision is not fully supported by case work.
Some are still very hierarchical and this traduces in more work with low relevance for the ACs (analysts)

headline: Surrounded by bright, motivated people
pros: Great Colleagues, Awesome Clients, High Impact cases
cons: Work-life balance can be difficult, but very very limited weekend work.

headline: Smart people, good place to work
pros: Very smart, generally humble people
cons: Work-life balance can go out the window generally.  Lives become subservient to client needs/request

headline: Great place to work
pros: Great people to be with
cons: Long hours and bad lighting

headline: Great company to work for
pros: Excellent peers, interesting work, great company culture
cons: Sometimes long hours on cases, unpredictability of travel / lifestyle

headline: Fast-paced, high-stress environment with great perks and smart people
pros: It's great to work with a lot of smart, talented, driven people. The culture of the company is great. Rarely do you encounter egos, people are generally nice, expectations are high, but your coworkers want you to succeed. And people who do good work are singled out and appreciated. There are opportunities to move around as new offices are opened or other offices in the system require ramping up.
cons: Difficult to maintain a work-life balance (at all levels); pay for admin staff is lower than what I've seen at comparable companies. Demands are high and control of your day-to-day job responsibilities is often low.

headline: Great opportunities at a great firm
pros:
Great people and culture
Great work
cons: Sometimes the hours can be long, but it's the nature of the beast!

headline: Awesome place to work
pros: Amazing benefits, they care about work/life balance
cons: Hard to grow within company

headline: Incredible culture
pros: Very focused on its employees.  Creates a great work environment for both consulting and support staff.  Making great progress with the support staff value proposition
cons: Can be difficult to "break-in" if you join from another firm.  The strong culture is great, but makes it challenging for those who haven't grown up in the firm to fit in

headline: Phenomenal Internship (ACI) Experience
pros: Treated as a full-time employee and given full-set of responsibilities (no watered-down tasks), great regimented training program and events for interns, transparent and clear (and frequent) feedback mechanisms inspire personal and professional growth
cons: Experience is very dependent on your specific case assignment (including client, supervisor, team, etc.), although internship managers do screen the cases very carefully

headline: Work hard, laugh often, learn even more
pros:
Incredibly smart, down-to-earth, intellectually curious, and fun-loving colleagues. 
Great place to get strategy experience that is hands on, analytical, fact-based. 
Lays a very practical foundation for those seeking careers in lifetime consulting or corporate strategy.
cons:
Long hours, stressful. Work-life balance can be challenging as you are never 'off' or inaccessible. 
Any individual's experience is highly dependent on the particular cases they work on.

headline: Great company
pros: Extremely professional team and very fast paced work. It was engaging and fulfilling working with them, and I have gained a lot of valuable experience.
cons: I found the hours to be quite long and interpersonal communication within the teams takes slightly more time than I would have liked.

headline: Great experience
pros: Smart peers, great work, fun work environment.  Can be very demanding
cons: Stressful, limited work-life balance primarily due to client service, travel can be rough

headline: Fantastic people & company culture with a reputation that will open many doors for you.
pros: Fantastic people, great company culture, extremely strong reputation and alumni network, interesting strategic clients
cons: Very analytical work (not suitable for some people) and occasionally, difficult clients or partners

headline: Great learning group
pros: In early years you learn lots of analytical and business related skills; very fast paced
cons: Lot of time and effort spent in managing internal egos and messaging; client work often not scoped in a way to drive results (very low risk environment).

headline: Nurturing, exciting, and fun environment
pros: Very sincere and structured focus on development and working relationships. Mentorship is expected and part of the DNA, not just taken up by a select few. Work is fast-paced and generally interesting. Team environment and class cohorts make Bain an incredibly fun place to work. There is true affinity amongst people here, almost to a cult-like degree (in the best sense of the word!).
cons: Lifestyle is generally ok but highly unpredictable. Recent local office-level cost cuts are mostly reasonable but change management could have been handled better (poor communication, with little understanding of what junior employees actually care about; explanations given seem patronizing and disingenuous). Slow promotion timeline in Asia vs. rest of Bain and competitors seems hard to justify based off capabilities of class.

headline: learned a lot
pros: awesome colleagues and fun and interesting projects
cons: long hours and travel can wear on you

headline: Good
pros: Pay. People. Training. Culture. Food.
cons: Sustainability - also not fulfilling after a point

headline: Great place
pros: It is a great place to work and learn.
cons: There are times where work and life goes out of balance to meet client needs.

headline: Best Firm to Work For...Ever
pros: Awesome culture, intelligent colleagues, nice work environment
cons: Career progression opportunities limited for shared services employees

headline: Great consulting company!
pros: Challenging, yet friendly environment! Strong culture of helping each other and not so formal as other consulting companies
cons: Long hours; slow career advancement for a consulting company; internal politics are extremely tricky and meritocracy is sometimes at large of discussions

headline: Excellent firm, great place to start a career
pros:
Consulting pros: Varied projects/tasks, professional development/exit ops, early responsibility
Bain pros: Fun-loving culture with extraoridnary team environments, private equity opportunities, true focus on results at the client level
cons: Hours are not bad (~60/week), but are very unpredictable, can't commit to something like a late Weds dinner with a friend. There's a lack of transparency (maybe necessary) on how activities such as staffing, sourcing, and fees are run.

headline: Great place to start a career
pros: Well oiled machine when it comes to personal development, feedback, management training, etc. While consulting in the long run ends up being less fulfilling for many, I can't think of a better job to have right out of undergrad or grad school.
cons: Not always the ability to choose your team or case project. Sometimes this can be brutal.

headline: Great place
pros:
- Invest in culture
- Lots to learn
- Recognition for hard work
cons:
- Work life balance
- Mismatch of expectations at BCC

headline: Nice company, intense working hours
pros:
WORK
-- Corporate case covers a broad range of businesses such as financial services, healthcare, oil and gas, consumer goods, customer services, government, TMT etc.
-- It has the biggest private equity consulting group in London, very professional, you get lots of experience working with big PE firms. 
-- Definitely very good career exits (PE firms, mid/high level management in big companies, enterprise, charity etc.)

STAFF
-- Partners and managers are very experienced and knowledgeable. Generally very friendly, don't feel hierarchy 
-- Managers/CTL generally are promoted from consultants
-- Consultant's background varies, generally has 2-3 years experience in other jobs, and join Bain straight after their MBA studies
-- AC and SAC typically come from Oxbridge background, some with MD/PhD degree or previous working experiences

FRIENDLY ENVIRONMENT
-- Friendly supporting staff
-- Nice office setting, canteen and gym 
-- On-site GP, nutritionists, physiotherapists, personal trainer, acupuncturist, hair dresser, massager etc.
--  Fresh fruits on every floor
cons:
-- Hours for corporate cases are generally 9 to 8, private equity cases are typically 9 to midnight and often 1-3am.

-- People can be competitive sometimes, this depends

headline: Go for the training, leave for a lifestyle
pros: Excellent training, smart people, good pay, social community, great on the resume, helps get into business school or certain corporate strategy jobs
cons: Terrible travel and hours lifestyle, feel like a robot, no excuses culture that tends to make people unhappy, culture both works and plays too hard in some situations.

headline: Interesting projects with supportive and fun colleagues!
pros: Amazing training programs for each level of employees. Very supportive culture ("a Bainie never lets another Bainie fail") - this is what sets Bain apart from its competitors. Interesting and fun colleagues with hobbies outside of consulting. More often that not you get a say in what project you would like to be staffed in. I feel I learned tons over 3 years in Bain as I worked on a variety of projects. When I was planning my wedding my manager was supportive when I needed more personal time.
cons: 12-13 hour days Monday to Thursday, in PE cases up to 17-18 hours. Culture naturally supports men (e.g. easier for male colleagues to bond over some drinks with their boss after work vs for me, a married woman)

headline: Fantastic
pros: Bain is a great company to work for - they put a lot of effort into reviews, expectations are clear, and everyone wants to help one another
cons: The cons are the same as they are for every consulting job- the hours can be long, the travel can wear on you.

headline: Great company to work for; challenging lifestyle at times
pros: I think Bain is the best place to start your career.  The learning opportunities, responsibility, and executive exposure are unparalleled, and the people who work here are amazing.
cons: The hours can be challenging, though the firm prioritizes protecting weekends.

headline: Great place to work and fun people to work with
pros: The firm genuinely cares about professional development of individuals and designed best-in-class training programs as well as on-job coaching scheme to help people grow along the career path. You can work with smart and fun colleagues and establish long-lasting friendship
cons: Long working hours with frequent travels. Some industry expertise is under developed in Greater China.

headline: Great Company
pros: They give a lot to their employees.  It's a great place to be to grow and learn.
cons: None that I can think of.

headline: great working experience
pros:
1. high pay
2. great team
3. growth and development
cons:
travel a lot
jet lag
crazy hours sometimes

headline: Great Experience
pros: Great culture, smart people, interesting work
cons: Travel can be extensive at times

headline: Great people, great atmosphere, hard work.
pros: Intellectually stimulating work, fun people
cons: Tough hours, lots of travel

headline: Great company and learning experience!
pros: Bain truly values and invests in their employees. While everyone works hard and is held to high standards, performance is recognized and feedback is always helpful and constructive. Fun events are planned through out the year for all employees to attend. Excellent pay and benefits.
cons: Depending on your role, there can be a lot of travel and long hours, but I do feel its worth it. Promotions are typically given on a set track- so even if you're a superstar, you'll probably have to wait until you've been there a set amount of time to be promoted.

headline: Very interesting
pros: Great company culture overall. Great salary. Great opportuniies
cons: Extensive work hours. Very demanding

headline: Amazing!
pros: Great training, Great work, amazing team
cons: Lots of travel, Work life balance is not great

headline: Could not recommend more highly
pros: Bain excels because of its emphasis on professional development and creating a collaborative, fun environment. Yes, everyone works hard, but they're also people you'd want to have a drink with after work (or while traveling). Most importantly, there's plenty of training, mentorship and both formal and informal feedback to help you achieve your long-term career goals, whether they be at Bain or elsewhere.
cons: As is the case with most consulting jobs, there is a decent amount of unpredictability in staffing, hours, and travel.

headline: Best Company to work for!
pros: Great work-life balance, great people, great culture.
cons: None that I have encountered so far.

headline: HR Coordinator
pros: The people at Bain are great.
cons: Compensation for admin is not great.

headline: Marketing
pros: Work-life balance and benefits. Strong leadership and mentorship culture.
cons: Up-or-out out culture with ceiling for non-consultants

headline: Great experience! Got involved in actual cases.
pros: Really steep learning curve. Great exposure to a lot of industries. People are nice and approachable. Absolutely love this job.
cons: Hour could be as late as 11:00pm~2:00pm (in rare cases).

headline: Smart, social, pragmatic people
pros: Wonderful people working on big problems -- and focused on tangible impact.

headline: Good company to work for
pros: Job growth and the location

headline: Traditional consulting firm, with many intelligent people working there

headline: Bain is an amazing place to build a solid analytical foundation and grow professionally.

Alumni relationships are important to Bain and your Alumni network is perhaps even more valuable than your time at Bain itself.
cons: The usual consulting suspects - long hours, unglamorous travel, demanding clients/partners.

headline: nice experience working here
pros: i worked as a part time assistant here, and the daily work basically consists of finding supportive stats and making cold call. you would be able to gain insights to certain industries in a short time, and the consultants i worked with are fun and dynamic

headline: Strong culture, long hours

headline: Work hard, play hard.

headline: Great consulting company

headline: 1 year in and I'm hooked.

headline: Great Company to Work for

headline: Case Interview and behavioral interview for the management consultant position at Bain and Company - Singapore, Malaysia
pros: General management is the best way to apply your MBA skills in a strategic level. Good compensation, good teamwork and constant feedback. Mentorship is excellent and care about your career goal.
cons: You need to work long hours and sometimes you need to work during the weekend. Many of your recommendation may not get implemented by the clients so you may not see the real impact that you can have.

headline: Greatest Culture Ever!
pros: Bain can really pick good people! Everyone at Bain is the type of person you'd want to be friends with and go hang out with on a Saturday night.

headline: Very good company for post MBA career
pros: Good culture, brilliant people to work with, fun projects

headline: Bain & company
pros: The organization has great culture, there is lots of learning and fun everyday. Top management is very co-operative and pays adequate attention towards work life balance

headline: Great Entry Level Experience
pros: Interesting work, hardworking intelligent coworkers.  Management was responsive to employees needs. They offer some nice extracurricular activities and seem to care about the work/life balance.
cons: Sometimes the work can be drudgery, and if you are good at that drudgery you can get stuck doing that drudgery until you beg for a reprieve. If you want to get out of a rut you need to push back and sometimes managers don't want to deal with that.

headline: Great place to learn and make immediate impact
pros: Extremely interesting projects in diverse sectors, with tangible impact to clients' bottom line. Very supportive culture with a strong focus on professional development. Diverse and fun place to work.
cons: Long hours and lifestyle is not for everyone, but team-oriented and supportive culture helps make it sustainable.

headline: One of the best firms in the world - a place where you'll love what you do and laugh a lot.
pros: Bain is a highly successful firm, so firstly, the opportunities to gain professional business experience are second-to-none. Personal development is a priority, so you learn a lot quickly - and training is awesome (and fun). It is a truly global firm, and from the get-go, there are opportunities to build friendships with friends globally - and you will, since Bainies are very diverse but in unity a 'friendly bunch'. Even as employees 'at the bottom of the hierarchy', you're made to feel personally valuable. This reflects in the flexibility, opportunities and work. The superlatives continue elsewhere too (amazing offices, events, perks, tech, externships, flexible promotion, transfers (especially) etc.)
cons: Everyone at the firm is exceptional and the work is often stressful. always demanding. Naturally it's constantly challenging to keep at the pace. It can feel perhaps too cliquey at times. Travel can be rough (though you're generally treated well) - although probably less so than at big competitors due to an office-driven staffing model. This does mean that you'll likely have a mostly random experience of cases though - ACs have little influence over what cases they're assigned to, and inevitably some 'lose out'.

headline: Terrific training, terrific people, terrific camaraderie
pros:
-Great opportunities for young people to work with industry veterans and executives
-Strong training program in both quantitative skills and "fuzzy skills"
-Amazing people - really smart, really fun
-Lots of socializing
-Opportunity to work across many industries
cons:
-Can be on the road up to 4 days a week for months at a time
-Can be a round-the-clock job

headline: Great firm, for a while
pros: smart people, good cash, high intellectual stimulation, strong brand
cons:
if you stay too long you become too expensive/irrelevant for many lateral exit opportunities. 
limited ability to control what you are staffed on, what expertise you are developing. 
work life balance is a constant struggle

headline: A great place to start
pros: The people who are hired to work at Bain truly are exceptional. The employees I interacted with were always happy to collaborate and help one another.
cons: I didn't find any glaring down sides. I can say the consulting side enjoyed more benefits than the business admin side but that is to be expected to some degree.

headline: Best in class consulting work alongside amazing, supportive colleagues makes the job truly rewarding
pros:
- Amazing people: I am constantly learning from the people above and below me. It is an incredibly supportive and inspiring group of people to be a part of. Day to day, your supervisors are aware of your contributions, professional development, and truly care about your experience on the team. In addition to your case team, you also start with a class of consultants at your level and they quickly become your friends and a great business resource. 
- Interesting and varied cases: In my first year and a half, I’ve gotten to work in over 4 different industries and across practice areas (strategy, merger integration and PE diligence). I like that no case is the same and that I'm constantly needing to learn something new. As a consultant, I’ve started managing more junior team members which I find rewarding as well.
-The firm gets all of the people stuff right to make the job sustainable and enjoyable – Temp checks to make sure teams are successful, inspired and happy. Ways to recognize good work in the office. Global trainings (Miami, Dubai, etc.) to prepare you to be successful for the job. Fun stuff to reconnect with the office or others in your class (Summer Meeting, Bain Band, Bain World Cup).
cons:
-The client problems we're solving can be tough to crack. In particular, it is difficult for big organizations to change and, at times, setbacks can be discouraging. Sometimes we’ll need to have multiple meetings on the same topic to get client buy-in throughout the organization which can feel tedious. 
-The hours can be long (~12+ hours/day) on tough cases, although weekends are almost always protected

headline: Incredible culture, people, development
pros: What really sets Bain apart from other hard-working, smart professional services firms is that Bain has prioritized a culture of genuine caring about people - employees, clients, community. I was often impressed and inspired by leadership's dedication to doing what was right for the client, and simultaneously trying to protect sustainable work-life balance and continuously cultivate a fun, connected office/firm culture. I loved and benefitted immensely from the focus on professional development, mentorship, regular and real-time 360 degree feedback, and learning (with learning lunches covering a wide array of topics beyond what's most relevant to case work).
cons: Work-life balance is still variable, depending on the client, case scoping, and team leadership. While there are a lot of benefits to the highly structured skills progression expectations across levels, Associate Consultants can sometimes feel limited to owning data analysis even when they could start demonstrating some of the higher-level thinking and "soft skills" that are more expected of Consultants and Managers.

headline: Great school
pros: Great people and good projects. Good opportunity to learn from peers and interact with senior clients
cons:
Not all projects are fun
Long hours and stressful situations

headline: A company that cares, and that isn't full of itself
pros: At Bain, people really care about each other and about their clients, and the single biggest reason for that is the humble attitude that's at the core of the company. There's a genuine sentiment of being "at cause," i.e., doing what's required to successfuly resolve the ask of the day, and it's pretty inspiring to find a large number of people at a global company aligned around a value like that.
cons: Consulting is a demanding career, period. Client service entails a certain non-predictability and readiness to live with peaks and ebbs in terms of hours. Bain is not any different from other consulting firms in that regard.

headline: Great place, great opportunities, hard work
pros: Bain has been a tremendous employer. The work is challenging, the people amazing. I've learned more than I could have imagined, and head off to graduate school feeling well prepared and excited for what comes next. I'm grateful I chose Bain as my first job out of college.
cons: The work in intense, the hours long. They tell you that in recruiting, but until it becomes real it's hard to understand how it feels. At times you're staffed to casework that feels fascinating and important, at other times it feels less interesting. there is, though, a real focus on making sure that whatever you're doing has impact.

headline: Bain is a place that does meaningful, high impact work, with sharp focus on development of its consultants
pros: You are constantly learning and being challenged and stimulated in the work at Bain.  The office-centric staffing model means that you develop a tight network within a close-knit office community and people are even more invested in your development.  It's a merit-based culture that provides tons of opportunities to consultants in their case roles.  The culture is second-to-none with a management team that cares about sustainability and making sure the job is workable and enjoyable for everyone.  Bain is outgrowing its competitors which means there's tons of opportunity here.
cons: There are currently a number of legacy clients with large, long-term programs, which means there's less variety of client work at any given time.  Expectations are very high so you must be up to the challenge to push yourself beyond your comfort zone and always outperforming expectations. Work can be unpredictable and staffing does not always go your way.

headline: Pretty good opportunity
pros: Pretty good compensation, free lunch free taxi free hotel free coffee
cons: Even as a part time analyst, sometimes i need to work till 10 pm.

headline: Great place to work
pros:
- Great career opportunities
- Huge exposure to senior managers and CEOs
- Great benefits and international mobility
cons: Challenging if you are not used to high rhythms.

headline: Awesome
pros: consistently connected to the client
cons: Although it is nice, it is a lot of work

headline: Amazing experience
pros:
- The people you work with will become your best friends.
- Smart people and great mentors.  The quality of the people is very consistent.
- Challenging work everyday.
- Informal culture which is incredibly consistent at all offices.
- Global transfer opportunities and top-notch training.
cons: -Work life balance, as is to be expected in consulting.  However, at my office, you usually get credit for a particularly tough case and can choose to be on something easier.

headline: Learned a lot.
pros: good training. good data analysis training. good understanding of business principles. good analytics of current market.
cons: not many challenges. overall great place to work. learn a lot. good compensation. good professional development.

headline: Great experience
pros: Learns a lot during time there
cons: Long hours and lots of travel

headline: Bain has a lot of great people but is increasingly stuck in 1995
pros: The people are really awesome and passionate about what they do. The company is generally very forthright and the compensation tends to be very competitive. The career opportunities after leaving the consulting staff are tremendous.
cons: Client services is always challenging on lifestyle and Bain is no exception. Leadership usually has the best intentions but there is nothing that protects the front line consultants. People get called of vacations and in on weekends to do work and the LT acts like there is nothing they can do about it. Bain also struggles to value anyone that isn't directly client serving - they're always viewed as overhead even if they are mission critical to serving the client. The partner group is also very stodgy and skeptical of anything new and different.

headline: An excellent place to work!
pros: Great people, perks and interesting work. Leadership team is strong and focuses on what is important.
cons: Hours can get difficult at times.

headline: Hands down awesome
pros: Incredible culture - people work really hard, but they enjoy doing it; Incredible people - mix of intelligence but also humility that you don't find at the other top consulting firms; Amazing exit opportunities - the Bain network is not only big, it's incredibly strong. Ex-Bainies will almost always help out another Bainie without fail. This is truly a remarkable place.
cons: work life balance - hours can get rough, and travel is not always the most convenient option.

headline: Great company to work
pros: People in the organization are incredibly smart and create a great working environment.
cons: Lots of travel and long hours

headline: I love working with smart, motivated co-workers!
pros: Benefts are unbeatable, culture is fun and hard-working, it's a team environment all the way, people support one another.
cons: Runs lean and is fast-paced with a high volume of work most of the time.  Upward career growth can be limited due to lean structure but that's only an issue if you are prioritizing that over work-life balance, family commitments, etc.

headline: Amazing place to work! Full of incredibly smart people!
pros: Bain really cares about it's people and it comes out in everything that they do. Everyone here is dedicated and determined to make Bain the best place it can be! You learn something new everyday
cons: The pace is incredibly fast so if you aren't used to that or don't like high pressured environments then you might stuggle at Bain.

headline: Pragmatic, no-nonsense place to work for with great human capital
pros:
Where Bain stands out is
-Professional development.  
-Apprenticeship  
-Strong fun culture
-High impact projects 
-Opportunities to see across many capabilities and industries
cons:
Working at Bain means you'll have to deal with 
-Sustainability issues; it is client services after all
-Hard to always predict work hours and travel schedule
-How the firm is run can sometimes be opaque

headline: Unmatched professional development
pros: Professional development, extremely structured thinking, mentors that really look out for you, extremely challenging problems, meritocratic with many step-up opportunities, office interest groups, extremely transparent organization, free weekends, worldwide trainings, great clients, private equity leadership, colleagues I enjoy being around and learning from
cons: Constantly pushing at work and very high expectations for work - not as much the hours, but the pace can feel like a grind

headline: You can't find a better first job.
pros: I've never been around a group of people as highly motivated and yet intensely caring; people want you to succeed not just because it makes them look good, but because apprenticeship and mentorship are the lifeblood of the business. Relaxed, informal culture that gives you the opportunity and skills to succeed.
cons: Long hours, and the fact that you are never the one creating something; the hallmark of success at this job is helping someone else succeed.

headline: Great place to work but don't bother recruiting for a consulting position with the Chicago office if you are not white
pros:
*less travel on average compared to other top consulting firms.  Focus on travel only as needed.  Get to spend a lot of time in the office with teammates and colleagues.
*thought provoking work and generally great teams and clients
*exit opportunities are great and if you just want a break, easy to take a sabbatical or transfer for a 6 month period to another office for a new experience
cons: *Only a handful of non-white candidates end up getting offers and coming here.  Hypocritical that even though "diversity" is mentioned all the time but when it comes down to the final decision, other ethnicities lose out at this office.  Seen many less qualified individuals given opportunities over ethnic minorities.  Yes, if you visit the office, there is no diversity.

headline: Best Place to Work - No Lie
pros:
Bain is a great place to work. I feel very fortunate to have landed my non-consulting job here. Plenty of personal time off, the training has been great and my colleagues are fantastic. It's so nice to work at a place where I never have to say, "that person is an idiot," because pretty much everyone at Bain is intelligent and thoughtful. My supervisors have been extremely supportive, I've been able to work in a way at Bain that I haven't been able to at any other company. Bain has an entrepreneur spirit in that you can "build your own Bain." At Bain we do the things we want to do and are passionate about, not just the things that just pay the bills.

I've worked at many other companies that people consider glamorous and are great for the resume. The management at Bain is fantastic, I promise you, it will be hard to find a better company to work for.
cons: If you're non-consulting staff there is a divide and you will feel it. Consultants are the bread and butter of the company (it is a consulting firm, after all!) and you will be reminded of this occasionally. There is ALWAYS a ton of work to do which is great for opportunity but can kill your live/work balance if you let it. It's up to you.

headline: Amazing culture with very high expectations
pros:
The people: I am inspired to come to work everyday to learn from my coworkers.

The culture: everyone hears this about Bain, but it's actually true. It's an incredibly fun, supportive and challenging environment. They work hard and play hard.

The work: We get to deal with some of the world's most complex and challenging problems, and no two days are every the same.
cons: The pace and the expectations can sometimes be overhwhelming.

headline: Unparalled development opportunities, extraordinary people, and high impact work
pros: You have the opportunity to work on high-impact projects with change-oriented senior leaders. You do this whileworking with teams that are passionately focused on not just handing over a slide deck, but rather working hand in hand with clients to deliver real bottom line results. And you get feedback and coaching in a highly structured way that pushes you to your limits, developing your skillset a a breakneck pace. Finally, the compensation goes up very quickly - you won't be a billionaire, but money becomes a complete afterthought.
cons: It is hard work and you have to be at your best every day. There will be times when you will get pushed to your limits, and of course that brings with it the expected stress and long hours. And traveling away from your family sucks.

headline: Great place to develop core business skills, develop expertise in areas of interest and work with smart people
pros: Focus on professional development of employees. My function focuses a lot on work life balance and provides lot of flexibility. It also follows a meritocratic approach to compensation and promotions making it a fair process. Bain also provides many industry leading benefits on health and life insurance as well as many opportunities to have fun such as annual office offsites and holiday parties
cons: No concerns as of now

headline: I've been challenged and supported throughout my career at Bain and I am so grateful for that.
pros: I'm constantly learning. There are outlets for me to join groups that I'm passionate about outside of work, non-profit work, event planning for the entire office, spanish lunch group etc. etc. I know I'm making an impact.
cons: The bar is set very high and you're constantly being challenged. This works for me as I always want to learn as much as I can and be exposed to as much as possible, however, I know it's not for everyone.

headline: Its people make all the difference
pros: Great opportunities to learn. You always have someone to help you (They never let an employee fail for lack of help). Big exposure to clients at very senior level. the trainning programs are very good. People are really friendly
cons: Work-life balance is quite hard and may have to work on weekend on a few ocasions. You may have to travel a lot (bad for some people).

headline: Wonderfully supportive culture with work that makes a real impact for our clients.
pros: Cases are extremely interesting and push you to think out of the box. Blue chip clients that seem to really value the work we are doing for them. Amazing culture and people that want to help you succeed in your role. I've never worked for a firm with such a supportive culture from peers all the way up to partners.
cons: Hard to think of any. It is a demanding job, which may not be for everyone. However, the work we're doing and the people we do it with make it worth it.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Talented, fun people solving tough problems. Great supportive culture and less travel than competing consulting companies.
cons: Hours can be unpredictable at times. Overall work-life balance is great compared to competitors, but not as good as other industries.

headline: Great!!!
pros: Good pay; various opportunities for travel and networking
cons: 24/7; it takes years to make it to partner!!!!

headline: PTA Intern
pros: Great employer, good to work with smart people
cons: Long hours, and stressful project

headline: All around amazing place to work!
pros: I started my career here and have stayed for so long because I have been given the opportunity to grow and learn.  It's been really wonderful.  I love the people I work with - everyone is hardworking, down to earth and so much fun to be around.  I know it's work but we have a lot of fun too!
cons: When it's busy it's busy.  There are several periods throughout the year where people feel stretched and overworked.  In the end though we get through to the other side and feel good about all that we accomplished.

headline: An incredible place to work
pros: There are so many pros about working for Bain & Company.  Amazing, smart, and incredibly driven and hard-working people.  Managers that are invested in the development of their employees.  Some of the best tools available that enable employees to do their job in the most efficient way.  An unmatched culture that is focused on having fun, delivering client results, and investing in employee development.  A flexible working environment that is not about face time.
cons: Not many cons.  Sometimes it feels like the consulting staff is treated preferentially to other employees which can effect morale with the support staff at times.

headline: Amazing impact - the respect that we as a Bain team get from clients is really powerful
pros:
I truly feel I am getting the best ongoing business education possible, on an ongoing basis.  Among my peers outside of Bain, it feels like as one ages, more doors close, e.g. your focus narrows - but with Bain, I feel like I keep adding to my portfolio of skills and my set of future opportunities actually broadens.

Second - frequently said but said because it is true - the people at Bain care about each other, collaborate, and have fun together.  Teaming with those around me is consistently a pleasure.
cons: Expectations are quite high - our work is expected to be excellent, and we are a client-service business. Consequently there are some stressful moments and some late nights.  An acceptable tradeoff for the great impact, learning, and people, for me.

headline: Amazingly satisfying
pros: Everyone you meet is extremely smart, extremely nice, and extremely humble. Bain has a super supportive culture that makes it a pleasure to come to work every day.
cons: The firm does a LOT to help make cases a consistent experience, but it's practically impossible to guarantee that in a consulting environment - you will have your ups and downs.

headline: Best job possible post college
pros: Coming out of college, learning at Bain never stops. Bain has fostered a very supportive environment and you constantly are working with the brightest and best.
cons: Very few cons. The work hours can at times be long but Bain focuses on trying to maintain a work-life balance.

headline: Diligent, fun, intelligent, and awe-inspiring colleagues make Bain the best place to work.
pros: The people who work at Bain are in a class of their own.  They never stop driving at results for our clients.  They are supportive in a way I didn't know was possible in a fast-paced, corporate setting.  Bain is the perfect place to grow my career.
cons: There are sometimes long hours and travel.

headline: Amazing launchpad for a career
pros: Bain is without a doubt, the best place to learn.  Between a wide, constantly changing, variety of case work, a deep network of mentors, and an incredibly supportive culture, I have learned more in the last 2 years than I thought possible.
cons: Consistently operating outside of your comfort zone can be incredibly stressful.  Small price to pay for the learning opportunities though and the leadership works hard to make this job sustainable.

headline: Unparalleled culture and opportunity - lives up to the hype
pros:
-The breadth and quality of the cases you can cover are hard to come by in all but a few other consulting firms
-The office based staffing model makes Bain more sustainable than other firms; I interned with another consulting firm where I traveled 4 days a week and was only in my home office on Fridays. I found it unsustainable and felt I didn't know the people in my own office. At Bain, when you don't have client meetings, you can be in your local office. This means you have a more reasonable travel schedule and you really get to know your colleagues. 
-Compensation and benefits are great - can't complain, comparable to similar employers
-Bain is serious about your development. It's viewed as an apprencticeship and your team really invests in your professional development, regular check-ins to talk about what you're doing well and how you can do better.
-If you work here, within a matter of months you will start getting multiple solicitations to go work for another company at a level that would be hard to crack into a few years out of business school; I've been recruited almost more heavily here at Bain than when I was in business school.
cons:
-The nature of client service is that you'll have an unpredictable schedule. I've averaged 60 hours a week but it's felt managable so far. If you rotate into the Private Equity Group you won't travel at all but you'll expect to work longer hours due to the nature of the work.
-Yeah, the only down side is the work life balance - this is not and will never be a 9-to-5 job, but you probably know that already.

headline: Great!
pros: People, level of work, complex problems to solve
cons: Hours can be great but also terrible; teams are small so one person not carrying their weight has a huge impact.

headline: Good place to learn and grow
pros: wonderful people. good compensation. fast learning.
cons: long working hour, comparing to corporates jobs.

headline: Phenomenal culture and great launchpad for your career.
pros: Boot camp for a career in business and you'll meet lifelong friends to boot.
cons: Work hard play hard isn't for everyone.

headline: Good for career, Bad for life
pros:
Great opportunity to learn many skills and logical thinking.
Great people to work with.
cons:
No work & life balance.
Hard to maintain personal life and this is why I left this company.
Even thoguh company keep trying shorten working time, it's not just working..

headline: Good for a while, but manage your career.
pros:

Develop good analytical and communicaiton skillset
Some people great mentors and people people
cons:
Long, unpredictable hours... Different cultures between offices
Great if you are a star, but not the best if you are average
High turnover of employees

headline: Good
pros: Great people, challenging work, interesting
cons: Work-life balance, hard work, repetitive

headline: Extremely Satisfied
pros: Smart, driven group of co-workers who all work their hardest for their clients
cons: The job is in an extremely competitive and fast paced environment, so you have to pace yourself or you will burn out in the consulting field.

headline: Consultant
pros: Experience, People, fast growth,Brand Name
cons: Work life balance, travel, Stress

headline: Love the coaching I am getting!
pros: Leadership pays a lot of attention to how to develop their team members. Great people. Lots of valuable feedback
cons: Cases are not always as exciting as they sound. Sometimes have to work really long hour. Too much travel

headline: Incredible place to learn and grow
pros: Training and apprenticeship model is incredible for people who want to learn about business. I started my career here and could not have imagined a better boot camp to learn technical skills and about a variety of industries
cons: The hours can be quite unpredictable and it takes alot of effort to protect your personal time but it can be done. I would also want a bit more responsibility and independence

headline: Used to be great, but things have changed...
pros: Interesting business problems with some of the biggest companies in the world; great people, great compensation. You will get a ton of exposure to different industries and types of cases
cons: Bain has gotten much more implementation focused. I found myself often being nothing more than a workshop planner, building ppt templates to keep people on track. Also, the sexy, pure strategy cases seem to be fewer and far between. I am also not entirely sure about the value proposition of consulting anymore. It used to be that it was a great alternative to Finance, where you still made great money and got to do a few different things before transitioning to the corporate world. Now, it seems like if you are interested in technology or want to do entrepreneurship, you should probably skip the consulting route completely and instead go work at a startup. With the new crop of tech companies (Google, Facebook, LinkedIn, etc.), you still get great pay, benefits and get to do cool things without necessarily dealing with all the client services BS, the travel and the long hours.

headline: Varied, challenging and rewarding career working with excellent people
pros:
People are great
Variety keeps you excited
Lots of travel opportunities
Learning is continuous and steep
Development is centre to all we do
cons:
Can be difficult to specialise early on
The hours will not be for everyone

headline: Culture shock- in a good way!
pros: Work-life balance, environmentallly friendly, they truly care about their employees, always improving
cons: Cons cons cons cons cons

headline: Great place to start a career
pros: Exposure to senior staff from several companies, quick learning curve about several industries, competitive wages and benefits

headline: One of the best companies to work for

Great culture
Friendly and smart people
Extremely flexible
Compensation is good

headline: SA
pros: Had  a very great experience. Great training and career progression. Access to C-level executives. Great work environment and awesome culture.
cons: Long hours, no very exciting at bottom of totem pole. culture can be too much. wasteful sometimes. sometimes questionable value to client.

headline: Best Company to work for
pros: Great professional development in a very competitive environment

headline: Amazing opportunities

headline: Best place to work for freshers out of college

headline: Incredible people and network, poor work life balance
pros: Incredible culture both in the New York Office and across the organization.  Truly humble, interesting people that are a pleasure to work with.
cons: Poor work life balance as team and client requests steamroll everything else.  Being so client driven has the tradeoff of never being able to turn 'off'

headline: Incredible people, work very hard to take care of their eployees
pros:
-Great benefits and compensation package at all levels of the firm
-A culture where everyone is expected to help each other and to always ask for help when needed
-Summer meeting and outing events are very unique compared to other competitors
-They recognize the importance of their people and reinvest money into the firm in order to improve working experience
cons:
-Work-life balance is always going to be a challenge given that the industry is client serving
-Incredibly competitive culture and results oriented, they are willing to terminate someone with ease if they are not pulling their weight

headline: Deserves its employee awards
pros: For the right enquiring, hard working mind, Bain is an amazing place to work. Great problems to solve, great people to work with, great clients and a great apprenticeship process to reall accelerate talent to its full potential. Over the course of a career, there is real felxibility to get the work - life balance right. If you live for interesting work, this is a great place.
cons: It is hard work, and not everyone has the passion and mental flexibility to make it work. And if you work to live, and want lots of evenings for other interests, this is not the right place for you.

headline: Good company to start off
pros: big name. good human relations. fast pace. challenging.
cons: Locked interns in the intern room and didn't allow them to fully participate on the project.

headline: Awesome place to start a career
pros: Great people, lots of client exposure, phenomenal training. No better place to start a career. Re
cons: Pretty respectful of work-life balance, but can still be long hours at times due to client demands and/or travel.

headline: Intense and rewarding
pros: analytic culture, fun, high salaries, fast track career
cons: lifestyle sucks (a lot of work to do in very limited time), meritocracy is kinda relative

headline: Great company to start at out of college
pros: Great people, Great training, Builds a strong business foundation, Strong network

headline: Great place to start career
pros:
Great culture
Great training

Great opportunities for continuation within Bain or a career in a variety of fields (PE, Corporate, etc.)
cons:
Can be taxing / hard work

headline: Amazing place to start your career
pros: Amazing culture, everyone is so helpful and wants to see you develop professionally. You learn A TON analytically as an Associate Consultant in the first three years that will help you no matter where you go
cons: Lifestyle isn't for everyone long-term, but it's definitely worth it right out of college

headline: The best place to start your career
pros: The company has a truly incredible culture; the emphasis on personal and professional development as well as the smart, passionate, and fun employees make this a very unique place to work.
cons: The hours can get long and the travelling can be exhuasting at times; you may be on the road more than you are home.

headline: Great culture and people, but hard to advance in back office role.
pros: Benefits are almost unmatched and lots of culture of really great people!
cons: Work life balance can be challenging for dedicated employees, consider compensation adjustment

headline: Amazing people and excellent learning opportunity
pros:
Steep learning curve keeps you on your toes
Working with some of the best and brightest people

Friendly cooperative culture
First class training 
Exposure to different industries

headline: Fantastic company!
pros: Very strong culture.  The perks are awesome; the people are fantastic.  Everyone works really hard (smart, driven people).  We are a small company in size, but a large company in our global footprint.  There's always something fun going on.
cons: Teams are run very lean and can feel under-resourced.  The hours can be long

headline: Great place to work during timw
pros: You get to learn a lot
cons: travel can be hard on families

headline: Growth-oriented but stressful
pros:
Excellent learning and career growth
Down to earth culture
Colleagues very helpful
cons:
Stressful at times
Face time
Hierarchy
Less fun culture

headline: Amazing people, fantastic learning opportunities, and incredible place to launch a career
pros: The amazing culture at Bain is truly unique. This culture is driven by the outstanding people who work at Bain. The people are very bright yet humble and approachable. They have a passion for driving results while also having fun. The work is challenging and stretches you everyday; however, Bain provides the support you need to be empowered to be successful.
cons: The long-hours and travel can prevent Bain from being sustainable long-term; however, this just really depends on individual considering how much Bain works to try and mitigate the lifestyle challenges.

headline: Amazing PD, but inane work at the associate level
pros: Extremely well run company where people really care about helping you develop professionally and even personally. The staffing managers are very thoughtful. It's just a great way to learn the best practices for analysis, slide-building, presentation, client engagement, business logic, and working in a team. That being said, it wasn't for me.
cons: I enjoyed case interviews because that dealt with the high-level strategic thinking of consulting -- the answer of the case. Unfortunately, that's not the work you do as an associate consultant; your role is to execute perfectly. It was hard for me to work long hours or be on call, spending ~30% of my time doing quality control (I'm not a very detail-oriented person). They expect you to feel ownership and responsibility over your work stream, but you don't actually have much ownership (I'd say on my teams they encouraged me to speak up and take a 'first pass' at higher level work, but there were always lots of iterations based on small suggestions at each level).

headline: Great training ground for wide-experience with high talented co-workers
pros: Company goes out of its way to provide fun activities for workers (e.g. away days, drinks etc.), and supports opportunities to take a break (MBA, secondments).
cons: Work-life balance is non-existent. Very tough environment with little room for error in long hours.

headline: An incredible opportunity to learn and grow while being surrounded by some of the smartest people I've met.
pros: Bain truly values the concept of work/life balance. The company works to adapt the job to fit your personal needs and there is a mutual respect for this across the business. The training provided to new associate consultants is invaluable and unique in that you meet hundreds of people from across the world. The people are the core element of Bain people. They are inspiring and motivated individuals that constantly push me to be better.
cons: The biggest challenge of the job is the demanding hours.

headline: Great place to learn quickly and interact with some brilliant and fun people
pros:
1) Working with incredibly smart people
2) Learn fast - 9 months out of undergrad, and I feel like I've built a great set of transferable skills
3) Very fun culture. Lot's of people with similar interests
cons: Work-life balance can be rough at times, but I believe that it's better than our competitors.

headline: quantitative, challenging, time consuming
pros: flexible approach to projects, possibility to grow fast, exposition to client, different kinds of projects, strong positioning in energy issues and consumer goods
cons: not strong defense of brand positioning in Italy, not enough investment on young resources, low positioning in banks, staffing processes dependent upon senior management and not on HR

headline: Impeccable Corporate Culture
pros: Outstanding people to work with and for! I do not personally have any issues with anyone or the company itself. Bain truly expresses their corporate culture and have stuck by it in my opinion. Always willing to lend a helping hand and very open environment where you can ask anyone whether you have a question or concern.
cons: For some there may be long hours at times, but you work hard and do your job and the reward is greater than the time put in.

headline: Bain London
pros: Great training and people; flexible; first rate brand name; exit opportunities; mentorship; global opportunities
cons: Poor lifestyle; pay mediocre given levels of expectation; lack of proper pension scheme

headline: Best Place
pros: People and culture of the firm
cons: Everything is fine with the firm

headline: excellent place to start your career
pros: Really supportive of any career even if you are leaving Bain. They have great training programs and everyone is very friendly and helpful. They are willing to give a lot of responsibility to even new hires and trust their hiring process
cons: Relatively homogenous culture. Some cases are much busier than others and while on average work hours are pretty reasonable at some weeks hours can be a little long

headline: Stimulating work, nurturing environment, and fun people
pros: You get to work on interesting business strategy problems for senior management across a range of industries. The company also places a lot of emphasis on professional development as well as work/life balance. The people make for a fun and collaborative environment and there are frequent fun events!
cons: Sometimes cases can be poorly scoped, requiring consistently long hours, but this is not common. Otherwise, nothing besides the general cons of the profession: occasional long hours and travel that require flexibility but which can be enjoyable if you like variety.

headline: Incredible place to learn and start a career
pros: Geting the opportunity to help businesses tackle their biggest problems is exciting, and I genuinely like the people that I work with. Robust feedback systems make sure that you are constantly developing as a professional, and although you may not be comfortable, you are always learning.
cons: Sometimes there are long hours with no clearly visible payoff - it makes it worth it when you see the effect you are having on clients, though.

headline: A great place to work if you want to be a Strategy Consultant
pros: Great training ground, excellent global training programs at every level from AC to Partner.  Opportunity to form global professional networks and friendships.  Smart and motivated co-workers who tend to be extremely collaborative and helpful.  Strong learnings and exposure to a breadth of business challenges. Excellent benefits and compensation (relative to industry jobs, not finance jobs).
cons: Like all other top consulting firms, the hours and travel can be very demanding. Stress levels can run high. It's difficult to establish a normal life schedule during the week because a new project may mean being on the road 4 days a week. People often describe themselves as feeling "on call".  The Bain culture is known to be quite conformist and emphasizes work hard / play hard -- this may or may not be for you.

headline: Mixed
pros: Good learning for everyone in company
cons: No work life balance for everyone working here

headline: Unique experience that rewards employees in all dimensions combined (hard/soft skills, compensation, personal, etc.)
pros: You can learn a lot, within the business consultant toolkit but also about client realtionship and teamplay; you will always have someone at your side ready to help you out on your tasks and people that do share same culture and interests; Besides, you'll be at a great spot if you decide to leave to other company at any time of your career
cons: The cons are not that different from any other big consulting firm - The work/life balance is pressured, as in any other high demanding organization; As a big consulting firm, you can sometimes be assigned to tasks or clients that are not that sexy - it means not necessairly all of your cases will be a huge strategy definition on a top company worldwide

headline: Great experience, wonderful learning experience
pros: Training, culture, benefits, flexibility, people focus, clients
cons: Work life balance, travel to clients

headline: Bain's culture is amazing - it fosters learning, fun and humility
pros:
1) Develop unique 1-on-1 relationship with supervisor and supervisee: the mentoring and learning opportunities are amazing and working so closely with down to earth, smart and fun people is very humbling
2) Develop great group relationship: Bain promotes an amazing "family-like" culture. Most people really live up to the moto "A Bainie will never let another Bainie fail"
cons: Demanding work and respect for other team members often lead to a will to over deliver. It's on us to remain ourselves that work-life balance is a priority.

headline: Great people, fun work, and exceptional learning experience
pros: Highly competitive compensation. Great place to learn both soft and hard skills to excel in business setting. Many mentors to look up to and learn best practices
cons: Sometimes, work-life balance maybe unpredictable but then you do get enough unstaffed time to rest

headline: Fun and rewarding learning experience
pros: Co-workers are intelligent, friendly, and very helpful-I honestly think we have the best people of any firm in any industry; We do interesting work that (as far as I have seen) leads to great outcomes for our clients; Chance to learn about many different industries and build valuable skills; Great exit opportunities if/when you decide to leave
cons: Work/life balance varies heavily by client and manager and can be bad in certain situations; regional staffing model does not facilitate as much travel as BCG or McKinsey's national staffing models do (this could be a pro for some people)

headline: Great culture and high level of mangement engagement
pros:
High level of management investment in mentoring and professional development
Great company culture and employees
Relatively short time on each case which results in a diversity of experience and constantly new and exciting problems to tackle
cons:
What the client wants you to work on isn't always the most fascinating topic
Work-life balance varies greatly depending on manager and client

headline: Interesting work and extremely fun culture
pros: Bain provides fantastic colleagues, interesting projects in varied industries, incredible professional development and a strong support structure, not to mention unparalleled exit opportunities. I feel incredibly lucky to be a Bainie.
cons: The hours can be long at times but that is the nature of client work, plus it balances out throughout the life of a case. At times I wish I had a bit more control over my staffing, but appreciate that I am pushed to try new things.

headline: Great place to develop and have fun
pros:
Very supportive culture. Firm provides multiple resources for advice, professional development, and mentorship throughout your career. 

High impact at every level of the organization. Each individual has the opportunity to contirbute to tangible results for our clients, local communities and colleagues in the office.
cons: Work hours can be long and highly variable. Also compensation and promotion should be more merit based and flexible.

headline: Incredible start to my career
pros: The open, welcoming, and fun culture allows me to truly be myself and to succeed by focusing on and enjoying my work without having to worry about perceptions, competitiveness, and other distractions. The operating principles of 'presume trust' and 'be open, honest, and direct' embody the Bain experience and have helped me develop in my personal life, as well as in my professional life. The step-up opportunities for someone just out of undergrad are incredible: the level of client exposure I had within my first six months is way more than I could've hoped for. Perhaps the best part, besides the people, is the seriousness with which professional development is taken. I learn something new every day, and that's absolutely invaluable to me. I feel confident in my work and in my trajectory knowing that I have a full team of mentors, guides, and peers here to support me. What truly encapsulates all of  for me is that I unquestioningly refer to Bainies as my friends, not my colleagues.
cons: Lifestyle, as with any consulting job, can be demanding and tough.

headline: Best place to work - for many, many reasons
pros: The people - the recruiting process is extremely successful in finding the right Bain fit. For some, that's not the right fit, and they likely do not pursue the job (and/or are not given an offer). For others, like myself, it is the most attractive aspect of the firm, and largest differentiator for Bain among its competitors. The work is great, and the clients are all top level, and both of those categories are equal to peer companies. But its the people that make Bain really stand out.
cons: Can have some large peaks and valleys in hours; seemingly more peaks than you would like; travel can wear on you after a while (though Bain does do the best job among companies I've seen in reducing the travel required)

headline: Great place to start your career
pros:
Great culture, great people, fun place to work - 800 people showed up for our global soccer tournament in Dallas- how many companies would 40 Australians show up for a weekend soccer tournament in Dallas?
Best job for people straight out of undergrad- really launches your career and gives you a broad business prospective
Senior leadership take a vested interest in associates
Lots of opportunities to do non-profit work including volunteering consulting teams
Opportunity to transfer to another office in your 3rd year for six months
cons: Strong face time culture, lots of variability in hours because of client service industry

headline: A special sauce of blow-you-away culture and ferocious intelligence
pros: The AC job at Bain and Company NY is the best job in the world out of undergrad. Full stop. The training you receive is unparalleled, the people are the coolest, kindest, most interesting people you could hope to befriend, and the brand name opens doors all over the world. Your colleagues will challenge you to be better without ever being cutthroat (no one discusses ratings, ever), and in many cases will be your main social group outside of work - not out of necessity, but by choice.
cons: The work is hard, the hours are long, and you don't get paid as much overall as a banker. If you're young and don't have a family, that shouldn't be an issue for your first few years though.

headline: Hard work, poor value proposition
pros: The people are consistently awesome. Great sense of humour, intelligence, integrity, ethics. The perks are also phenomenal - health insurance, good salary, plenty of fun and social opportunities
cons:
The hours can be very long, doing very stupid stuff on the request of clients
I didn't feel there was as much of a mentorship culture as they sell in recruiting, I felt that I was hung out to dry when the going got tough
Type of work almost feels deceitful in that it is often quite simple, but charged out at phenomenal rates and packaged nicely

headline: Combination of work and dedicated mentors provides great foundation for any future career
pros: Good review system, people/culture are great
cons: Long hours, travel, day-to-day work is not always exciting

headline: best job after undergrad
pros: amazing culture, people development, learn different industries, can transfer to different geos
cons: long hours, hard work, travel every week

headline: Great place to work with focus on the people
pros:
Great people culture.  It is the people who makes this company great
Challenging work, but fun
cons: Not much to say.  The company is very focused on the people and culture

headline: Generally good culture but people are increasingly getting driven to the ground
pros:
Overall the culture (in comparison to BCG/McKinsey from what I gather) is great - mostly great people, fun and open work place. I have come across some bad apples though, they do exist even at firms like Bain but generally people are smart and genuine.

There is so much flexibility to pursue things your want - leave of absences, international office transfers, externships are all common and a nice way to give you a break from consulting if you need it (you probably will).

Needless to say the skill set you develop and the speed at which you develop it is invaluable.
cons:
There seems to be a trend for people to work longer hours, the 55-hour average week doesn't exist. Overscoped/underresourced projects are more common than not and everyone I know has been driven to the ground on multiple projects. Working in consulting builds a great skill set but it comes at a cost - practically no work/life balance during the week unless you are happy seeing more of Bain than family/friends etc. It can be really cliquey and there are people who have few friends beyond Bain.

Compared to corporate salaries, consulting salaries don't appear competitive given how hard you work, however you need the skill set to transition to corporates.

headline: Learning experience
pros: Excellent place to gain insight into multiple industries, great place to work
cons: travel, long hours given intense ramping up steep learning curve, but hey, that's also a plus!

headline: I've had a great few years at Bain - great people, supportive environment and the world's top companies business issues
pros: Bain is a great organisation; the people are smart, friendly and motivated (walk into any office worldwide and they all feel like Bain offices), the environment is supportive and people genuinely want to help you out, and we wok with many of the worlds biggest companies to help them solve interesting and challenging business isues
cons: Like all consulting firms the hours can be long, but Bain does try and help everyone manage this in a variety of ways. I've been constantly stretched which is great for learning but can be a bit tiring after a while!

headline: Good place to start
pros: Company values for next step, Mentoring, Training, Case experience (case by case)
cons: Working hour, some leadership problem

headline: Tough place to work if you come in senior
pros: Great learning experience, with a strong brand that will help you going forward. Phenomenal job if you are a recent graduate.
cons: Very insular culture, with little room for outside ideas. Difficult place to work if you have ever worked before.

headline: Awesome place to work
