pros: Overall great place to work
cons: No Cons that I can think of

headline: All depends on the particular cases you work on and the partners you work for
pros: Supportive colleagues, opportunity to develop meaningful relationships with clients, interesting cases/adventurous travel, fun firm culture and traditions, excellent benefits.
cons: Some cases are so intense they literally take over your life and you only have time for Bain, firm not flexible in approaches to the work, firm does not allow you to specialize in an industry until the Manager level.

headline: Great culture and a good place to work..
pros: Flexible hours. The bosses are not clock-watcher but i am part of the non-consulting staff.
cons: Fast pace of life which will take a couple months to be used to.

headline: Great place
pros: Really interesting work and you're surrounded by great people.  Exit opps are as good as they come, but I don't really see any reason to leave.  Culture is fun and supportive, and building great relationships is very easy here.
cons: Travel lifestyle is better than some other top firms because of the local staffing model, but still can wear on you.  Hours can be grueling but rough patches never last too long.

headline: people oriented culture
pros: flexible career paths, no cut in salary when changing segments
cons: not as aggressive as Mck tec., so not for those who want a fast track career

headline: Awesome place to work
pros: Really strong training and exit opportunities
cons: Difficult lifestyle, day-to-day work sometimes grueling

headline: Amazing place to really open opportunities
pros:
There are a lot of reasons why Bain is a wonderful place to work:
-Top notch training programs
-Amazing and inspirational people
-Great compensation for the work you do
-Ability to transfer to other offices
-Zero politics before Manager level
-Varied and interesting work
cons:
Some of the main challenges of working at Bain:
-It can be hard to strike a balance between work and personal life, but the company tries to do what they can to help.  Really depends on the case you're on and the manager you're working for.
-Not everyone at the top (Partners/Directors) are aligned with our working principles (especially transfers from other firms) which sometimes translates into uncomfortable conversations around where priorities are between family and work
-If someone demonstrates ability within a certain capability/industry some Partners will unofficially 'ringfence' them into their teams, making it difficult to get broad exposure
-Smaller offices sometimes find it hard to really buy-into all the flexibility options available to the wider organisation (transfers, LOAs, etc.)

headline: Positive atmosphere
pros: Great people to work with, always willing to  share and to learn. Bain hires the best available people, and it shows. This company offers an opportunity to work in a worldwide marketplace on many diverse projects. The company atmosphere is extremely fun, with a definite work hard play hard feeling. Bain finds many ways to help in the community as well
cons: Hard to set one's  self apart with so many talented colleagues.

headline: Part-time Associate
pros: fast-paced but very rewarding experience
cons: longer working hours until midnight

headline: The BEST place to work
pros: As others have said, this place is full of amazing people.  Interesting, high-impact work.  There is no better place to start your career.
cons: Hours can be long but it is possible to create a sustainable lifestyle

headline: The best job I've ever had
pros: I am an Executive Assistant and absolutely love it. There is a tremendous investment on people here at Bain. That's important to feel especially in a support staff role. I feel empowered, encouraged and valued in my role. The work is always changing, and that keeps it fun and exciting. The focus on work life balance is unlike anything I've ever seen for EAs. Also, there are opportunities galore - if you are interested in learning a different industry - be it HR, IT, Recruiting, Marketing, etc, they take those desires seriously and will work to place you in that space.
cons: Securing conference room space is getting difficult because we are growing so much!

headline: My company values my work and creates an platform to constantly learn and grow.
pros: Learning scope, Work enviornment, People who invests in your development, work and life balance and last but not least the fun time/party time.
cons: Well maintaining office time here in India office and then getting back to the calls for projects in the evening... kind of at times kilss the whole day. Practically one would be working whole day.

headline: Awesome place to work!
pros: As a part of the Shared Services team at Bain, I am a strong promoter. The work culture and work-life balance of teams here is much better than the other organizations I have worked with. Employees feel valued and broad based benefits that are provided here are great. Most importantly, working at Bain is FUN :)
cons: I think the biggest challenge for shared-services employees is career progression and lack of a defined career path. A structured performance based growth plan is missing for most shared services teams.

headline: Dynamic and challenging learning environment with top-notch people to support you
pros: People are engaged, smart and interested. Projects and teams are focused on results and driving real impact. You'll take on work that allows you to grow and learn and realize that you are learning a lot along the way. There are countless opportunities for advancement and growth (for your position, office).
cons: Almost everyone is time constrained and focused on results, so this creates a constant flow of work that is never done and can pile up.

headline: Great place to start career in consulting
pros: Nice culture, interesting cases, solid leadership
cons: Hours, travel, uneven mentoring, unable to specialize for several years

headline: Great experience that I would recommend to anyone coming out of school
pros: Excellent learning experience. Great people. Great business experience that has and I believe will continue to pay dividends in my professional life.
cons: Exhausting schedule if traveling. Not always the flexibility to work on the types of cases you wanted to work on. Potential to have an unbalanced case load. There a few people that I have in mind that were consistently staffed on bad cases (long hours, unattractive travel, difficult CTL, etc.) and others that were consistently staffed on good ones.

headline: Consultant
pros: Very case heavy - no different case structures
cons: Must be very structured in thinking

headline: Absolutely amazing place to start your career!
pros: Bain is an incredible place to start your career out of college and continue to build a career.  The learning opportunities are unparalled; over 3 years as an AC/SAC you get incredible exposure and learning.  The people are amazing- genuine, inspiring, devoted and caring.  The culture is fantastic- fun, supportive.  "A Bainie never lets another Bainie fail" is definitely true!  Returning as a Consultant post-MBA (with Bain sponsorship) was equally rewarding.  As a college senior, I never thought I'd still be at the same firm, but I can't imagine working elsewhere!
cons: Hours can be long but this is typical of consulting, and the travel options are better than elsewhere.

headline: Best place for top business talent with inspiring people to work with
pros: Bain has been a fantastic place to build a career.  The two years I'd planned to stay at Bain have since turned into 12 years.  The reasons I've stayed:  Great learning and career trajectory.  I started on the client facing side, but have now moved into a non-client facing position.  On both sides I've been continually challenged to learn and grow.  The people here are 2nd to none, inspiring role models and friends.  They are bright, talented, and engaged in making Bain a great place to work, with great trust and mutual respect.  I've also found flexibility in my career where I've needed it (e.g., working part time when my youngest child was little...)
cons: We pride ourselves in maintaining a lean operating model and cost structure, which means that teams can feel very stretched or resource-constrained.

headline: Intense fun
pros:
People: Incredibly intelligent, inspiring, fun, teamwork-oriented people
Work: Lot of exposure to upper management
Culture: Down-to-earth; never take themselves too seriously; "A Bainie never lets another Bainie fail" culture
cons:
Not as international as McKinsey (most cases staffed within the country)
Although better compared to some other firms in this industry, still long hours.

headline: Amazing company, challenging work
pros:
-Wonderful, smart, and driven co-workers
-Lots of client exposure at the junior and senior levels
-Extraordinary professional growth
cons:
-Long hours - it varies by case, but it can get up to 95 hours if getting close to a big meeting
-Frequent travel - most cases in the DC office involve travel, but that should be changing as the office grows

headline: Associate Consultant
pros:
- Great mentorship and focus on professional development. Everyone you work genuinely wants you to do well.
- They invest a lot in you for training.
- Great people and culture. Particularly in the Toronto office, it feels very close-knit.
cons:
- Long hours and lack of sustainable work/life balance.
- Lack of clarity in staffing and opportunities to work in specific industries that you are interested in

headline: Awesome people, great learning environment and impact.
pros:
The people you work with
The topics you work on
cons: Hard job with high work load

headline: Bain is a great place to work
pros: In consulting, "the product is the people." Bain invests an enormous amount into developing its people. The formal training programs are great, but it's more than that. There is a culture of frequent "real time" feedback which is reinforced by formal reviews twice a year. The learning curve is steep and expectations are high, so you gain skills fast. You also get to work with great people who are not only smart/capable but humble, friendly, and caring.
cons: Management consulting is a demanding career. Bain does try hard to maintain sustainable work life balance, but you can't be client-facing at Bain and have a 9-to-5 job.

headline: Amazing workplace with stellar exit options
pros:
Bain is the best place to work as a young professional interested in learning about business in a holistic way -- from the nuts and bolts of getting organisations moving towards a goal and implementing a program to defining the overall strategic direction for any/every type of corporation.

The culture at Bain is also truly exceptional -- rewarding, meritocratic and collegiate all at the same time.
cons: Long work hours. In some cases/projects, can be very long, extending upwards of 100 hours a week.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Great culture and interesting projects. The company genuinely cares about the professional development of junior professionals. Very collegial working environment and you become friends with many of your colleagues
cons: It can frustrating at times that consultants are in an advisory role. Ultimately, it is up to the client to decide what to do with your recommendations. But this is applies to all the consulting firms out there

headline: Great place, great people
pros: Phenomenal location, and the senior management is brilliant and funny. While my engagement with Bain was short, I loved working at this company, and felt that the Milan office at least wasn't as cut throat as what colleagues told me from McK, and BCG
cons: Sometimes too much politicking, like with all consulting jobs the hours weren't that stellar and a lot of the engagements were in backwoods parts of Europe.

headline: Admin Side job
pros: Good culture, lots of perks intended for consulting side that admin can enjoy as well
cons: two class system - admin & consultants

headline: Bain is the best place to work I know of, considering both my past experiences and my peers in the industry
pros: The greatest thing about Bain is the people with whom I work with and also the variety of different professional experiences I am exposed to on a daily basis. I get to work with top management of the largest and most interesting companies in the world, from a diversity of industries and functional areas. Bain also offers targeted training sessions for all consultants on a yearly basis, which is certainly differential. And on top of that, I am able to pursue other kinds of activities that interest me and help me develop even more my professional career.
cons: Sometimes, on a few specific projects, work can be heavy, with long hours in the office to finish a presentation or piece of analysis, but all the effort is offset by the great people I get the chance to work with and the learning that happens in the process.

headline: Intense
pros: Food is for free, including drinks
cons: Expect to work days and night

headline: People. Passion. Results.  It's true to the core.  Great culture and environment to work in!
pros: The people. Challenging work assignments. High-caliber of talent in the organization. Collaborative work environment.  Play hard, work hard mentality.
cons: High-stress levels given performance measures. Long hours.  Not a ton of upward mobility in administrative departments.

headline: Great place to start your career
pros:
You learn a lot even in your first year. It'll never stop challenging you as you are always working on different problems.
The team members are one of the smartest people you will ever work with. That being said, they are so down to earth that you'll want to spend time with them even on weekends.
cons: Work-life balance can be very hard to maintain in this career. Work is very unpredictable and it is hard to know how your life is going to be a week or two in advance.

headline: super good peopel, good supervisor. consultants are clever, efficient, smart, fun, passionate, hard working. good office
pros: fun, passionate, very very very high salary compared with competitiors, good office decoration, beautiful staff
cons: hard working, long hours, DD

headline: Amazing place to work and learn before you get burnt out
pros: Amazing people work at Bain. Smart, dedicated and humble coworkers make going in to the office everyday a joy.
cons: Professional services does not create for a sustainable lifestyle and despite all its attempts, Bain doesn't do a good job balancing the load for individuals, particularly the best employees. The joke of "hiring insecure perfectionists" is somewhat true and exploited. Bain burns out the best and relies on the culture to keep people around.

headline: Work on interesting and important problems with great people. Very quick learning of broad skillset
pros:
Fantastic training and personal development
Talented and relaxed people to work with
Relatively fewer hours and less travel than other consulting firms
Work on important problems for Fortune 500 companies
cons: Current client list heavy with huge companies doing multi-year transformations. Not ideal if you want to see the tangible difference you personally made

headline: Senior Associate Consultant
pros: Smart people working on interesting problems
cons: Very long hours and unpredictable weekends

headline: Great Place to Work
pros: This company really works hard to make its employees feel that they are apart of a greater whole, like a giant international family. The employees here work hard and also play hard.
cons: Due to the fact that the company is rapidly growing, the idea of a familiar, inclusive workforce can be forgotten at times. The company also struggles to find a way to make its admin staff feel as included and driven as the rest of the consultant employee body.

headline: Great place to work in
pros: Great working atmosphere, fantastic training, great experiences and a strong focus on client results and delivery
cons: Not necessarily the most meritocratic; limited global mobility and can at time be political

headline: "This opportunity/company is way over-hyped -- a lot of fuss for very meaningless work."
pros: - Ability to get an interview almost anywhere after
cons:
- Long hours/always on call for very trivial tasks -- very inefficient work environment
- Low client interaction at Associate Consultant level
- Work for a new MBA instead of a more experienced manager or partner 
- I've seen so many people cry at work in < 2 years here and within a year almost everyone wants to quit
- Cultish environment - the people here are followers not leaders at all
- People at top (partners) are essentially sales people so a very "salesy" organization

headline: Intensive working hour
pros: you can meet very smart people there
cons: the working hour is really bad

headline: Great training, great people...long hours, high stress...lots and lots of slides
pros: Great people and great training. You learn a lot very quickly and gain access to many industries and functions. Great job for those are new to business / management and don't know where they want to specialize.
cons: Hours are long and arduous with high stress. Culture can be disheartening at times, and varies across offices (the west (e.g. SF) has the best culture (most supportive and constructive)...the culture in Europe & NYC can be more cut throat).

headline: Great place to start your career
pros: Learn a lot, smart people, interesting cases
cons: You are still a generalist at the end of the day

headline: Top-notch employment opportunity.  Great long-term career or training ground for line management positions.
pros: Results-focused, team-oriented, inclusive, compassionate, always at the top of best places to work lists.  Truly a special place for a wide variety of people.
cons: Hard place to get a job.  Can be challenging work, sometimes unpredictable client needs

headline: Best job you could ask for post-college
pros: Learn a ton, work on clients' most important problems, gain the 'consultant toolkit', awesome exit opportunities no matter what you want to do, great people who care a ton about helping you succeed
cons: Work can become very process oriented and feel less impactful at times.  Sometimes too little effort is put into fully understanding industry and company context.  Culture can be a little overbearing (e.g. pressure to have all three meals together every day).

headline: A good (not the best) place to begins one's career, especially for undergraduate candidates
pros:
Aggressive professional development
Talented colleagues
Interesting projects (generally)
Generalist model ensures you won't get pigeon-holed
cons:
Lifestyle isn't great (project dependent)
Good career opportunities (definitely not as good as McKinsey)
Access to industry verticals are driven by office location given regional staffing model
Candidates have almost no say in project staffing

headline: Excellent place to learn with smart and fun co-workers
pros:
Strong culture of mentorship and learning pervades most day-to-day activities. There is a consistent focus to make sure employees are developing the skills they need to succeed.

Variety of industry coverage and practice area capabilities. Regardless of particular area of interest, chances are the opportunity to work in it will pop up at some point.

The people, can not emphasize enough how much this impacts the experience
cons: The hours can get a bit long at times, and there is the potential for the experience to vary based on the cases assigned (i.e. working at only one company, vs. working at many)

headline: Great Company, not for Everyone
pros: Overall, I had a great experience at Bain.  The quality of the people is fantastic and learning environment is great.  Particularly for folks starting their careers, Bain provides a great, no nonsense introduction to business.  The fact-based and numbers-driven approach to consulting is
cons: The leverage model leads to a lot of very junior people carrying the bulk of the workload.  This sometimes led to fairly shallow analyses of the client's business.  People tended to stick to the playbook rather than thinking deeply about the client's industry and specific challenges.  This works very well when looking for cost reductions/efficiency, but fails when looking at go to market strategy.

headline: More focus on presentation than real work
pros: Good Brand to have on your CV, Smart People hired from the best places
cons: Bad Lifestyle, 50% of time is spent on formatting and presentation readiness than real analysis.

headline: Bain are for Bainies
pros: Strong culture with sense of belonging and community. There is one way of doing things - the Bain way. Strong standardisation, one approach to problem solving - follow the process and an answer will emerge, no need for thought leadership or creativity at junior levels, ability to manage and orchestrate a process most important. All training, does not matter level follows same logistics and set up. Incredible strong brand and lots of parties, Friday drinks, summer, winter, theme parties, run up to X-mas...seemless continuation of college.
cons: The Bain way is the only way (sometimes that means using dated systems, tools and ways of doing things). Bain is 1., 2. and 3. priority and you have to become a Bainie. Your life is Bain. There is negative bashing of competitors on events, in meetings...all to uphold Bain and strengthen culture. Little room to be different, think differently, or question. Women's agenda is way behind, there is a fair share of female partners, but no real role models or female partners with power, more figure heads... Strong Good news culture, everything is talked up, storytelling rules the Bain world,...every Bainie believes they work for the best company in the world, most have never experienced anything else and the culture and doctrine tells them one thing..."Bain is the best firm".

headline: Great culture & challenging work - ideal place to start your career
pros: culture, people, quick learning guaranteed, skills acquired are sought-after in the job market, company events and trainings are really fun
cons: pay and benefits is only ok compared to competitors, unpredictable hours and travelling, career loses attractiveness about 5 years in

headline: Great place to learn
pros: people are fantastic. great culture
cons: long hours. certain cases are not great

headline: Best consulting company to work for.
pros: Great culture and teams. Firmly believe it is the best consulting company to work for.
cons: Consulting generally has poor work and life balance.  Bain is working on it. But, it is still not easy.

headline: Great people, lots of learning
pros:
The people and culture at Bain are what sets it apart - incredibly talented, well-rounded, and down-to-earth... work hard - play hard
It's an incredible place to start your career in business out of undergrad (or b school)
cons: Consulting lifestyle isn't for everyone

headline: Great smart people and challenging environment where you will learn a lot.
pros: You are surrounded by smart and accomplished people, they take mentoring and development seriously, and you work on variety of interesting projects.
cons: Be prepared to work hard - there can be long hours and travel but that comes with this kind of job.

headline: Genuine company.
pros: Company truly invests in its people. All employees from all backgrounds and departments et along, converse and have each other's backs.
cons: Some departments are slightly overstaffed and management style needs improvement as far as deligating direction to it's team.

headline: Fantastic place to work and gain a business training
pros: Great business training.  Real focus on training both formal and informal.  Very proud of the work done during my eight years there.  Fantastic people and team
cons: Hard work.  Long hours at times however considerate of personal needs.

headline: Great place to learn a wide variety of skills
pros: Fun and friendly environment, world class training, wide variety of projects, opportunities for travel and short-term global transfer are quite plentiful to high performers
cons: Offices are sometimes isolated from each other despite being a "global firm" and it can be difficult to transfer permanently/across international borders

headline: Great company
pros: Smart People, lots of incentives, they do a great job to help you have a good work-life balance considering the hours that are worked.
cons: It's not always stimulating in this position. Work comes in waves and more often than not, I'm not really excited about my work.

headline: Great company to work for
pros: Supportive and friendly atmosphere in the company
cons: Travel can be tiring at times

headline: The ultimate post HBS business school
pros:
Understand how to develop and execute business strategy at the highest level
Get as close to operating a company at the C Level as an advisor
Confidence to solve the hardest business problems in the world
Network of the next generation of business leaders
cons:
Not for anyone trying to balance their life
Travel can be insane
Starting to be more like McKinsey than the old Bain

headline: Great place to work!
pros: The culture and people are amazing.
cons: Limited opportunities on the administrative side of the business.

headline: Incredible learning in a challenging, supportive environment with the best colleagues
pros: Interesting work. Smart people. Change-oriented clients. Collaborative atmosphere. Best colleagues. In general, I have found Bain to be a great place to build my career over the past five years. I look at external opportunities, and haven't found anything to be as remotely compelling as continuing here. And, when I look at the competition - I think that we work with a broad, diverse client set on their most challenging issues, and that we really partner with them to make sure they can implement what we recommend. And, not to be cliche about Bain, but the colleagues and relationships I've built have been phenomenal. I know these people are the ones I'll be in touch with 20 years from now, on a personal and/or professional basis.
cons: Despite working hand-in-hand with our clients to enact change, we aren't actually responsible for making the decision and sometimes that is very hard to accept...especially when they don't end up doing what you think would be best.

headline: Bain is a great place to work, if you don't have a family
pros: The people are wonderful and you will learn a ton. And  you'll get a great job when you leave.
cons: The travel and hours are brutal if you have a family. If not, they're still tough, but probably pretty manageable

headline: Rough at first, rewards later
pros: Great culture and post-Bain opportunities
cons: Unpredictable work-life balance, occasionally tedious work

headline: Smart, passionate people; probably the best of the big three if you want to do consulting
pros:
- Smart, passionate people, who really care about each other and their work
- Very much a culture of "work hard, play hard", with senior partners just as ready to let loose and have fun as the new associate consultants
- Culture focuses on helping each other, and succeeding as a team, yet still acts as a meritocracy for rewarding performance; meritocratic comp becomes more pronounced at more senior levels
cons:
- Long hours are often part of the game at management consulting firms; anecdotally Bain is the best of the top 3, but the whole industry isn't the place for those looking to work 9-to-5
- You will live in PowerPoint. Except when you're living in Excel.
- High pressure, demanding schedule. You may love that, or it may grind you down. Probably both.

headline: The best place to start and develop your career
pros: Great culture, great people, enormous development opportunities
cons: Working hours are long. Sometimes very long

headline: Associate consultant intern
pros: very smart people, godd compensation, amazing work environment, very rewarding and motivating job
cons:
expect rather long hours, 
travel can be a pain, comp could be higher

headline: World class platform to develop yourself into a change-oriented leader
pros:
- Pragmatic approach that designs and executes results that stick
- People who team well and operate with the utmost integrity
- Optimal blend of global scale with continued growth opportunities
- Flexible platform over the course of your career
- Very attractive economics
cons: - Demanding career, but people attracted to Bain are ambitious by nature. You'll work hard wherever you go, because that's who you are. Might as well benefit from a more impactful and rewarding career if you're going to put in the hours anyways.

headline: Work hard, play hard. A great culture in a job very demanding from an intellectual point of view
pros:
- A real team spirit
- Working with some of the brightest minds you will ever meet
- A very efficient alumni network
cons:
- Work life balance is hard on the long run, although much better than investment banking
- Only work for big companies

headline: An exceptional place to work
pros:
-Work on the world's toughest business problems
-Variety in work due to case based model - opportunity for depth (industry or capability expertise) or breadth (variety of industries/business problems)
-Training and development is outstanding (formal and informal training and mentoring/coaching) - a true career accelerator
-Apprenticeship model - senior leadership invests to make junior folks successful
-Very international - opportunities to work around the world
-Fun colleagues
cons:
-Travel can be frequent
-Hours can be long

headline: Great launching pad for career
pros: Great training, talented colleagues, high investment in people, good compensation
cons: unpredictable lifestyle, job can change dramatically each time you change projects (different lifestyle, different boss, different clients)

headline: Can't imagine a company that treats their employees better
pros: Partnering with C-suite execs who look to us for advice adn help with their most difficult issues. Working with people who are brilliant and interesting, know how to have a good time, laugh at work, and help colleagues be successful. Compensation is very good, and gets high very quickly if you stick around. You are generally not forced to do things - the system is actually built around letting people make their own decisions about their career and path within Bain and thereafter..
cons: Stretches of long hours, travel, and high stress... but you know that going in!

headline: Great opportunities to build formative career experiences and get the support/mentorship to succeed along the way
pros: Get to work on challenging and interesting problems.  Work with senior executives who have the ability to change the course of their business and often shape the overall industry.  Great firm culture and interesting/fun colleagues.
cons: Client service business that can have long and sometimes unpredictable hours, as well as the potential for high travel.

headline: Very self-rewarding experience
pros: Bain offers you fantastic opportunities for professional development, with exciting projects and constant learning. You are surrounded by some of the smartest people in a truly collaborative environment. On top of that it has in place a series of checks and balances to make sure the life-style is as manageable as it can be for a professional services firm
cons: Although the work is possitively challenging, it sometimes involves long hours and regional travel

headline: Amazing place accelerate a career
pros:
Extremely high-impact, challenging, and interesting work
C-suite access and ability to drive change
Amazing training, professional development, support
Great people
Values align with what is important to me
cons: Job is intense - sometimes hours can be long

headline: Best place to work!
pros: Bain has an incredible culture and truly cares about its employees and their experience!  Every day, we're surrounded by smart and creative colleagues.  You will never find better people to work with anywhere, period.
cons: Expectations and hours are high - this is drives some people and not others.

headline: Fantastic company Im so proud to work for
pros: The People. Hands down the people.  And the type of work and impact we get to have with our clients.  I work on some of the most interesting, cutting edge issues in Healthcare today and look forward to heading into work every morning.
cons: We work hard and we must remain very flexible to serve the needs of our clients.

headline: Still the best place to grow and learn
pros: Fantastic work environment, strong company culture, smart and fun people, access to game-changing work and the resources to deliver that work. Bain still is the best place to be in consulting. Firm is going from strength to strength in its financial performance. The upside of being in an environment with this much growth is you can control for the quality of the projects the firm takes on. As a result, I find myself going from one fascinating challenge to another. Have been at it 10+ years and feel like the learning curve continues to remain steep.
cons: Consulting is just a hard job - hours, travel and pressure of being in front of a client remain the big challenges in this job. That's not going to be firm dependent, but is the reality of the industry.

headline: Remarkable culture, personal development, and impact
pros: Working with smart, passionate people who will inspire and challenge you... this describes both the Bainies and the clients we tend to work with over the long term.
cons: As much as the firm tries to support flexibility in an effort to make the job more susatinable... hours are long, time off is ratem and your schedule is unpredictable. This is a hard job on families.

headline: Great learning opportunity
pros: The learning, culture, and results focus is great. It keeps me motivated and excited to work at Bain
cons: Travel can be burdensome especially on longer duration projects

headline: An amazing, life-changing experience
pros: Working with smart, talented, interesting, yet humble people; working on difficult and important questions; getting exposure to so many companies, industries, and functions; great exit options
cons: Although Bain takes a very active stance in making this job sustainable, there are times when we need to work hard to deliver for our clients.  I think this is common across the consulting industry and any fast-paced career.

headline: My best self
pros: I have the privilege of getting up every day and working on client problems that truly matter.  The challenge is immense, but I love helping specific individuals at my client to succeed and seeing the collective results of our work together.  At every turn I am supported by a team of Bainies at my side.  We are a team, and we team with our clients.  Every year I think about whether Bain is the best place for me to continue to reach my personal full potential (across all dimensions -- career, personal, family), and every year I choose to stay at Bain.  I know I am having an impact and am developing into the best person I can be -- as a business leader, colleague, wife and mother.
cons: Having an engaging and worthwhile career means making some trade-offs.  I travel 2-3 nights a week on average, and I work hard.  However, I do not believe I work any harder than my business school classmates who are also career track/high potentials.

headline: Drive real changes to solve big problems, while learning a ton and having a clear career path
pros:
- Interesting, impactful work: There is rarely a boring day, much less a boring project. The problems we're solving are usually what's written in the WSJ about our client - big, complicated challenges, often challenges that are leading issues for that entire industry.  And my clients regularly tell me (over many years now) that they would have missed huge opportunities or never driven the required changes successfully without our help.

- Continuous learning curve: The people above you really want you to be successful and offer a ton of valuable coaching and feedback.  You are constantly improving yourself.  And those skills will be valuable no matter where you go - you get really good, for example, at separating what matters from what does not, or at making difficult changes happen in complex organizations.  

- Great people: You have incredibly smart and interesting collegues.  Yet they're also collaborative, supportive, and relatively down to earth for folks with fancy degrees.

- Smoothly-functioning meritocracy:  There's so much less office politics and similar nonsense that you experience at so many companies, even well-regarded ones.  At Bain the people who deserve to get promoted get promoted, you get more responsibility as soon as you're ready, most everyone gets along well with each other, and the pay and benefits are consistent and generally very good.
cons: - Lifestyle can be challenging:  First the positive - there is more scope to manage your lifestyle than many people think.  Once I've gotten comfortable in a role at a given level in Bain, I've found I can create great results for clients in 50-55 hours a week.  However, when you first join or when you are shifting to a role with more responsibility, it's probably more like 70 until you learn how to do it right.  And you can never completely avoid the travel, the unpredictable client requests, checking email regularly even when not working, etc.  Client service can be a tough business and despite a lot of effort and good intention Bain hasn't cracked that nut yet.  If you really enjoy this job, though, you CAN make it work - it's possible if not always easy.

headline: Fantastic professional development, tremendous opportunities to have an impact, collaborative and supportive culture.
pros:
-Office-centric project staffing:  stronger local relationship building, better work life balance
-Formal / informal global training programs
-Collaborative supportive people throughout the organization interested in individual success
cons: -Unpredictability of management consulting due to being professional services (i.e., less control over timing and duration of working demands)

headline: Broad exposure to multiple industries and their most challenging problems
pros: Great career training, unmatched exposure to CEOs and their senior leaders
cons: I personally can improve the way I set boundaries

headline: Best firm with the best culture
pros: Bain has an incredibly cohesive culture, oriented towards people development and client impact. Excellent people, who are exceptionally talented. There are plenty of social events to help build strong bonds within the firm and in the offices. Talent management is taken very seriously, with one of the most comprehensive and rigorous programs at every level of development and seniority.
cons: Need to learn the lingo (lots of acronyms), but not too daunting.

headline: Exhilerating growth
pros: Personal impact on real companies doing important work, with lots of formal and informal support
cons: Client work is spikey in terms of hours and stress (common to consulting industry)

headline: Fantastic place to build the general manager skillset and drive meaningful change for your clients
pros: quality of your coworkers; work on some of the toughest business problems
cons: Consulting is a demanding lifestyle (not unique to Bain)

headline: Best place to start a career
pros: The work we do is pretty powerful - we are helping the world's top leaders solve their toughest problems.  I improve organizations that are positively impacting the lives of people around the world.  It is pretty exciting to see the impact of my work in some of my favorite brands or mentioned in the press.  The experience, exposure and skills I am gaining by solving these complex problems is invaluable to achieve my long-term career goals.
cons: It is not easy to develop real-world solutions to complex problems.  As a result, the work can be demanding.  The Bain culture is flexible and supportive - making the long-hours manageable and rewarding.

headline: Interesting work with great people who are fun and provide great professional development coaching.
pros: The best part about working at Bain is the people.  The people make the fantastic culture, provide wonderful professional development and coaching opportunities, and make the job fun.  The people are incredibly smart, contributing to a stimulating and challenging work environment.  Additionally, Bain's clients include the top companies in most industries, so there is always an opportunity to work on very interesting, challenging and important business issues.  Finally, given the project nature of the work, there is tons of variety, providing a new and interesting business problem to work on every 3-6 months.
cons: The negatives of the job include travel and long hours.  Many clients are not based near the office and require some regular travel.  This can get tiring week-in and week-out.  The hours can also get long, depending on the project (65+/week).  However, neither of these two factors is necessarily the case.  There are plenty of locally-based or light travel options, and while some weeks have long hours, they are balanced by shorter weeks or down-time in between projects.  Finally, given the size of the company, advancement is very structructured without much room for flexibility to accelerate or decelerate based on individual needs and abilities.  For those who like stability and structure, this could be a positive thing.

headline: Best management consulting has to offer
pros: Phenomenal opportunities for professional growth and career development. The partners I work with are truly invested in me and my success. Ability to work on the most challenging problems that executives are facing - and to develop practical solutions that have significant impact. Firm invests in people for the long-term.
cons: This is a top tier professional services firm, so you need to understand that client needs are top priority and this is not a 9-5 job. Within management consulting, I think Bain does as good a job (if not better) than most at helping manage work/life balance, but ultimately it's up to the individual employee to be assertive.

headline: Outstanding platform for launching a career in anything
pros:
-Smart, passionate people
-Fascinating case work
-Everyone is really nice and friendly
-The market will treat you incredibly well after 1-2 years at Bain
cons: -Not a ton of upside for top-performers at junior levels

headline: Brilliant colleagues and a brilliant culture
pros: The people are incredible- smart, fun, humble, nice. The work is incredibly interesting. Compensation is very good. The culture is unmatched in consulting.
cons: As in all management consulting, hours can be long and travel can be difficult, depending on the case/client

headline: Amazing experience - real results, great learning
pros: Opportunity to really make a difference. You get significant responsibility to help tackle your clients most challenging problems. Bain has a very supportive environment where your team, your supervisors and your mentors all care about developing you and helping you build your skills and your career. Also, it is a genuinely fun place to work - at the end of the day, it's the people that make the difference
cons: The travel can get old at times, but Bain works hard to ensure the overall lifestyle can be sustainable

headline: Amazing colleagues; focus on being the best place to work in consulting
pros: Strong focus on people & culture, including fostering office & class communities, a best-in-class training program, and firm-wide events such as Bain World Cup. Fantastic colleagues. Highly engaging work on interesting problems across a range of industries and topics. Efforts to make the job as sustainable as possible.
cons: The unavoidable downsides of consulting: travel (though less frequent / less far than at many competing firms) and unpredictable / highly variable hours. Some comp/benefits/perks not as good as at competitors.

headline: Bain - A challenging, fast paced, collaborative, and rewarding place to work
pros: Work with the smartest people you will ever meet, solve companies hardest problems, have a real and immediate impact on your clients
cons: There is no doubt - consulting is demanding and Bain is no exception.  You will work very hard and push yourself.

headline: Bain will launch your career!
pros: Bain is a great place to start your career.  They have great pay & benefits, flexible hours, a lot of training opportunities, and mentorship programs.  The work hard, play hard atmosphere that is really fun and educational.
cons: There isn't anything negative I can say about my experience at Bain.

headline: Hands down best place to work
pros:
People, culture, career opportunities, ability to grow and learn, compensation... all top notch.

I'm convinced I could not find a company with the same quality of people... smart, fun, collaborative, friendly, interesting
cons: Life can be unpredictable, but that is the only way you get the variety and the interesting work!

headline: Never stopped raising the bar, never stopped teaching me to grab it
pros:
Constant escalation of my skills, but paired with a huge amount of support. I was always in over my head and there was always someone throwing me a life preserver and teaching me to swim.This has stayed true for 8 years.

Great culture, great people.
cons: Gets stressful when you're close to a promotion point - though I admit this is most self-imposed!

headline: Make real impact while developing a tremendous skill set
pros:
1. You work on the most important, complex problems the client is facing - which is both immensely challenging and energizing.
2. Because of this, you get the chance to develop a wide range of skills that truly prepare you for a career as a business leader, regardless of your plans (stay at Bain, move on to for or not-for profit
3. The support network - and just the general type of people that you are surrounded with - is fantastic. You really become friends with your colleagues and so many people take an active interest in your development and overall satisfaction with the firm/office/career.
cons: It's consulting, so there the typical long hours and decent amount of travel. As a member of management, trying to make all the pieces fit can be challenging, balance client demands with the desires of people on the team, etc...

headline: Came for 2 years, still here after 6+
pros: Fantastic, supportive colleages. Interesting work across industries and challenging types of problems. Best in class training - have been to 5 global training sessions in fantastic locations with even better trainers.
cons: Client service and work ethic places demands on work-life balance; hard to find balance on a daily or weekly basis pending deadlines and deliverables

headline: Incredible opportunities and incredible people...not like any other consulting firm
pros:
Things that make this culture amazing are wired into the governance, compensation and I operating model of the firm.  It's not an accident or just a killer recruiting engine.

There's a reason Bain is not embroiled in scandals or about to be sold...it's about the people and culture.
cons: Consulting has its downsides, but wouldn't trade Bain for any other firm.

headline: Fantastic place to learn, develop, and work with inspiring people
pros:
Significant dedication to your professional development
Steep learning curve that never seems to flatten
Awesome, smart, insprining, fun co-workes you sincerly miss when you move on to a new project
cons:
Travel cases can drag on (4 days a week in Phoenix for 6+ months)
It's hard - as soon as you've mastered your job, you're expected to take on more

headline: an ok experience
pros: people are great, the atmosphere are friendly, they are willing to help and make you grow in a very fast pace.
cons: boring ground research, have to make cold calls, not enough data/they are short of budget to support the projects which sucks.

headline: The most incredible set of learning experiences I've ever had
pros: The people are fantastic, the problems you are tasked to solve are challenging and interesting, and the training/coaching is second to none.
cons: At times your schedule can be unpredictable and swing from very manageable to unmanageable, but this is to be expected in the world of strategy consulting.

headline: Best place to work, hands down
pros:
Bain does amazing work for its clients.  The focus is always on delivering results and working collarboratively with the clients.  It is very rewarding work.

The people at Bain are the best.  People are supportive and help you develop your career.  The combination of making an impact at my clients and working with amazing people make me want to build my career at Bain.
cons: As with all consulting, the hours can be long, so know what you're getting into before choosing a consulting career.  Bain is rewarding, both financially and personally, and it takes dediciation to sustain it long term.

headline: Great people, great culture, great work
pros:
The people you work with are always high quality and geniunely invest in your future.
The local staffing model produces an environment that is more sustainable than other consulting companies I have worked for.
The culture results in a place that is fun to work in and long-lasting relationships inside and outside of the workplace.
cons:
The generalist model certainly has its pros and cons - especially when you join later in your career.
Bain's dominance in the world of private equity can result in some great learnings, but also pretty much requires its employees to take a tour through the demanding Private Equity Group at some point in their career.

headline: Incredible!
pros:
Strong focus on personal development
Value driven approach minimizes unnecessary work and yield loss
Smart and collaborative people
Relatively more sustainable
Fun culture
cons:
More office centric than key competitors (not always a negative)
Room for improvement in diversity and sustainability

headline: At Bain, the work is both challenging and interesting and the people truly make it the greatest place to start a career
pros: I have worked on some very interesting projects around the country.  I have been given the training and mentoring needed to succeed, while having the autonomy to drive results for our clients with minimum oversight.  As great as the work is, at the end of the day, it really is about the people.  The people at this company care about your success and really push you to succeed
cons: The work we do is great but the lifestyle can be rough at times.  Traveling away from a family is never easy, but Bain does try to accommodate a more flexible work schedule when possible.  Additionally, leading up to a big client update, the hours can be pretty rough, again taking a toll on the work/life balance.

headline: Best place to build a career!
pros: Incredible learning opportunities - I am learning everyday and am never bored. Tremendous flexibility. I really feel like I can work full-time and also be an everyday part of my children's lives. Great support - I always feel like there are people to help me and advise me when I have questions or want to bounce ideas around.
cons: Bain is an intense, exciting and exhausting place to work. You will be challenged by your colleagues every day and cannot come to work without your A-game on.

headline: Unparalleled opportunity to work with amazing clients & teammates, and have real impact on exciting companies.
pros: Bain has been an amazing place for me to learn; not only about multiple industries but also from incredible senior leaders, both within Bain and at my clients.  I've had access to decision making at the top level of management at incredible companies, both large and small, and the opportunity to have real impact on the outcomes at those clients.  As a working mother of young children, I've also been able to grow my career in a sustainable (though challenging) atmosphere where I've always felt supported.  Bain takes care of its people.
cons: Consulting is a challenging lifestyle that isn't for everyone.

headline: Flexibility makes for a rich experience
pros:
Overall,  I'm proud to work at Bain---we work collaboratively to help our clients achieve great results.    The learning curve is steep and we tackle exciting problems. 
Personally,  I've changed roles as my family situation has evolved, and I truly appreciate Bain's flexibility.   I've seen many other people benefit from the flexibility, too.
cons: The cons are driven by the industry--not the company.    Consulting is a demanding profession, and the unpredictable hours and heavy travel can be draining.

headline: Inspiring work environment with high expectations
pros:
- inspiring work environment resulting from being surrounded by incredibly high calibre talent who push you to be your best
- fantastic culture built on the philosophy of "work hard, play harder"
- genuine commitment to employee happiness and fulfillment
- fascinating work with exposure to tough business problems faced by top companies
cons:
- demanding schedules and workload
- Bain's lean model means that there's always more work than resources

headline: Great company for fresh graduate
pros:
Very good training and organized mentor/buddy program
Very good benefits
Good relationship/friendship among the same class young consultants
cons:
Bad work-life balance
Working over time is taken as granted
Meaningless work of massaging numbers
Young people have to book restaurants, buy lunch/dinner for the team

headline: Associate Consultant
pros: Great culture and people.  Training on fundamentals also very good.
cons: Project experience depended heavily on the managers and partners.  If partners can manage client expectations or project scope well, then expect to work your ass off for something they may not be well received.

headline: My time at Bain has far exceeded my expectations
pros:
Incredibly smart but humble people
Laser focus on results
Genuine care for people and work/life balance
Great benefits
Meritocracy
cons: Many people do not understand what you do

headline: Best education to do whatever comes next in life
pros: You learn an amazing amount about how to get things done - in business or in other organizations.  Not just about specific tactics like 'how to put together a cash flow' - Bain teaches you how to change organizations.  We do a lot of work in the trenches with our clients, and it feels like we learn both the strategic 'what do we need to do' as well as the equally important 'how do we navigate an organization to get this done'
cons: Stress - life in consulting often means that you are really engaged in your work - not just when you're in the office

headline: Making tremendous impact in an incredibly supportive environment
pros: I have had the opportunity to work on & affect game-changing issues for clients in several different industries during my career here.  The work itself has been interesting, challenging and pushed me to the next level.  While doing this, I have felt incredibly supported.  I work with really smart people who care a lot in my success and have gone out of their way to invest in me - both coaching me on skills required to get to the next level here, but also taking time to talk to me about my long-term career goals and what is the best fit next step given my long-term interests (which are outside of Bain).  I've also had a chance to take advantage of the some of the flexibility here including doing an externship with a non-profit, working 60-80% and taking a sudden leave during a family crisis.  Bain has been incredibly supportive every step of the way.
cons: The consulting lifestyle can be challenging given client demands and there is definitely a ramp-up period to figuring out how to work effectively and in a style that works best for you.  But anyone pursuing a career in professional services should expect to work hard.

headline: A wonderful platform for a career
pros:
Bain offers a wonderful oppoortunity to work with top executives in the private, public, and non-profit sectors on their largest strategic issues.  I can't imagine a better place to learn more about how to identify opportunities and work with executive teams to make their organizations more successful.

The Bain culture is absolutely extraordinary.  The people are extraordinarily gifted while also quite humble and service oriented.  It is an absolutely wonderful place to work.
cons: The work at bain is intense and you will likely never feel like you've mastered your job.  You mentally take your work home with you because the problems are both challenging and engaging and there is always more you could do.  The job is a good fit for people who are comfortable, and even energized by, the ambiguity inherent in complex strategy problems.

headline: Amazing place to develop as a leader
pros: Analytical; laser focused on working with client executives willing to change the status quo; top-tier client roster, from Fortune 50 to growth-capital backed companies; team-oriented, supportive environment; fantastic exit opportunities if you choose to leave Bain
cons: Like all high-achieving careers, you'll work hard, but you will get lots of support along the way.  You should go into a Bain career wanting to learn and make a difference with your clients.  You need to care about your clients' business as much, if not more, than they do.  That can come with longer hours early in your career.

headline: The last job i'll ever have; no place I'd rather work
pros:
The people are extraordinarily talented
Colleagues are kind, empathetic...they listen
The compensation package is very strong; I'll retire before 50
One gets to decide what they want to do, what they want to work; do what energizes you
Personal development opportunities are terrific; at all levels, people are stretched
Best carrer opportunity to develop a general manager toolkit
Spend a few years at Bain, and you will develop a new level of confidence in your problem-solving skills, your ability to influence, and your capacity to effect organizational change
cons: The consulting lifestyle is demanding; if you aren't down with frequen travel, find another career

headline: Best place to work in strategy consulting
pros: Positive environment - on the whole you work with, friendly, smart, motivated people. Learning from and coaching others on your team is the most rewarding part of this job
cons: Depends on your luck, but work life balance can go down the drain. Not always, but will at some point. At lower levels, you have less of a voice and control over the work, but that improves with tenure

headline: Best training for anything you want to do in life
pros: Always learning something new. Opportunities to expose yourself to different industries, markets, geographies. Surrounded by incredible people, who are smart, interesting, and mostly compassionate / interested in mutual benefit. Very low internal competition, extremely collegiate environment.
cons: Sometimes you just have to suck it up and do work that's less appealing for a time. Not always an opportunity to work on what you want to work on, whether it be industry or time of work. You have to actively manage work/life balance to keep yourself sane.

headline: Definitely best consulting company to work for!
pros:
great people
really nice atmosphere
you can see their focus on the "fit" to the company, which results in a high level of cooperation among employees
cons: long working hours - but i guess it's not a secret for all the consulting companies

headline: Good
pros: Career opportunities are great and happen fast. This always true no matter the project or the location within the company. Also colleagues are amazing professionals.
cons: Work-life balance. Work hours are long and the stress level is high. Not always projects are interesting and not always value is added to client.

headline: Challenging, continuous self-improvement, no worklife balance
pros: Smart people to work with, great brand name, intellectual stimulation
cons: Very long hours, no worklife balance, demanding partners and colleagues, constantly have to prove yourself

headline: one of the best place to work for
pros:
smart people
fun filled environment: parties, offsites, booze and fun
superb culture
good compensation 
work life balance
cons: not very well defined career path for admin staff. Top management of india offices is not very effective.

headline: A great personal growth experience
pros: Intellectually stimulating and great people to work with
cons: Hours are too long in Asia

headline: Great business boot camp experience post-MBA
pros: Good exposure to a range of industries and business issues. Bain does not have any particular focus except for private equity, so you could end up working on a Pulp & Paper company re-organization one day and a private equity due diligence on a Oil & Gas E&P company the next day.
cons:
This office in particular had a pretty rough work/life balance. While you were on a case you were expected to be there from 9am to 12am Mon-Thurs and do some work on Sunday evening. 
Biggest issue was the lack of control on what you work on and the lack of control on which managers you end up working with. When you had a good manager or partner to work with it was great, if you had a bad manager it could be awful.

headline: Awesome
pros: Great people, great learning, entrepreneurial culture
cons: Can be long hours, some travel

headline: It has been a terrific experience
pros: Great people, learning, perks, decent comp
cons: Maybe a bit too process heavy

headline: Great company, strong values and culture
pros: Very smart people, hardworking culture, access to Partners
cons: Competitive as can be expected, long working hours

headline: The best consulting experience across the big three
pros: Results focus, far greater visibility at client, never encountered any "ivory tower" mentality
cons: work life balance and considerable deadline pressure. threat of understaffing, particularly during a recession

headline: probably the best way to learn how business operates right after graduating college
pros: good to learn business by sharing executives' issues and their perspectives
cons: it's basically agency's job; very long working hours

headline: Great learning curve and future career opportunities
pros: Great future career opportunities, opening many headhunter's doors
cons: Compensation, although high, is not in line with the sacrifices and workings hours that the job asks (at least in the Italian office)

headline: Everything you'd expect it to be
pros: The work is engaging and nearly everyone you work with is brilliant. Lots of effort put into personal development and growth. People really care about you, and the atmosphere is more collaborative than competitive.
cons: Bain, like all consulting, has highly variable work. Sometimes it's very, very busy, other times it's not. The problem is that planning for it is very difficult. You can rarely commit to things outside of work more than 1-2 days in advance, if at all.

headline: SAC to CTL
pros: Excellent training, working with the best/smartest people, amazing experiences!
cons: Long hours, have to switched on to the "Bain Kool-Aid" 100% of the time

headline: Very good
pros: Travel and flexibility is very good. Good learning opportunities. Decent salary for hours worked. Very international feel to all of the offices
cons: Lack of visibility over where you will be staffed next. Some issues around taking leave but all in all a very good place to work

headline: Senior Specialist
pros: Bain has one of the brightest and friendliest people. The environment is really friendly and people try to take care of each other
cons: You have to put in lot of hours. If you did not sign-up for it then you will not be able to survive.

headline: Great place to work
pros: Incredible people, lots of opportunities
cons: Struggling to stay true to roots with growth - next 1-2 years will be interesting.  Getting increasingly hierarchical.

headline: Bain AC
pros: Smart people, great network.  Great first job out of school
cons: Travel too much.  Client services is tough

headline: Great place to start a career
pros: Interesting work, good people and environment
cons: Hours are long, lots of travel required

headline: Top-rate firm, incredible culture
pros: Incredibly talented people, working in a team environment on most complex business problems for senior management.   Very supportive, fun, and friendly culture.   incredible learning, both on-the-job and through formal training programs.
cons: The work can be intense at times.   There are many mechanisms and programs in place to help with work/life balance, but at the end of the day, client services work will always be demanding.

headline: Great company to work for and a great place to start a career
pros: Bain is a great company to work for because it is young, fun, and welcoming. There is a lot of team work and collaboration going on. It is a very fast-paced company with a lot of very intelligent people, so it is a challenging environment, but still welcoming and there are many people available as mentors.
cons: Some of the downsides are longer hours, so not as much social time. Many of the social time is with other people from the company, which is nice, but it is also important to have down time away from work.

headline: professional and high-quality, market leader, well-established
pros:
- High Quality
- Work-Balance
- Very Clear Career Path
- Subsidy for future studies
cons:
- Not competitive salary
- Not very decent welfare package

headline: Executive Assistant
pros: Excellent benefits and work-life balance, with numerous opportunities to enjoy esprit events and peer social interactions.
cons: Defined separation of consulting group from support staff that translates to inequitable lines of compensation.

headline: Great people, great culture, okay work
pros:
+People are fantastic
+Learning is rapid, and the analytical tools you build are transferrable
+From a high-level, the work is very interesting, and you can get a lot of responsibility at a junior level
cons:
- Relative to other consulting firms, feels like junior people get less exposure to clients
- Promotions at the more junior level are tenure-based, rather than merit-based
- The junior level work can be very uninteresting, and you live in Excel/Powerpoint

headline: Bain is a great first employer to build your strategic skills;
pros: Learning curve, great colleagues, dynamic company with much drive, very smart people;
cons: worklife-balance is non-existent, hard to balance with private life / family life;

headline: Great company to work for
pros: Brightest people, interesting work, and great training
cons: Difficult lifestyle, travel and long hours are not sustainable

headline: Great place to learn a lot: soft skills, strategic thinking, business sense
pros:
Great training environment: instittionalized professional development systems, with regular chats with supervisor and mentor, formal review after each case, consensus review after every 6 months, global training program every 1.5 years of your tenure on average, local training program every 2-6 months each year (depending on level). Development criteria common across offices.
Strong culture: true north, results driven, answer-first / hypothesis led approach, etc; culture common across offices, but some variations in work-life balance.
Strong global network of well-connected offices (and hence opportunities), like 6-month transfers, permanent transfers, on-demand transfers
cons:
Sometimes work can be physically very tiring, without creating a lot of value for the client; leadership team's ability to manage client's direction and expectation can vary wildly
You will not learn/develop too deeply in any technical knowledge or expertise: e.g. financial forcasting and valuation modeling

headline: Great career jumpstarter
pros: Mentorship, Learning, Opportunity to advance quickly
cons: Lifestyle not always under your control

headline: Great career opportunities and culture
pros: Talented people, very career oriented
cons: Hard to get work/life balance

headline: Ok but hasn't lived up to expectations
pros:
Some amazing and diverse colleagues
Ability to work across a multitude of industries
Good exit opportunities
New London office is a nice work environment
cons:
Long hours and little work-life balance in most teams (you can never make any plans outside work Monday-Thursday)
Training in London, especially on the job training/coaching is extremely variable. Often feels like luck of the draw as to the support/opportunity you get to develop
Pay isn't great when compared to the hours worked and the sums senior management are taking home
Hierarchical set up of case teams

headline: Ineffective and arrogant management style
pros: Great crowd of people at lower levels- however, its seems a lot of the best people leave at consultant level
cons: Very hierarchy driven office, with a high level of arrogance among partners and senior managers. At times quite clear to the whole team how insecure partner/manager combinations translate into burning the team, driving high yield loss from overengineered output and micromanaged process.

headline: Great company
pros: Great people, great environment to workin
cons: Tough job, straining at times

headline: Good place to work for
pros: People are smart and nice. Lots of opportunities for learning.
cons: Expectation level is very high, and especially for MBA new hire it's very hard to catch up.

headline: Working at Bain for the past 2.5 years
pros: Great culture and great perks
cons: No room for growth at Bain for the consulting support staff

headline: Hard work, high learning curve, up or out. But they pay you for it.
pros: Very smart, ambitious colleagues, and high earning potential.
cons: Completely unsustainable lifestyle.  Young managers with little experience managing people.

headline: A great place to work
pros: Great people, interesting projects and fun environment
cons: Work hard, long hours and office is full

headline: Great company to work for with limited opprtunities to grow
pros: Great culture and wonderful colleagues
cons: Very limited job scope with no growth and restrictive compensation

headline: Tough but good experience
pros: Colleagues were great and I met many smart young people that will remain my friends for life.
cons:
Long work hours
 little control over personal schedule
Case experience too dependent on client

headline: Work Hard, Play Hard, but doesn't show CSS same respect as other staff levels
pros: Work life balance is great
cons: Lack of CSS respect from upper management and pay

headline: Great professional development and fun people
pros:
Young, vibrant office culture.
Great training programs and interesting work.
Excellent transition support and opportunities post-Bain
cons:
Generalist culture until you are very senior in the organization
No longer lighter travel than other firms
Staffing process can be a bit challenging at times

headline: The best job to have straight out of college
pros:
- Outstanding professional development of all employees
- Intellectually challenging, fascinating work
- Great people to work with
cons:
- Longer hours
- Some demanding travel

headline: Great company to work for
pros: Great training, smart peers, generous benefits
cons: Long hours, unpredictable schedule, tiring travel

headline: Smart, results-driven, people-friendly
pros:
Incredibly smart yet warm and accessible leadership team
Great brand; one that will open doors for you well into the future
Rapidly rising responsibilities and opportunities for professional development, with strong internal support system
Excellent skills development for future entrepreneurs
Strong alumni network
cons:
Uneven growth/development across offices; some work incredibly long hours with comparatively less personal satisfaction (e.g. Asian offices)
Occasionally do not communicate hard messages strongly enough to employees given the firm's culture of being "nice" and "supportive"

headline: A phenomenal place made up of an exceptionally intelligent, thoughtful, fun group of people
pros: The culture is unparalleled, the work is challenging and engaging
cons: Some cases require travel, but not all

headline: Amazing people and a lot of opportunities
pros:
People and culture
Great learning opportunities
cons: Work life balance could be tough if travelling but still better than other consulting firms

headline: Great place to advance the career
pros: Company pays a great deal of attention to mentoring and making sure each employee is learning the most. Its commitment to working together with the client to bring recommendations to fruition is also inspiring, and makes me keep wanting to do my best in each assignment.
cons: Work life balance can be challenging since the time span of the projects is short, and generally there's a lot of interaction between consultants and clients to create engagement.

headline: Great learning experience - but not very sustainable
pros: Great way to build a generalist management toolkit; every year you learn a different skillset and have can get exposure to many industries in short timeframe
cons: Work/life balance is difficult despite continued focus from management; don't plan on having a life outside work during the week

headline: Great Experience
pros: Great people, challenging environment, fast moving
cons: Working hours, travel, work life balance

headline: It's a Gym
pros: High growth and steady curve of learning / experience
cons: Very limited Work / life balance

headline: Unparalleled opportunity to learn and grow while working in a fun environment
pros: Work with sharp and down to earth people, both upwards and downwards. Amazing learning opportunities. Bias to action.
cons: Lifestyle balance (Again, this is a given  in management consulting, and I realize that it is better than some peers)

headline: Good company overall, though different experiences in regional office
pros: strong culture and nice, down to earth people...
cons: high turnover translates to limited investment in mentorship

headline: Great company to gain work experience
pros: Open culture, entrepreneur, non hierarchical
cons: "scale" and ïndustry expertise" is required to seriously participate in certain industry sectors.

headline: Great experience!
pros:
Great perks, lots of sponsored social events, colleagues are typically fun to work with, smart as possible and have tons of different backgrounds!
Pretty good client exposure
cons: Depending on the case you are in, you can have very heavy workloads! I've been to cases with average 15-16 hours a day (only 2-3 weeks case) and cases with 10 hours a day (3 months)

headline: Unmatched people and opportunity
pros: Some of the most talented people around and the marketing story is real - there is a true focus on results and making sure recommendations can be implemented and deliver real value.  While there are a variety of personalities at all the consulting firms, Bain under-indexes on "tough" personalities that people are trying to avoid working with, which is where you really feel the "people" difference at Bain.
cons: The work/life balance is tough as is the case with any consulting firm, and there's a fairly strong bias toward former AC's at the Consultant (post-MBA) level.  Coming in new from business school, you'll feel "behind" the former AC's, which is a challenging gap to close as they will tend to get accelerated opportunities and higher level performers to manage early on.

headline: Highly rewarding and great for career progression
pros: Great people who really care about both their colleagues and solving client problems. It is refreshing how team-oriented people are. Excellent professional development opportuniities. Very motivating environment.
cons: Hours can be long, although compensated for by recognition from managers / partners and rewarding work. Although  you can influence which project/s you get to work on, you don't have full control - it is driven by business needs.

headline: Great company to launch a career
pros:
- Diversity of projects creates many learning opportunities
- Great on the job training and both hard & soft skill building
- Strong culture focused on performance
- Smart, driven colleagues
cons:
- Projects aren't always interesting
- Project lengths are increasing, meaning there are fewer opportunites to see more industries & functions
- Client service means life is unpredictable

headline: personal review of Bain and Company
pros:
personal review of Bain and Company
funtime, parties,funtime, parties
cons: work life balance is not good

headline: Associate Consultant
pros: Excellent opportunity to work at the highest levels at a variety of global companies.
cons: Frat boy culture sometimes is difficult to crack.

headline: Great culture, great learning opportunities
pros: No politics. Outstanding and fun people that don't take themselves too seriously. Interesting projects.
cons: Potentially long hours. Some constraints on project selection due to local staffing model.

headline: Excellent place to start your career
pros: Work with incredible people while developing invaluable analytical skills & understanding of business,  Very entrepreneurial and gives you opportunities to contribute to the office in ways you like through "Extra 10s".  Lots of formal and informal mentorship as well for learning.
cons: Very steep learning curve, hours more unpredictable (as with all consulting jobs)

headline: Great people & better management
pros:
-Management puts a lot of thought into structures and decisions that truly differentiate this place. 
-People here are not just satisfied, they are enthusiastic. That brings energy into the work. 
-The work is awesome!
cons: Though Bain does a great job of making it easier, consulting is a hard job

headline: challenging, yet rewarding
pros: smart people, great brand, results
cons: unsustainable work/life balance, need to hire more admin staff to help support office

headline: Great people, striving to make an impact
pros:
The firm has a strong focus on creating results for clients - you have the opportunity to work on things that matter to the client.

You have the opportunity for rapid career development. The leadership team are personally invested in your professional development, which is a priority for the firm.  The team environment is supportive and follows an apprenticeship model - you get to learn by doing, with support from a team of experts.

The firm regularly seeks feedback from clients and teams and acts on this feedback to improve our work and our working environment.  You will be given constant feedback, and will be given opportunities to work on your weaknesses.

Pay is comparable to other top tier consultancies.
cons: Achieving work-life balance can be difficult as at any premium professional services firm, though the leadership team are constantly working to improve this part of the job.  Often the work involves travel, though individual requests not to travel are taken seriously in staffing travel cases.

headline: It is a very good foundation and stepping stone to kick start your career
pros:
