Work across multiple industries
Work in live consulting projects across the globe
Can have the opportunity to shift to main consulting office in New Delhi ( based on performance and demand)
Lot of extra curricular activities
Fun culture
Good work life balance and good salaries
cons:
Post 2 years the work can get repetitive
Management is slightly complacent

headline: Bain is an amazing organization to work with.
pros: Its Culture, People, Passion and employee friendliness are the best points to describe BAIN
cons: Never felt any downside working with BAIN.

headline: Fantastic place to work
pros: Great variety of experience while developing a highly transferrable skill set; the coaching and mentoring you will get is fantastic, you are given the tools you need to grow and continue learning; competitive compensation; international transfer opportunities can be life-changing; great exit options; and most of all the people are amazing (extremely talented yet humble); Chicago office is one of the best in the global system
cons: The travel eventually takes its toll (though Bain does what it can to manage this and all the miles/points you’ll accumulate are a perk); your work-life balance and overall satisfaction for any 3-6 month period is highly project dependent (the rare poorly matched team or occasionally ornery client can make life difficult)

headline: A very fun and professionally rewarding place to work
pros: The fantastic people who work at Bain, the interesting types of roles and cases, always learning new things
cons: Working hours and sustainability, sometimes short visibility

headline: Great job out of undergrd
pros: Great people and culture, broad-based development, challenging work, travel, fun place to work
cons: Growth trajectory moderated by promotion cadence

headline: Amazing experience, unparalleled learning, awesome colleagues, company that really cares
pros: Smart down to earth colleagues, high impact work, great compensation,unparalleled training ground in business, high integrity partners, high focus on the individual, Bain always leans in when employees have challenges outside of work (eg health or personal issues). I have nothing but great things to say about Bain
cons: Long hours, unpredictable travel at times

headline: Great company to build foundational business skills
pros:
- Fun work hard, play hard culture
- Best business training ground
- Help make real change at clients, not just perform studies
cons:
- Lot of hours
- Can be a lot of trouble, although they have improved this quite a bit (office dependent also)
- Up or out meritocracy is good if you're going up, no so much if you are good but just need more time to mature

headline: A vibrant place to work with great culture and tones of opportunities for having impact and developing skills
pros:
- Minimum office politics: The company is very result oriented which encourages everyone to focus on the objective and reduces the politics involved compare to other companies that I worked at. 
-A true Meritocracy: The promotion process is truly based on merit which give all the employees motivation to focus on doing the best they can for solving the clients challenges  
-Great culture: Teams are extremely supportive which creates a ideal atmosphere to work in
cons: Bain probably has one of the best work life balance in consulting industry but at the end of the day the work load is not predictable making it difficult to plan your schedule during the week.

headline: Great place to work but takes getting used to!
pros: Great employer with an amazing cohort of down-to-earth, talented consultants who are fun to hang out with; great opportunities to travel both domestically and internationally, as well as pursue learning opportunities both within the Bain network but also through MBAs
cons: As with all professional services, hours can be long and travel intense. Increased turnover within the Australian business over the past couple of years, with sustainability and work/life balance being the biggest challenge facing the business.

headline: Great company to work for with an outstanding culture that I've never seen repeated at another company
pros: We have smart people and an outstanding culture at our company.  Everyone works as a team, always willing to help out, never let a Bainie fail.  We do exciting work and have great learning opportunities while having worklife balance.  What also is unique is our global network of outstanding professionals around the world.
cons: Growth opportunities for Consulting Support Staff are not as great

headline: Extremely focused learning experience, with lots of fun thrown in
pros:
Excellent people (direct, smart, focused)
Very fast learning curve - I was presenting my slides to C-level executives at the clients after only 1 year in Bain. This kind of experience is rather unique.
cons: The number of hours might get a little heavy sometimes. However, it's not a deal-breaker. Besides that, when working with clients your schedule can become hard to predict. It varies from project to project.

headline: People are awesome but work-life balance is terrible
pros:
1. Amazing people that have many interests besides work
2. Good salary 
3. A lot of travel outside Russia (office event, case team events, sometimes work opportunities)
cons:
1. Limited number of opportunities to choose project you want or transfer to another office
2. Work-life balance is terrible sometimes 
3. Graphics support is very limited

headline: Outstanding firm with amazing people.  I love this place!
pros: The people are outstanding.  Bain has built an incredibly special culture that is down to earth, collegial, supportive, intellectually stimulating, and just out right fun. I absolutely love coming to work here and truly miss the office and our people when I'm away.  That's a rarity and something I cherish each day.
cons: Client services is inherently challenging when it comes to work/life balance. Bain has a huge number of systems in place to track work/life balance and ensure each person has a great experience overall, but consulting will at times mean travel and late nights.  Overall, I've found the firm and the people to be extremely flexible and willing to help you make this career work.  Everyone here is invested in their life outside of Bain, so we are all aligned towards the same goal!

headline: Great place to start/accelerate career
pros: Day-to-day contact with brilliant professionals, exposure to C-level executives right from the start, great quality training and good money
cons: Very very long hours (including, sometimes, weekends), evaluation process can be more attached to political factors than to the truth itself

headline: Best place to work
pros: Humble, grounded, immensely talented people. Great diversity of talent, experience, and interests on the Bain team. Never a dull moment, opportunities for career growth year in and year out.
cons: Never a day off for your brain - your colleagues demand you to bring your A-game every day.

headline: Bad life style but a lot of learning
pros: Global training, exposure to different industries, fast learning environment
cons: Long working hours, unpredictable work schedule, spontaneous meetings and travel

headline: Lots of office politics and
pros:
Great brand
Clients are the very top in every industry
Great effort in training young resources
Very diverse work-force
cons:
Extremely long hours
excessive hierarchy
New joiners can easily get lost
Few times projects could be disappointing for people who studied business as they are mainly focused on strategic issues (no numbers)
limited comp package

headline: Filled with people I personally and professionally admire
pros:
There is no shortage of inspirational leaders.  I can safely point to the majority of my bosses/supervisors and say, "If this firm attracts those kinds of people, then I'm happy to be a part of it"
Your peers are there to help you.  The environment is intense and the work is challenging - it's enjoyable because you aren't 'competing' against your peers, you are propelled by them.
cons: Southeast office means a lot of travel to Thailand/Indonesia etc.  On the plus side you will typically always spend Friday in your home office with the rest of the team.

headline: Best place to start a career and really learn the skills to run a business
pros: Fantastic place to learn the full set of what it means to run a business, balancing both innovation and pragmatism. You will not find a more thoughtful, intelligent group of people who truly view the client's business as their own, and work hard to solve the problem (while remaining humble).
cons: The work/life challenges exist, as you'd expect in any management consulting job. Occassionaly, you could find yourself working on a project that you are less passionate about (e.g. in an industry you don't really like), and that makes the work/life trade-offs more difficult.

headline: Intense culture, can be political
pros:
Good perks
Good work environment
Good exit opportunities
cons:
Poor work/life balance
Work that is not very fulfilling
Up and out culture

headline: Work hard play hard
pros: Fastest way to learn biz fundamental and raise your ability to think strategically and logically
cons: Bad work-life balance.. sometimes hard to manage your relationship with other team members

headline: Fast-paced growth with dynamic and global outlook, but important to look after work-life balance
pros: Amazing growth, great compensation/benefits, global outlook
cons: Difficulty in maintaining your work-life balance is probably the only negative I can think of

headline: An excellent learning experience with diverse exposure
pros:
- Opportunity to quickly gain opportunity to interact with senior management personnel
- Great work culture and colleagues
- Strong focus on driving success for clients - both the organization as well as key leaders
- Open to discussing career outside Bain and supporting transition
cons:
- Work life balance takes a pounding with all the travel
- Something which is probably not totally avoidable, but sometimes work which is done is to keep the client happy and not because it's going to be adding significant value. Also, commercial priorities lead to doing work where Bain's probably not the most qualified in terms of capabilities.
- Compensation competitveness vis a vis other top tier consults is slipping

headline: First impressions always matter, and here they are amazing
pros:
Amazing working environment where everyone is willing to help the other in anything that is asked.
Interesting projects all over the place.
cons: So far nothing that I can point out. Everything is working perfectly

headline: Excellent experience
pros: Great people, great atmosphere. Most people that I have worked with are truly collaborative.
cons: Lifestyle and the way things work varies a lot between offices.

headline: Excellent experience and learning path
pros: People are great to work with. Always learning. Great culture and fun
cons: no Cons - so far everyone is very helpful and inspiring

headline: Best in class HR

headline: The best people and culture and unparalleled development opportunities
pros:
If there was ever a company that invested in its people it's Bain. Local and global training, formal mentorship and sponsor programs, diversity initiatives, customised learning, learning through apprenticeship - that's all Bain.
The Bain culture is very strong and cemented on genuine values that resonate with Bainies. People are very smart, but pragmatic, fun to work with and down to earth. We help each other out. You actually DO want to see these people on weekends!
cons: As in any other consulting job, the hours can be long and a bit unpredictable. It is really about getting used to it. But I think Bain is amongst the best in the industry in terms of actively managing sustainability and ensuring that flexible options are available so people don't get burned out

pros: Fun loving, yet hard working culture. You will want to be with the people you work with, making case teams a truly enjoyable experience. headline: Excellent Job
pros: Great people, committed management, Excellent culture.  This is a great place to work out of school, and I'd do it again in a heartbeat.
cons: Consulting industry means a lot of travel.  Generally low comp relative to some other options.  I think the lifestyle can also get tough at times, so be prepared for some long hours occasionally.  At those times, the job doesn't seem worth it, but if you look over a 3-6 month period, I always felt very happy to be where I was.

headline: International management consulting firm is a great first job out of college that prepares you to break into other areas
pros: Diligence of private equity targets in various industries, financial data analysis and modeling, market research, customer surveys, and collaborating with clients on strategy and buy-in to Bain action plans on 2-10+ person teams.  Fantastic culture, you will become part of a worldwide family and make friends who will be with you for life.
cons: Can feel distanced from true products and services, often feels like you are just giving advice rather than taking action.  Can be variable, long hours, not the best job in terms of hourly wage.

headline: Incredibly smart and hard-working teams working on high-energy, high-value client-services work
pros: Teamwork and culture are the focal point of Bain.  You will be challenged and stretched with the level of responsibility given to you at every stage in your career, but you will be given every amount of support from your teams to be successful at what you do.  As far as client-services work goes, the problems Bain is brough in to solve are often at the forefront of senior executives' minds.  Bain works hard to deliver practical results that the client can use, instead of an array of unprioritized opinions.  There is a deep focus on driving to an answer early on during cases, instead of waiting to turn over every rock and then deciding the best path forward.  Answers are developed collaboratively with the client, which helps maximize the likelihood that clients will take to action even after Bain is finished with their deliverables.
cons: The job will take as much from you as you will give it.  One must learn to set boundaries and proactively manage work/life balance.  Bain is very respectful of work/life balance and personal priorities and committments, but only if you are actively voicing them and communicating them to the team.  Balance can be achieved on this job, but it, too, will only come with thoughtful work and planning.

headline: Great place to launch your executive career
pros: The career/geographic flexibility and awesome culture - young, vibrant, creative. I worked in four continents over my decade there.
cons: A lot bigger (and a bit more stuffy) than it used to be. Still great but has become a legitimate 'big' company.

headline: Great post-MBA landing spot
pros:
- Engaged and energetic people
- Workable lifestyle
- Multiple opportunities outside of work 

Bain is a great place to work post-MBA. I have colleagues that are younger and engage in multiple additional opportunities including the Bain Band, non-profit work, and recruiting, as well as colleagues who have young children and still find time to balance their case work while spending time with their families. Los Angeles in particular is a smaller office within the North American system and within 3 months you'll definitely know everyone's name (as opposed to just randomly passing them in the hall and awkwardly nodding)
cons:
- High turnover (typical of consulting)
- May have to spend some time in your car

Like any consulting you may be staffed in a case that involves significant and / or inconvenient travel (but there's always Starwoods) or with a manager whose working style differs from your own. But these apply to the field in general more than Bain and I think the company does a good job of utilizing a regional model to minimize excessive or unnecessary travel and having multiple opportunities for upward feedback including monthly case team surveys that are displayed in the office kitchen to help improve case team dynamics.

headline: Working at Bain has given me work/life flexibility and the opportunity to make a significant global  impact
pros: The people are smart, dynamic and fun and the global network of peers is fantastic.  There is a strong focus on results and efficiency which optimizes the work we do and the outcome for our clients. The company does more than help other companies grow their profits,they are also very commited to driving social change and have both a formal and informal way for employees to get involved.  There are great flexible career path options to enhance work/life balance - I'm taking advantage of one right now.  And if you decide Bain isn't for you, it's a highly sought-after training ground for other careers (headhunters call all the time) and there is a strong alumni network to leverage for connections.
cons: As with any consulting firm, being client-facing comes with two big cons: travel and schedule unpredictability.  Bain tries to minimize both (e.g. not being away the full week if on a travel case, planning key client meetings in advance, anticipating the unexpected), but there's always an element that will remain uncontrollable.

Employees from the other global offices coming to do thier rotation programs also find the work culture incredibly different than offices abroad. headline: Absolutely terrible, would not recommend firm to anyone
pros:
Good reasons are 
1) the people -- consulting attracts the best / brightest students, and Bain is an awesome firm in that regards.

2) The support that the junior Bainies give.  Most people there Consultant and below (that's the level immediately post-MBA) are good people and support each other however possible.

3) Work-life balance -- obviously consulting stinks but at least Bain tried (weekly health checks, meetings on how to make life better).
cons:
1) Incredible sketchiness.  The partners / managers are more interested in lining their own pockets with money than providing useful advice -- case in point is that the managers / partners are much more concerned with extending cases (calling 'rolling' in consulting lingo) than actually providing good advice

2) Cult-like intensity.  The excellent reputation is proactively managed, such that I wouldn't be surprised if this point is followed by tons of comments that support Bain and try to paint me as a bad apple (for the record I wasn't).  There's also a strong culture of following, simply because there's so much direct feedback.  Bain did not appreciate diversity whatsoever -- any divergent thoughts / actions were quickly fixed, and the vast majority of leaders ended up leaving the organization as quickly as they could.  

3) Incredibly political.  Everything in Bain, including your feedback review, is group driven -- if even one senior partner takes a stand for or against you, it either jump start or completely destroy your career (I have seen it both ways).  Most people join consulting because they're risk averse and that only gets worse as people get promoted -- as a result everyone in the higher ranks just tries to blend into the crowd and not rock the boat.

4) Limited skills learned.  A lot was said to me about how the skills I learned would be helpful later, which is completely false.  At Bain (and other consulting firms), we perfect our analysis / presentation skills -- but to be perfectly honest, unless you're already great at those, you're not getting hired in the first place (and you're certainly smart enough to do whatever you want to begin with).  I'm not sure the extra 10-20% of refining your thought process will make any substantial difference.  Bain does not teach leadership or implementation in any way, shape, or form -- and the risk aversion you learn at Bain will get in the way of whatever you will do later.  At best, I believe it's a wash.

In summary I would not spend a year or two here, and I would certainly advise against staying longer than that and trying to make partner.  And by the time you make partner, the industry itself will be in decline and your margins (and take-home salary) will be far lower than what they are now.  And besides, too many things can go wrong in the meantime -- and it's not like a manager is really qualified to do anything in the workforce other than stay in a strategy role in a large corporate.  If you want to stay in strategy then by all means... but for the other 99% of us, just do what you want to as soon as you can.

headline: Growth Fueling Inconsistency
pros:

Great way to gain additional post-MBA experience while exploring a variety of industries
Opportunity to work with clients at a very high level
cons:
Lots of inconsistency at smaller offices.

Growth of Atlanta and Dallas offices exceeded the ability to attract candidates at the level of quality of other North American offices, especially at manager level where they've been brought in by lower-caliber firms. 

Reality of travel is that once you get away from an office in a city that has a big base of potential clients, you'll be on the road all the time. Staffing has also become national. Can be hard to build mentors within your home office if staffed under managers based elsewhere.

Some consultants work for the same client for case after case.

headline: Great place to work coming out of college and learn about the "real world".
pros: Great place in terms of work/life balance. Managers are very fair about lettign employees use thier vacation time and are understanding when unexpected scenarios present themselves. The company is very unique in the culture and the various activties they offer throughout the year to reward employees. When they want to do something they do go all in. There is no holding back or cutting corners.
cons: Working in the administrative side of the business, chance for job growth and promotions are limited. A lot of the upper level managers have been here for a long time and are not going anywhere. There is very little chance to move up. There are no mid-level managerial positions and your career path can be very ambiguous at times. Hiring practices for open positions can be a lengthy process as the company looks to hire Senior level people at Junior level pay.
